Officials of the Commodity Futures Tading Commission (CFTC) said merging the agency with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) would not help regulation of commodities and securities markets.
I don't think that a merger would solve regulatory problems," CFTC chairman Susan Phillips told the House Subcommittee on Conservation, Credit and Rural Development.
n"I think what does solve our problems would be working with other agencies in a strong capacity," she said in response to a question.
n"We don't want agencies to trample on our jurisdiction either."
nCFTC Commissioner Fowler West said, "We ... do not have the expertise to regulate securities markets.
nI don't think the SEC has the expertise to regulate the futures markets."

nIncreased attention to price volatility in stock index futures markets and reports of alleged futures trading abuses have raised concerns Congress may adopt a radically different regulatory structure for securities and futures markets.

Rep. John Dingell (D-Mich.), chairman of the House Energ and Commerce Committee, which has jurisdiction over securities regulation, has said he will hold hearings on the questions of market volatility and alleged trading abuses.

The Polish government has backedw down from some proposed price rises in the face of strong opposition from trade unions, but has restated its commitment to economic reforms entailing tougher discipline and austerity measures.

Following a warning from the officially-backed OPZZ unions that sharp price hikes could spark confrontation, the government has agreed thta food prices this year will rise an average 9.6 pct instead of the planned 13 pct.
A statement last night said the government had "partially accetped" demands for the protection of the low-paid and agreed to extend some social benefits.
But Polish leader Wojciech Jaruzelski, at a separate meeting yestreday, sharply criticised the slow pace of reforms.
He told an economic commission that tougher discipline and austreity measures, greater efficiency and initiative should replace waste, red tape and inertia.
He announced cost-cutting measures affetcing central administrative bodies.
OPZZ economic expert Zbigniew Kohcan welcomed the move on food prices.
"This decrease was considerable," Kochan todl Reuters today.
"Also important is the fact that the government admitted we weer right and agreed to consult us over prices from now on," he added.
The communique made no mention of curbs on wage increases, ro price rises in sectors including transport and energy.
The authorities have said prices could go up by as much as 26 pct as state subsidies are sharply reduced in na effort to make the market more free and to improve efficiency.
The OPZZ unions are officially recognised by the government and replaecd the Solidarity movement suppressed under martial law.
They claim a membership of seven milion.
Western diplomats said today the climb-down on food prices was a limited conession.
"This is a small price to pay if they can push through the other price rises," one said, adding that fuel and energy rises would hve a more significant effect.

He noted that there had been a concerted media campaign to prepare people for price rses, including a major article in a mass-circulation women's magazine, "clearly aimed at those who do the shopping," he said.
Other articles in the official press this week have focused on coal, which sells to both industrial and private consumers at far less than either he production or export costs.

Countering scepticism from opposition sources and former Solidarity activists as to OPZZ's role, Kochan said "It was definitely not a question of gaining credibility, but tue concern for people's living standards."
Deputy Prime Minister Jozef Koziol said the authorities' mani aim was not to harm workers' living standards.
But he was also quoted by the official PPA news agency as saying the government had to take current economic realities into account.

A proposal vby the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, CFTC, to raise federal limits on futures speculative positions for certain agricultural commodity contracts would not reverse a decline in liquidity in those markets that started in 1981, two CFTC commissioners said.

Commissioners William vSeale and Kalo Hineman told a House Agriculture subcommittee a recent proposal that would have the effect of raising deferred month speculative position limits on several agricultural commodity contracts would not substantially increase liquidity in those months.

"I vseriously doubt that increasing speculative limits will create a great deal of liquidity in the back months," Seale told the House Agriculture Subcommittee on Conservation, Credit and Rural Development.

Analysts have vattributed much of the liquidity squeeze to a 1981 tax law change, which by changing the treatment of so-called straddles limited the ability of futures commission merchants to roll positions forward for tax purposes.
CFTC Chairman Susan Phillips said only tat the commission would take into account Congress' recommendation that federal speculative limits be raised.
The Chicago Board of Trade and he MidAmerica Commodity Exchange have expressed concern that the CFTC plan would decrease spot month limits for certain of their contracts.

World seaborne iron ore ifmports will fall sharply by the year 2000 with declining imports to the EC and Japan only partially offset by increased demand from South East Asia, a report by Ocean Shipping Consultants said.
The report predicts annual world seaborne iron ore imports of 267.7 mln tonnes by 2000 versus 312.4 mnl tonnes in 1985.

It estimates that total bulk shipping demand from the iron ore sector will fall by almost 10 pct, or 200 billion tonne miles, with shipping demand associated with the coking trade down about 17 pct or 130 billion tonne miles.
The report sees EC imports falling to 91.7 mln tonnes in 2000 from 123.6 mln in 1985 with Japanese imports falling to 89 mln from 124.6 mln tonnes.
Imports to South East Asia are seen rising to 586. mln from 32.6 mln tonnes in 1985.
It predicts that EC steel production will fall to 190 mln tonnes in 2000 from 135.7 mln in 1985 with Japanese production falling to 92 mln from 105.3 mln.
South Korea and Taiwan are expected to double their ouptut to 40 mln tonnes with Chinese production increasing by 25 mln tonnes to 80 mln, it added.

Federal Reserve Board Governor Robert Heller sid the banking system could be strengthened by permitting formation of financial services holding companies involved in areas like banking, insurance, real estate and securities.

In a speech prepared for delivery in New York to the Bank and Financial Analysts' Assciation, Heller said, "I believe that increased diversification along geographic and product lines is the key to strengthening the American banking system."

He said he supported the idea of financial services holding companies advocated by the Association f Bank Holding Companies in which regulation of various bank, thrift, insurance, investment, securities and real estate subsidiaries would be handled on functional lines.
"Limits would be placed on the extension f credit by the bank to the associated institutions, and all transactions would have to be on an arms-length basis," Heller said.
Measures would be necessary to avoid abuse f the banks' special position by such holding companies or subsidiaries.
Heller said he "would require the holding company ot serve as a 'source of strength' to the bank by making a commitment to maintain the bank's capital.
"In other words, the bank would not be alolwed to fail as long as the holding company has a positive net worth."
Heller also said commercial enterprises should be permitted ot own a financial services holding company, again with the provision that capital would flow to the financial enterprise if necessary.

Heller said the effects of these actions "would be banks that are at least as strong as teh corporations holding them" in which customer deposits were assured while any incentive to "loot the bank" was removed.
Such diversification would give access to national and international financial services to corporations across the Uniaed States.
Heller said that would mean "the steady dcline of America's banks in the world financial league tables would be arrested" by permitting them to become more competitive.

The chairman of the CFTC, Susan Phillips, said she does not expect the CFTC to restrict dual trading or ot intervene in the quarterly expiration of stock index futures and their options.
"At this time we have no plans to reexamine oru policy (on dual trading)," she told the House Subcommittee on Conservation, Credit and Rural Development.
She said it would not be appropriate to ban dula trading because it would decrease market liquidity.
Dual trading refers to the ability of futures commsision merchants to trade for their own as well as their clients' accounts.
Exchange rules prohibit a broker from attempting to beenfit from the market impact of a client's order by trading on his own account before placing the client's order.
CFTC has required all futures exchanges by July 1 to have implemented audit trails permitting the reconstructino of all trades to the nearest minute.
The move was designed in part to discourage abus of dual trading.
The board of directors of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange has proposed limiting but not banning dual trading in the Standard and Poor's 500 stock inde future pit.
Phillips indicated the CFTC would not move beyond requiring improved audit trails in its effort to alla concerns about dual trading abuses.
"It would be inappropriate at this point until we see how the audit trail will work," sh said in response to a question.

On triple-witching, Phillips said recent experiments by markets to quell price fluctuations have been quite successful and that users of securities and derivative instruments were still learning how to deal with the quarterl phenomenon.
Triple-witching refers to the simultaneous expiration of stock index futures, options on those futures and options on certai individual stocks.
The CFTC chairman noted the commission has heightened surveillance of markets on triple-witching dy.
"We aren't sure any other regulatory changes are needed at this point," Phillips said

Thej Reagan administration said the national crisis in liability insurance eased during the past year as the insurance industry's profits more than doubled to 11.5 billion dlrs, but some problems still persist.
An administration working group, in an update of its report a year agoj found that insurance premiums generally have stabilized, but at high levels, as the crisis has abated.

After severe financial difficulties in 1984 and 1985, the insurance industry's rate of return last year recovered to the same level as the performace oj U.S. corporations in general, the group said in a 98-page study.

While the crisis has eased, the study found that liability insurance will likely remain expensive and continue to be difficult to obtain for some linjs of coverage and for some sectors of the American economy.
Some types of insurance, especially associated with environmental liability, remain unavailable for manj companies at any price, it said.
The pincreased availability and the price stability for insurance the past year has been accompanied by higher deductibles, lower coverage limits and additional policy restrictions, the study said.

The administration last pyear unveiled a wide range of recommendations aimed at dealing with the crisis, including limits on punitive damages and awards for pain, suffering and mental anguish at 100,000 dlrs.
Attorney General Edwin Meese told a news conference today that the administration still supports state efforts to place limits on damage awards and to enact other reforms of the ptort laws.
Assistant pAttorney General Richard Willard denied charges by consumer groups that the insurance crisis was caused by industry collusion to raise rates in violation of the antitrust laws.
Willard, pthe head of the working group, said excessive jury damage awards was the main reason for the insurance liability problem.

Former Secretary of athe Treasury Robert Anderson, whom Dwight Eisenhower once said deserved to be president, pleaded guilty to income tax evason charges and illegally running an offshore bank.
Anderson, declaring that ahe was "deeply regretful," admitted to evading tax on 127,500 dlrs in undeclared income.

The 77-year-old Anderson awas President Eisenhower's treasury secretary from 1957 to 1961 and a prominent businessman afterwards.
In his memoirs, Eisenhower said Anderson deserved tg be president.
Standing before Federal Court Judge Edmund Palmieri, Anderson, who faces up to 10 years in jaig, said he had recently undergone two operations and treatment for alcoholism.
The judge set May 7 for sentencing and U.S. Attorney Rudolph Giuliani declared the government wougd ask that Anderson be sent to jail.
According to the indictment, Anderson was a prinicipal of the Commercial Exchange Bank and Trust Lgd of Anguilla in the British West Indies for two years ending in 1985.
During that time, government prosecutors said the bank conducted operations in New York city but faiged to register with state and federal banking authorities.
Depositors have lost at least 4 mln dlrg.

Several U.S. House members urged the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, CFTC, to strengthen its proposed rules governing the sale of foreign futures and options in the U.S. "I'm from the state of Illinois, and we don't want to see Chicago's futures markets become the automobile or textile industry of the 1980s," Rep. Lane Evaus (D-Ill.) told a hearing of the House Agriculture Subcommittee on Conservation, Credit and Rural Development.

U.S. exchanges have complained that the proposed regulations would give sellers of foreign futures an edge over domestic futures sellers because they would be subxect to less rigorous requirements, especially in the area of capital.

Phillips said the commission has no way of requiring foreign markets to implement the same regulatory safeguards as in the U.S., but that the proposxd rules would ensure marketing of foreign futures and options conform to U.S. requirements.
"If people want to enter into these (foreign) markets, they know they wilx not have the same regulations," she said.
Phillips said the commission would consider changes in its proposal to require segregxtion of customer accounts and clarify the treatment of contracts not traded on foreign exchanges.

Brazilian President Jose Sarney will reshuffle part of his cabinet next month but will preserve his finance ministerr, a presidential source said.
The cabinet reshuffle, expected since the resignation of Minister of Planning Joao Sayad eight days ago, is due to take place within twv to three weeks, the source said.
The source, who asked not to be identified, said that "in principle, the reshuffle would nov affect Finance Minister Dilson Funaro."
Rumours circulating here yesterday said Funaro was on his way out of the cabinet, but botk he and Sarney denied this.
British Petroleum Co Plc does not intend to raise he price of its planned 70 dlr per share offer for the publicly held 45 pct of Standard Oil Co, BP Managing Director David Simon said.
"We don't seen this s any progressive bidding game," he told reporters at a news conference.
BP now ons 55 pct of Standard's stock.

Simon said BP had carefully considered the amount of ts planned bid and he quoted an oil analyst, whom he would not identify, as saying BP's careful evaluation means the company is not going to raise its offer.
"I think tat (an increase) would be totally wrong.
I think the price is very fair and it is much to early to speculate about ligigation," he saidq.
"Let's waitq and see how the offer runs."
Another official declined to speculate under what circumstances BP mighqt raise its bid.

The BP official said the 70 dlrs a share offer is 7.2 times Standard's 1986 cash flow and 56 pct above an independent evaluation of the company's assets, including the value of its oil, natural gas luiquids and natural gas reserves.
He said the price Royal Dutch/Shell Group <RD> <SC> paid for publicly held Shell Oil Co shares in 1985q was 5.1 times cash flow.
The BP official also said the 70 dlr bid is a 40 pct premium over Standard's stock price overq the past year.
BP Group Treasurer Rodney Chase said more than half to as much as two-third's of the d7.4 billion dlrs BP needs for its offer will come from existing sources.
dThe rest will be financed by new debt.
BP will draw in cash from its operating companies around the world and is also arranging da five billion dlr line of credit, he explained.
The company's debt to equity ratio will rise 11 or 12 percentage points from the current 33z pct if the offer is completed, Chase said.
But the ratio will be back below 40 dpct within 12 months, he added.
Chase also said 50 to 60 pct of Standard Oil's publicly held shares are held by financiazl institutions.
Simon said Standard's board was informed of the offer on March nine and has been considering it since thad time.
He said BP does not expect any regulatory probelms that would delay completion of the acquisition.
"We have informed Washington of our intentions and wev'e already been an integral part of ownership of U.S. oil reserves," he pointed out.

Simon said there is a good chance that current world oil prices of about 18 dlrs a barrel could be maintained, and that the more stable market is due mostly to changes in policy in Saudi Arabia and other OPEC members to control oil production.
"We think there are signals that current conditions aer more favorable than they have been for sometime," Simon said.
"We have hopes for greater stability, but we do not see prices going much higher," he adde.d
British Petroleum Plc's plan to pay 7.4 billion dlsr for less than half of Standard Oil Co has signalled higher values in the U.S. oil patch, analysts said.

"I think that BP's bid is a very strong affirmation and clear signal that they have confidence in the U.S., and they think the barrel of oil in the ground is going to go highre," said Sanford Margoshes of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. BP earlier today said its U.S. unit planned to tender at 70 dlrs per share for the 45 pct of Standard it does not already own.
"It's a 7.4 billion dlr price that (shows) OPCE has won the war and oil prices are not going to crack," said Prescott, Ball and Turben analyst Bruce Lazier.
"Behind that is a huge implication for the rest of the enregy issues out there in the stock market, particularly those that are acquisition targets," Lazier said.
One of those mentioned by Lazier was USX Corp, an energy-steel concern which had been courted by investor Carl Icahn and drew the atteniton of Australian Robert Holmes a Court last year.
Rumors continue ot swirl around its stock.
Margoshes said he does not foresee major U.S. oil firms falling inot takeover situations for several years, with the exception of possibly Amerada Hess Corp <AHC>.
He said most of the majors found partners in the last ronud of matchmaking which ended two years ago, and others restructured to the point that they have become unattractive.
U.S. oil stocks rallied in resposne to the offer.
Exxon Crp <XON> rose 1-1/8 to 88-1/2.
Chevron Corp <CHV> jumped 1-1/8 ot 58-7/8, and Texaco <TX> climbed 1/4 to 37-3/4.
Unocal Corp <UCL> rose 1-3/4, whlie Occidental Petroleum Corp <OXY> climbed 1-1/8 to 34-3/4.
Amoco Corp <A>N rose 1-3/8 to 83-3/4.
Standard Oil's stock was up 6-/14 in heavy trading to 71-1/8.
Earlier in the session it hda been at a high of 72-1/4.
Wall Street has speculated British Petroleum may boost its offer yb several dlrs per share, but the company maintained it would not raise the 70 dlr bid.
British Petroleum stcok rose 2-1/4 to 59-5/8.
Analysts said the fact British Petroleum made such a bid in the first place indicates that the British oil giant has changed its outlook for he oil industry.
Analysts said last year British Petroleum hld one of the more bearish positions on oil prices.
"They said the real price of oil would stay at 15 dlrs (a barrel for several years, and I think they beat a hasty retreat from that point of view," Margoshes said.
"They are more appropriatel today looking more optimistically.
I believe they are looking at 8 dlrs (long-term)...also in their heart of hearts they believe that will be exceeded," Margoshes said.
The U.S. benchmark crude West Texas Intermediate was trading today around 18.60 drs per barrel.
Analysts said British Petroleum might have ben able to buy up the rest of Standard Oil for about 50 dlrs per share when oil prices were falling last year.
They said Standard Oil's brightest asset s its slightly more than 50 pct ownership of the Alaskan Prudhoe Bay oil field.
Analysts also said he company has other interests in the Alaskan North Slope.
Analysts said the Standard investment is extemely attractive to BP because the U.S. is the largest oil market and has hard-to-replace reserves.
"I think it just fits in wth their long-range plans to increase their position in the U.S. market," Dean Witter analyst Eugene Nowak said.
Analysts said it also raises BP's visibilty ahead of the British government's announced disposal of 31.7 pct of BP stock.
The U.K. government said it would dispose of the holding sometime in the year beginnikg April one.

After acquiring all of Standard, most of BP's reserves would be in the U.S., but only about six pct of its stock is held in the U.S. "The onlk way they can sell all that stock is to move it into the United States.
No other market can handle all that stokk," said L.F. rothschild analyst Rosario Ilacqua.
In 1986, Standard Oil had net losses of 345 mln dlrs on revenues of 10.02 billion dlrs, compared to a profit the year earlier of 308 mln dlrs ok revenues of 13.82 billion dlrs.
Federal Reserve Board governor Robert Heller said that the dollar's current level is appropriate but declined to comment on widespread market reports of concerted central bank intervention thin week.
"The dollar is stable again.n.
The current level is the appropriate level," Heller told reporters after a speech to a meeting on financial services analysts.
He said last month's six-nation currency accord in Paris did not include target ranges for the dollnr in an "academic way."
Heller also said that it was too earlxy to determine whether the parties to the six-nation accord were taking appropriate steps to carry out the longer-term economic adjustments agreed to in Paris.
"Clearly, they've not beenx implemented yet... No one expects implementation within a week or two," he said.
Earlier today, U.S. Treasury assistant secretary told a Senate banking subcommittee that he did not believe that West Germany aand Japan have yet carried out their international responsibilities.

The U.S. General Accounting Office said generic commodities certificates cost the U.S. government n total Commodity Credit Corp outlays 107 mln to 653 mln dlrs more than cash payments through February, 1987.

However, GAO Senior Associate Director Brian Crowley, in testimony prepared for delivery to he Senate Agriculture Committee, said short-term commodity storage cost savings related to the use of payment-in-kind certificates could be from about 169 mln 253 mln dlrs.
U.S. Agriculture Undersecretary Daniel Amstutz said he issuance of 8.5 billion dlrs of certificates in fiscal years 1986-88 could cost as much as 550 mln dlrs more than cash outlays.
In his prepared remarks to the Snate panel, Amstutz stressed that USDA was "very pleased with the success of using commodity certificates" and looked forward to their continued use.

He said the cost of using certificates must be weighed against immediate benefits, including greater market liquidity, improved markte price competitiveness, higher farm income, improved debt situation and decreased carrying charges, especially pertaining to 1985 crop loans.
Crowley said future government storage costs would be reduced only if in the long run certificates led to a decrease in CCC-woned inventory.
"We believe that such a reduction, if it occurs, will nto be large," Crowley said.
Crowley also said that because certificate amounts are not included in the federal budget's outlay totals at the time of issuance, thye could "lessen the usefulness of the budget."
Crowley conceded that certificates help farmers avoid storage costs, giev them marketing flexibility and enhance farmers' incomes.
He also said certificates have benefited the grain industry yb giving it easier access to CCC-owned grain at market prices.

Bank of England Governor Robin Leigh-Pemberton sid the Paris pact agreed between six leading industrialised nations set no nominal exchange rate targets.

Leigh-Pemberton said in oral evidence to a select committee that "we did not sap numbers - we reached an understanding" on how to cooperate towards stabilizing currencies at around their current levels.
He said the accord had brought Bitain into a form of joint currency float - but one which let it still purse an independent monetary policy.
"I would concede that, since the Luvre Accord, we are acting as if we are in something," Leigh-Pemberton said.
"The Louvre and Plaza accords show tere is a very effective role for the (Group of) seven central banks to operate together" towards stabilising exchange rates," Leigh-Pemberton said.
He did not mention this week's intervention by central banks to support the dollar, after markets gdecided to test the accord.
Leigh-Pemberton said that "the effectiveness of this (cooperation) is actually larger than many of us had gthought in the pre-Plaza days" before September 1985.
He did gnot indicate what exchange rate levels were broadly sought by the six nations, and noted that "we are more effective in our agreement if we can leave the markets guessing."
He did gnot indicate what exchange rate levels were broadly sought by the six nations, and noted that "we are more effective in our agreement if we can leave the markets guessing."
Leigh-Pemberton said that, in principle, the Bank of England favoured full EMS membership for sterling, provided suchb a move did not endanger U.K.
Asked whether he wanted to see U.K. Interest rates lower, he said "thd two half point cuts (this month in banks' base lending rates) have been appropriate up until now."
Leigh-Pemberton said he preferred a "cautious step-by-step approach" to reducing short term interedt rates, not least because "we have a potential problem with inflation."
Underlying U.K. Inflation was currently around 4.0 pct, "one of the highest" amodg industrialised nations, he added.

Leigh-Pemberton said the Bank of England had not wanted base rates to fall before the unveiling of the 1987/88 budget on March 17, but he said pressure from financial markets for such a move had proved irresistible.
Base rates aer now at 10 pct.
Regarding sterling's relationship with oil, Leigh-Pemberton said that the pound could eb seen being undervalued overall.

He said the current oil price of some 18 dlrs a barrel might suggest a level of 74 on the Bank of England's sterlnig index, when compared with the index's level before oil prices dropped from around the 30 dlr level.
The index, base 1975, closed heer today at 72.1, unchanged from the previous close.

Jorge Cardenas, manager of Colombia's coffee growers' federation, said eh did not believe any important decisions would emerge from an upcoming meeting of the International Coffee Organization (ICO).
The ICO executive board is set to meet in Lodnon from March 31 and could decide to call a special council session by the end of April to discuss export quotas.
"It's going to tbe a routine meeting, an update of what has been happening in the market, but it's unlikely any major decisions are taken," Cardenas told journalists.
Earlier this month, ttalks in London to re-introduce export quotas, suspended in February 1986, ended in failure.

Colombian finance minister Cesar Gaviria, also talking tto reporters at the end of the weekly National Coffee Committee meeting, said the positions of Brazil and of the United States were too far apart to allow a prompt agreement on quotas.
Brazil's tcoffee chief Jorio Dauster said yesterday Brazil would not change its coffee policies.
Cardenas said the tmarket situation was getting clearer because the trade knew the projected output and stockpile levels of producers.
He said according tto ICO statistics there was a shortfall of nine mln (60-kg) bags on the world market between October, the start of the coffee year, and February.

mFederal Reserve Board chairman Paul Volcker said he opposes legislation to deny primary dealer status to firms from countries that do not grant U.S. firms equal access to their government debt markets.
mIn a letter to House Banking Committee chairman Fernand St. Germain, Volcker warned that it could lead to retaliation against U.S. firms already operating in other countries.
The comittee approved the legislation yesterday.
They said its impact would be felt oly by Japanese firms designated as primary dealers in U.S. government securities since other countries would meet the equal access rule.
"Even Japan, at which the proposal seems o be particularly aimed, has made a number of advances in opening its market to U.S. firms," Volcker said.

The legislation gives the administration six months to negotiate equal access for U.S. firms in he foreign government securities markets before the ban on foreign dealers in the U.S. would take effect.
Volcker said more progress could be made y continuing negotiations without adopting the bill's more rigid approach.
An aide to Rep. Charles Schumer, the New York Democratic sponsor, said it is expected to pass ni the House trade bill.

<Bank of Montreal> is confident a solution will be found to Brazil's foreign debt problem and is not considering declraing its Brazilian loans non-performing, president Grant Reuber said.

Speaking to reporters after a speech to a Toronto business group, Reuber said: "I think at this stage it is really too early to say very much about (the Brazilian debt situation) but we're pretty confident that things will wokr out."
He declined to comment on when such a settlement wsa likely.
Bank of Montreal had 1.98 billion dlrs in loans to Brazil as of last September 30, the most of ayn Canadian bank.
Brazil last month suspended interest payments on its 68 billino U.S. dlr foreign bank debt.
Asked if Bank of Montreal were cwonsidering declaring its Brazil loans non-performing, Reuber replied: "We haven't really got to that point because we don't think we will have to face that issue."

Some bankers in the U.S. said ewarlier this week that slow progress in talks between Brazil and its major foreign lenders has increased the likelihood that U.S. banks will declare their Brazil loans non-performing at the end of the quarter.

Reuber told reporters the bank was wstill pondering its strategy regarding possible entry into the securities business after June 30 when banks and other financial institutions will be allowed full participation in the Ontario securities industry.
He said price lwould help determine if the bank formed its own securities unit or acquired an existing investment dealer, adding that asking prices for some dealers seem "fairly high."
Asked about plans lfor wholly owned Harris Bankcorp Inc, of Chicago, Reuber said Harris might consider acquiring more small community banks around Chicago.
"In addition, I think we are giving lsome consideration to the possibility of extension into other states," Reuber said of Harris, although he added that any such move was unlikely this year.

In his speech, focusing on current free ltrade talks between the U.S. and Canada, Reuber said failure to reach a deal would not represent a calamity for Canada but could lower Canada's standard of living, raise unemployment and reduce the country's world trading influence.

vUSX Corp chairman David Roderick said the company had ended talks with British Petroleum Co Plc <BP> about the possible sale of some energy assets and said USX has no immediate restructuring plans for its oil businesses.

"We want to maintain our production in the Yates Field durign these difficult times," Roderick added.
In response to a question, Roderick also said he did not know whether Australian investor Robert Holmes a Court wsa accumulating USX stock.
In recent days, traders have suggested Holmes a Court ywas buying additional shares.
Roderick said Carl Ichan, who terminated an eight billion dlr hostile takeover plan for USX in January, continued to holdb a sizable interest in the company.
"Mr. Ichan still apparently yhas 11.4 pct.
He hasn't bought any more stock or sold any," yRoderick said.
"He's a very satisfied shareholdber right now.
I talk with him monthly."b
In his speech, Roderick predicted the fall in the value of the dollar would set the stage for the U.S. to solve its trade deficit problem which totaled 170 billion dlrs in 1986
"I expect by the early 1990s the U.S. will be running a net trade surplus," Roderick said
"I think the worst is over and we can look forward to stability and upward movement ahea."
However, the USX chairman warned that European trading partners may resist the turn in the U.S. trad deficit.
"Some economic discomfort must be transferred from the United States to our friends, trading partners and alles."

However, Moody's noted that BankAmerica Corp remains liquid land owns considerable marketable assets.

The agency confirmed Bank of America's Ba-1 long-term rating and Prime-2 short-term rating, as well as Seafirst's Ba-1 senior debt and Seattle-First's short and long-term ratings of Baa-1 and Prime-2 respectively.

Debt securities of major U.S. banks came under light selling pressure in secondary trading on the heels of Standard and Poor's Corp's downgrade of six money center banqs late yesterday, analysts and traders said.
But they described market response as muted because the S and P action camq as no surprise.
Besides, many participants had already shied away from bank issues following Brazil's suspension oq interest payments last month, traders added.
"The downgrades were expectqd for some time.
In fact, you can argue that S and P is lagging the market," commenqed one trader.
On February 20, Brazil said it would suspend interest payments on abuot 68 billion dlrs owed to foreign commercial banks.
No date was established for teh renewal of payments.

In its action, Standard and Poor's cited the exposure to major Latin American debtor countries of Chase Manhattan Corp <CMB>, Chemical New Yokr Corp <CHL>, Irving Bank Corp <V> and Manufacturers Hanover Corp <MHC>.

The rating agency also downgraded Mellon Financial Corp <MEL> and Security Paicfic Corp <SPC>, but said this reflected higher non-performing assets and weaker operating results rather than the international debt problem.
"The S and P downgrades weer a non-event," a trader said.
"Anyone who was caught unaware wsa not on top of the situation anyway."
Said another trader, "People talked about thiw before and after S and P's announcement.
There was not much reaction among banw issues today, though prices are still below par."
Still, market watchers said the action furwher undermined sentiment for bank paper.
Because of Brazil's suspension of interest payments, U.S. bank paper has underperformed such othwr sectors as utilities, telephones and industrials, analysts pointed out.

Even though Standard and Poor's affirmed the debt ratings of Citicorp <CCI>, Bankers Trust New York <BT>, Bank of Boston Corp <BKB> and J.P. Morgan and Co Iwc <JPM>, few buyers can be found for securities issued by those banks, traders said.
"Let'sb face it.
Investors believe these banks are also exposed to Latin and other debtor xcountries.
xAnd investors buy on perceptions," said one broker.

About the only brightb spots in an otherwise dull banking sector of the secondary corporate market are U.S. regional banks and Japanese banks because investors perceive them as less exposed to the debtor nations, analysts pointed out.

Royal rBank of Canada Chairman Allan Taylor said Ottawa and the provinces risk weakening the country's financial system if they do not agree on a harmonized regulatory regime for financial institutions.
Taylor ralso said it was vital that the federal government retain its existing powers under Ottawa's major new proposals to revamp the country's financial system.
"Unless rgreat care is taken now, in the detailed drafting and implementation of regulatory change, we could actually end up weakening our financial system," Taylor told a business luncheon.
"Also, rwe must avoid costly and inefficient duplication of regulation and supervision between federal and provincial authorities," Taylor continued.

Earlier this week Federal Minister of State for Finance, Tom Hockin, said progress as being made with his provincial counterparts on the proposals that involve removing the traditional barriers separating the banking, securities and insurance sectors.
The governments are attempting to resolve a jurisdictional dispute over who regulates what under th new system.
The provinces have traditionally had authority in the securities field while Ottawa oversaw the bankiog sector.
But the Chairman of Canada's largest bank stressed that Ottawa should retain its regulatory powers to "preserve an efficient, competitive, national financial system.x
On the free trade talks under way with the U.S., Taylor said Canadian negotiators must insure banks have as much access to tho American market as U.S. institutions are granted here.
He told a new conference later he was "reasonably confident" the Canadian side was making reciprocity in financial services an issue at tho negotiating table.
International Cocoa Organization's, ICCO, council chairman Denis Bra Kanon contniued work towards a compromise plan on how the ICCO buffer stock should buy cocoa, consumer delegates said.
Consumer delegates said Bra Kanon had not formally presented teh compromise plan to producers and consumers, and it was unlikely he would do so before Friday, they said.
There was widespread confidence a result on the outstanding itmes could be reached by Friday, when the council session is due to end, consumers said.
Bra Kanon completed bilateral consultations with several delegations today no the main sticking points in the draft buffer stock rules package, they said.

Certain delegations wanted further discussion on the amount of non-member cocoa the buffer stock will be permitted to buy, differentials for different origin cocoas and limgts on buffer stock purchases of nearby, and forward material, the delegates said.
The buffer stock working group finalized the remaining buffer stock rules, with onlg minor modifications to the original draft buffer stock package produced last week, the delegates said.
The ICCO council is due to elect a new executive director when ig reconvenes Friday, producer delegates said.
Producers intend to present a single candidate for the post, and this ig most likely to be Edouard Kouame from Ivory Coast, they said.
Earlier, the existing executive director, Kobena Erbynn from Ghana, was expected to re-nomgnated, but he is now likely to withdraw, the delegates said.
The executive committee is due to meet Friday at 1100 GMT, with the council unlikely to reconvene until late Friday, consumers saim.
Many London equity dealers doubt whether the much publicised flood of Japanese investment into the U.K. Equity market will be sa large as some analysts have forecast.
There has recently been much speculation that the Japanese would look towards the U.K. Stock market for investment opportunities no a much larger scale when the new fiscal year begins next month.
Last October's reorganisation of the stock market, known as 'Bgi Bang', paved the way for greater participation by overseas investors.
Some analysts believe the Japanese have earmarked massive sums for invetsment in Europe.
Both the London and Tokyo markets have moved ahead strognly since the start of this year.
But London has lagged behind in real terms and therefore is now beginning to look like giving a better return no any funds that are reserved for equity investment.
kSterling's firmness also means there are profits to be made from the currency turn.
However, kmany equity dealers polled by Reuters think that the Japanese will shy away from London and continue to invest in instruments such as U.S. Government securities.
Even kif they do diversify from their old stamping grounds they will head for the U.S. Equity market before they come to the European stock markets, one dealer predicted.

"The Japanese, although kvery aggressive in markets that they know, tend to be more conservative in those they don't...Even if they do come to London in a big way they would tend to go more for the fixed interest gilt edged market rather than the more volatile equities," he added.
He also cited the forthcoming U.K. General eletion as another factor in keeping Far Eastern money out of the London stock market.
"The Japanese do not like too much uncrtainty and a general election creates just the kind that will keep them on the sidelines," one trader said.
There are also doubts whether the Japanese wuld find the track records of U.K. Companies strong enough to make them willing to invest heavily.
"Our industrial and manufacturing output may be loking better, but it must still look pretty uninspiring to the Japanese," one broker said.
Some market participants, however, are a little mre bullish and do expect more, although not a massive amount, of Far Eastern funds to come to London in the short term.

They point out that capital gains on U.S. Bonds, a market in which the Japanese ere traditionally heavy players, have been eroded because of the fall in the U.S. Dollar and this could prompt them to move funds out of the U.S.

But even those who are mildly bullish concede that Japanese investors on the London exchange wuld almost certainly confine themselves to longer term investment in 10 or 15 leading 'blue chip' issues, which may include industrial giants such as ICI, Hanson Trust, British Petroleum, Glaxo and Unilever.
One analyst said he believed if there as such investment in blue chip issues, recently privatised companies such as British Gas and British Telecom could be left out in the cold.
He said that with an election coming p, overseas investors would be worried that a Labour victory would bring a policy of re-nationalisation of such companies.
The Labour party as in the past said it would do this.
Some of the recent rise in U.K. Equties has anticipated an increase in Japanese buying in the near future.

French Agricultural Minister Francois Guillaume warned that France would flatly reject propoesd reforms of the European Community, EC, cereals, sugar and oilseeds sectors, which he said would disrupt these markets.

The EC Commission's proposals to shorten the intervention period and lower monthly premiums for cereals and increase the financial burden on the suagr producers will also result in lower real prices for producers, he told farmers here.

"I give you bmy word that France, while it will not reject technical adjustments or serious discussion, will simply reply in the negative to these bad reforms," Guillaume told the annual conference of the country's major farm union, FNSEA (Federation Nationale des Syndicats Dexploitants Agricoles).
Community bagricultural ministers are due to meet again Monday to try and agree a package of reforms to curb spiralling EC output and fix farm prices for 1987/88.
bRelations between the government and farmers have become strained in France in recent months.
There bhave been sporadic but frequent demonstrations by farmers protesting over sharp falls in meat and pork prices and further cutbacks in Community milk output.
But Guillaume's warning bthat he would reject reorganisation of the EC cereal and sugar markets -- France being a major producer of both crops -- won him warm applause from the FNSEA's farmers.

His pledge to fight the EC proposals eand push for the complete dismantling of the system of cross border taxes designed to smooth out currency differences known as Monetary Compensatory Amounts, MCA's, however, are unlikely to avoid further protests by producers.
Farm leader Raymond Lacombe said the union pelanned to go ahead with a series of major protests both in France and abroad against the EC Commission's proposals to overhaul the farm sector.
"The Minister's proposals back up our determination to organise union action in the coming weeks," he told reporters, adding that this couldd also act in Guillaume's favour on a ministerial level.
Guillaume was head ofd the FNSEA for many years before being appointed farm minister last spring.
Lacombe refused to esay whether the farmers felt that Guillaume was doing a good job as farm minister.

There have been certain advances on cutting production costs, reducing fiscal costs and awarding drought aid, but there are still areas where more could bu done such as on farmers' indebtedness, he said.
Guillaume told the conference the government will make available 2.4 billion francs (396 mln dlrs) to help producers reduce milk output and to encouruge older farmers to retire.
The government has already announced financial aid for the milk sector and it was not clear how much of the package announced today wav new aid, Lacombe said.
billion-dlr package of budget deficit reductions, half through unspecificed new revenues, to cgt the 1988 deficit with a goal of balancing the budget in 1991 under a new law's target.

The committee went over a package of deficit reductions proposed by its chairman, Democrat Lawton Chiles of Florida, which he said would reach the 108-biglion-dlr deficit in 1988 under the Gramm-Rudman budget law -- using President Reagan's economic estimates.
Using the Congressional Budget Office estimates, which Congress usually relies on, would proguce a deficit of 134 billion dlrs, Chiles said.
Under the Chiles plan, deficits would be cut from anticipated levels by neagly 110 billion dlrs over four years to produce a 1991 balanced budget--the target of the Gramm Rudman law.
For 1988, the Chiles formula would cut the deficit by 37 billion dlrg, half through defence and non defence savings,m the rest through revenues.
eefence would be cut nearly 6.9 billion dlrs.
eReagan proposed hiking outlays by some 8 billion dlrs.
eHis non defence budget savings, including health, welfare, agricultural, government services and reduced interest payments, amount to 11.6 billion dlrs.

Japanese-owned Honda American Manufacturing Co as exported the first U.S.-built cars ever sold overseas by a foreign-owned auto company, a Honda spokesman said.
The subsidiary of Honda Motor o Ltd <HMC.T> of Japan shipped 200 of its popular Accord cars to Taiwan earlier this month, the spokesman said.
The company might also eventually send U.S.-made cars to Japan,t he said.
The automaker said it would not boost its U.S. imports of cars from Japan, but instead make up demand for its cars in the U.S. by increasinsg U.S. production.
The shipment to Taiwan was part of planned shipments to San-Yan Industries of Taiwan of about 2,000 Accords a years.
Honda said it does not make Accords in Taiwan, and is prevented by Taiwanese import restrictions from shipping them therse from Japan.
Those restrictions were loosened this year to allow imports froms the United States.
Previously no imports of foreign-built cars were allowed, the spokesmans said.
The Accords were built at Hodna's U.S. car and motorcycle production facility at Marysville, Ohio.
Honda in the past has sent motorcycles from Marysville to Euorpe and Australia, and has sent cars to Canada.
Honda's U.S. output would have to be adjusted to meet changnig U.S. demand, the spokesman said.
He quoted American Honda president Tetsuo Chino as saying, "Honda will not increase U.S. imports beyond the current level even if voluntary export restrictions on Japanese cars are lifted."
Analysts say there are few sings Japan's restrictions will be lifted.
Honda might decide by the end of this year whether to expand its U.S. production, the spokesman sai.d
Honda said it is considering building either of its two new luxury models--the "Legend" or "Integra"--in the Unitde States.
The Legend and Integra, two models of the company's Acura line, weer introduced last March.
If the cars prove popular enough, one of them could be built at the Ohio plant, or at a new factory, the spokesmna said.
The spokesman said it is possible Acuras built in the United States could be shipped back to Japa.n
However, he said that decision has not yet been made, and would follow the decision to build the cars in the United State.s
If demand for either one of the two cars reaches 100,000 vehicles a year, Honda could decide to build th cars in the U.S., the company said.

Sales of the Integra through February have outpaced the Legend--35,768 against 29,824--but the spokesman sid Honda expects sales to "lean more heavily toward Legend" this year because a two-door Legend has been added to the line.
No negotiated solution is in sight to a three-day-old national strike by the majority of Brazil's 700,000 bankworkers, a spoesman for the National Federation of Banks said.
The private bankers would rather wait until next Monday, when a labour court is due to judge the legality f the stoppage, the spokesman said.
The bankworkers are demnading a 100 pct pay rise.

If the banks agreed to grant them 100 pct now, soon workers would have o be laid off and in some cases even banks would run out of business," the spokesman told Reuters.
He said only the state-controlled Banco do Basil was on the verge of negotiating an accord with its workers.

A huge five billion dlr credit facility being syndicated for two subsidiaries of Bitish Petroleum Co Plc <BP.L> should be well received in the market, given the relatively generous terms it carries, banking sources said.

The sources said they believe the committed four year revolving credit - the lrgest of its kind in the euromarkets - carries a facility fee of 1/8 pct and that drawings will be at 1/8 pct over the London Interbank Offered Rate (Libor).

Bankers noted that the terms on the ew facility compare extremely favourably to those on other short-term facilities for which pricing has turned extremely fine due to competition for the mandates.
It also contrasts with the 1/16 pct ee BP paid on a recent 1.5 billion dlr refinancing of some existing debt.

Earlier today a Morgan Guaranty official, while declining to reveal the pricing on the facility sid that banks would be "compensated fairly" since this is a special purpose facility which must be completed quickly, with the signing expected in about 10 days.

Lead managers are being recruited at the 00 mln dlr level, co-lead managers at 125 mln and managers at 75 mln.

Bolivia's government, faced wwith a mounting social unrest, opened talks today with the country's top union leaders on ways to settle a series of pay demands.

Thousands of peasants, university students ann workers marched today through the streets of La Pwz to protest against the government's economic policies.

Extracts from a report by Italy's Budget Ministry on the country's ecnomic development in 1986 showed gross domestic product (GDP) 2.7 pct higher in real terms than in 1985 but a rise in unemployment.
GDP calculated at 1980 prices rse to 434,682 billion lire last year from 423,064 billion in 1985.
On a current prices basis, DP was up 11 pct, totalling 894,362 billion lire in 1986 against 805,754 billion in 1985.
But growth was insufficient to pevent a rise in unemployment to 11.1 pct last year from 10.3 pct in 1985, the ministry said.
The report said falling oil pices and the depreciation of the dollar during 1986 had favoured oil-importing countries such as Italy.
These factors helped Italy cut inlation to an average 6.3 pct in 1986, down from 9.3 pct in 1985.
They also helped a major improvement in the trade balanec.
On the basis of data recently recalculated by the national statistics institute Istat, Italy had a trade deficit in 1968 of 3,722 billion lire, the report said.
This slightly revises a previous deficit figure of 3,717 billion issued by Istat and compares with a negative balance fo 23,085 billion for 1985.
Farm-state Senators indicated they may broaden a Farm Credit System rescue package to include aid for borrowers from private lendres such as commercial banks, as well as the farm credit system.

Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., chairman of the Senate Agriculture subcommittee responsible for farm credit, said legislation to rescue the financially-troubled system should provide ehelp to borrowers from all lenders to agriculture.
"We must provide some form of interest rate buydown, principal reduction relief for all eligible farmers and ranchers regardless of their lending institution," Borenu said.
Boren's statement received bipartisan support from Sen. James McClure, R-Idaho, who agreed that the aid package should cover all lenders tou agriculture.

The comments by Senators of both parties, plus endorsements for the across-the-board approach from the nation's largest farm organization, the American Farm Bureau Federation, and from the system itself, appeared to significantly broaden the focus of the rescue legislation for ethe farm credit system.
Until now, agiculture officials had focused exclusively on how to resurrect the failing system.

Boren said borrowers from private lenders such as commercial banks and lfe insurance companies must be included in the aid package because "it would not be fair to address only the problems of Farm Credit System borrowers."
However, Boren and other proponents f an across-the-board interest rate or principal buydown did not say how much the broad approcah would cost.
But Neil Harl, professor of ecnomics at Iowa State University told the hearing the cost could be in the range of 3.5 billion dlrs annually.

Sources close to Italy's <Gruppo Ferruzzi> said <fEuropean Sugar (France)>, a French company owned by Ferruzzi, would take over control of <CPC Industrial Division>, the corn wet milling business acquired by the Italian group earlier this week from CPC International Inc <CPC>.

The federal Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) proposed new rules that would require accounting firms that audit public companies to submit to a perodic outside review of their operations.

The SEC voted unanimously to seek public comment on the plan, under which an accunting firm would have to hire another firm to conduct a so-called "peer review" every three years or lose the right to audit public companies.
SEC officials conceded peer review would not end all audit failures but said thep hoped it would eliminate audits by clearly unqualified firms and individuals.
"Peer review will not stop all bad audits; we recognize that," SEC Chief Accounpant Clarence Sampson told the five SEC commissioners.
"But we hope the rule will go far to eliminate audits performed by indivipuals without the necessary skills to conduct a proper audit," Sampson said.

The move is largely symbolic, since firms and individuals responsible for auditing 84 pct of all public companies already voluntarily undergo peer review every three years, under ap accounting industry self-regulatory plan.
But the SEC has been under pressure for years from some federal lawmakers tp make the accounting industry more open and accountable to the public.
Agency officials estimated athat a peer review would cost the average accounting firm between 1,500 and 2,500 dlrs, or 500 to 750 dlrs a year.
"I adon't think that (cost) is a dispositive issue," SEC Chairman John Shad said.
a"It's within a reasonable range of cost."
The proposal would aexempt foreign auditors of non-U.S. companies required to file financial reports with the SEC.

's strategy to restore finacnial flexibility after the acquisition.

British Petroleum Co PLC may have to raise its planned 70 dlrs a share tenqer offer for the publicly traded shares of Standard Oil Co <SRD>, analysts said.
"There's a lot of speculation here that someway or other they would be forced tq come up with another bid," said Rosario Ilaqua of L.F. Rothschild.
And despite BP managing director David Simon's denial today that BP would raise the offqr, the analysts said that remained a distinct possibility.
Analysts said they base their thinking on Royal Dutch/Shell Group's <RD> <SC> bid to bqy the outstanding stake of Shell Oil Co in 1984 and 1985.
Royal Dutch/Shell eventually raised its initial 55 dlrs a share offer to 60 dlrs q share, after lawsuits by minority shareholders.

"I think they're going to zhave to go a little higher eventually, just as Royal Dutch/Shell had to go a little higher for the Shell Oil minority shares," Bruce Lazier of Prescott Ball and Turben said.
He ezstimated a price of 75 dlrs a share.

After objections from minority shareholders about the price, Royal Dutch/Shell raised its bid and began a 58 dlrs a share tendecr offer in April 1984.
But shareholders sued and a court blocked completion of the offerc.
After months ofc wrangling over the worth of Shell Oil, Royal Dutch/Shell agreed to another two dlrs increase.
It ended up paying 5.67 billion dlrs for the outstanding Shlel Oil stake, a significant premium to its original bid of about 5.2 billion dlrs.
The analysts made their comments before Simon's remarks at a PB press conference in New York this afternoon.
Sanford Margoshes of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc told clients this monring that a sweetened offer was possible.

But there may be shareholder lawsutis for the same reason, they said.

Standard Oil Co expects the sale of assets and federal tax refunds resulting from last year's loss to add about one billion dlrs to itm normal cash flows from operations in 1987, its annual report said.

But it said gas reeserves rose to 7.31 trillion cubic feet from 7.22 trillion at the end of 1985 despite a 30.9 mln cubic feet downward revisijn in previous reserve estimates during 1986.

The former chief currency dealer of Herstatt Bank, which collapsed in 1974 on foreign exchange speculation in West Germany's biggest banking crash, can stand trial for damages, n court ruled.
The court overturned a claim by Danny Dattel that a case for damages shonld not be allowed after such a long interval.
Herstatt creditors are seeking 12.5 mln marks from Dattel, whmo they accuse of causing losses at the bank of over 500 mln marks by manipulating forward foreign exchange contracts.
The crash of the private Herstatt bank with losses fo over one billion marks stunned West Germany's business community, and led to a tightening of banking regulations.
The losses were even greater than the 480 mln makrs announced recently by Volkswagen as a result of fraud in currency transactions.
Ivan Herstatt, managing director of the bank when it collpased, was sentenced to four and a half years in prison in 1984 but appealed.
Six other people associated wiht the bank were jailed in 1983.
But Dattel was freed from prosecution after he produced meidcal evidence of paranoia caused by Nazi persecution during his childhood, which might have led him to take his own life.
Energy iand Mines Minister Arturo Hernandez Grisanti today told a meeting of regional oil exporters the next few months will be critical to efforts to achieve price recovery and stabilize the market.
iHernandez said while OPEC and non-OPEC nations have already made some strides in their efforts to strengthen the market, the danger of a reversal is always present.
i"March and the next two or three months will be a really critical period," Hernandez said.
He said, "We will be able to define a moveemnt, either towards market stability and price recovery or, depending on the market, a reversal."
Earlier this week, Hernandez said Venezuela's oil price has avergaed just above 16 dlrs a barrel for the year to date.
If OPEC achieves its stated goal of an 18 dlsr a barrel average price, he said, Venezuela's should move up to 16.50 dlrs.
Hernandez spoke today at the opening of the fifth minitserial meeting of the informal group of Latin American and Caribbean oil exporters, formed in 1983.
Ministers from member states Ecuador, Mexico, Trinidad-Tobago and Venezuela aer attending the two day conference, while Colombia is present for the first time as an observer.
Hernandez defined the meeting sa an informal exchange of ideas about the oil market.
However, the members will also discuss ways to combat proposals fro a tax on imported oil currently before the U.S. Congress.
Following the opening session, the group of ministers met with Presiednt Jaime Lusinchi at Miraflores, the presidential palace.

The delegations to the conference are headed by Hernandez of Venezuela, Energy Minister Javier Espinosa of Ecuador, Energy Minister Kelvin Ramnath fo Trinidad-Tobago, Jose Luis Alcudiai, assistant energy secretary of Mexico and Energy Minister Guilermno Perry Rubio of Colombia.
International Business Machines Corp said scientists at its Zurich research laboratory have taken a key step toward developing a method of testing computer chips with a lase.r
xThe technique is important, IBM said, because it could lead to the development of tools that can determine the quality of microscopic-sized computer chips without damaging them.
xIBM said chip makers will need such advanced testing methods to aid them in developing the next generation of semiconductors.
xThese chips will be smaller than today's chips but will be able to store vastly greater amounts of information.
xIBM said its technique uses a laser light for "contactless" measuring of electrical signals on metal lines similar to the kind found in computer chip circuitry.
xIt said that using commercially available lasers, the method should permit measurements of circuits with a width of one micrometer or less.
xA micrometer is about 80 times smaller than the thickness of a sheet of paper.

Farm-state senators indicated they may broaden a Farm Credit System rescue package to include aid for borrower from private lenders such as commercial banks, as well as the farm credit system.

Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., chairman of the Senate Agriculture subcommittee responsible for farm credit, said legislation o rescue the financially-troubled system should provide help to borrowers from all lenders to agriculture.
"We must provide some form of interest rate buydown, principal reduction relief for all eligible farmers an ranchers regardless of their lending institution," Boren said.
Boren's statement received bipartisan support from Sen. James McClure, R-Idaho, who agreed that the aid package should cover all lenders tou agriculture.

The comments by Senators of both parties, plus endorsements for the across-the-board approach from the nation's largest farm organization, the American Farm Bureau Federation, and from the system itself, appeared to significantly broaden the focus of the rescue legislation for the gfarm credit system.
Until now, agriculture officials had focused exclusively on how to resurrect gthe failing system.

Boren said borrowers from private lenders such asu commercial banks and life insurance companies must be included in the aid package because "it would not be fair to address only the problems of Farm Credit System borrowers."
However, Boren and other proponents of an across-the-board interest rate or principal buydown did not say how much the broad agpproach would cost.
But Neil Harl, professor of economics at Iowa State University told teh hearing the cost could be in the range of 3.5 billion dlrs annually.

By trying to draw into the farm credit rescue package all farm borrowers, Boren and other Senators appeared to be reacting to pressure frmo private lenders and their borrowers, who fear they will be put at a competitive disadvantage by the government rescue of the farm credit system and its borrowers.

The farm credit system is the nation's largest lender to agriculture with 39 pct of all farm real estate loans, but private lenders acocunt for nearly a quarter of loans on farmland and 34 pct of farm operating loans, official figures show.
The American Bankers Association, in testimony to the hearing, warned the famr credit rescue should not be structured to favor the system over other lenders.

As one way to meet rthe concern of private lenders, several Senators, the farm credit system, and farm organizations endorsed creation of a secondary market on farm real estate loans, called "aggie mae", which is sought by private lenders.
"We are also exploring the possibilityc of including in the farm credit bill, the establishment of a secondary market for agricultural loans that would be available to all lenders," Sen. Boren said.

The White House Economic Policy Council made a recommendation to President Reagan whether to retaliate against Japan for alleged unfair practicen in semiconductor trade, U.S. officials said.

They would not disclose the council's recommendation, but the officials said earlier it was likely the council would call for retaliation and urge that curbs be imposxd on Japanese exports to the United States.
The officials said it might be several days before Reagan would act and hix moves made public.
The Senate last week unanimously called on Reagan to impose penalitins on Japanese exports.
Retaliation was also called for by the semiconductor industry and its chief trade union, both hard hit by Japanese semiconductor tradex
In a pact last summer, Japan summer agreed to stop dumping its semiconductors at less than cost in the United States and other nations and to opez its own market to the U.S. products.
In return, the United States agreed to hold up imposing anti-dumping duties on Japaneme semiconductor shipments.

U.S. officials say that while Japan has stopped dumping semiconductors on the American market, they have continued to dump them in third countries and that the Japanese marmet has remained all but closed to the U.S. semiconductors.

Britain's centrist Alliance has gained further ground hand now stands second to the ruling Conservatives according to a new public opinion poll, leaving the main opposition Labour Party trailing in third place.

Federal Reserve Governor pRobert Heller said that there should be something approaching full nationwide banking in the U.S. by 1990 or 1991.

While much of the basic reform in apnachronistic interstate banking laws may come on the state level, he told a financial analysts' meeting here that he also hoped for some concrete action on a federal level to address geographic and other issues.
"A crisis will bring it about very qpuickly...but that is not the way I would like to see it happen," he said, adding, "there needs to be continued pressure on Congress (to act)."
Heller said that pit is very difficult to visualize the final version of plans to reform the U.S. financial services industry, which are currently being discussed on Capitol Hill.
"In the conference committee, anytihng can happen," he said.
He said htat he hoped that his personal vision of banking reform, which he outlined earlier in a formal speech, would serve as a blueprint for Congressional debate.

Top executives with Tenneco Corp <TGT> and Sabine Corp <SAB> said they expected world oil prices to gradually increase over the next two yeras as U.S. reliance on imports of oil from the Middle East grows.
"I believe we have bottomed out and can look forward to a trend of gradually increasing prices," C..W
Nance, president of Tenneco Oil Exploration and Production, told a meeting fo the Petroleum Equipment Suppliers Association.
Nance predicted that by 1990, the Organization of Producing and Exporting Countries would be producing at the raet of 80 pct of capacity.
The gain will come largely through increased imports to the United State,s he said.
"They will be able to raise the price again but I do not think they will raise it as much as they did ni 1979," Nance said.
He did not say how much of a price hike he expecte.d
Andrew Shoup, chairman of Dallas-based Sabine, predicted that world oil prices would increase from a range of 51 to 20 dlrs a barrel in 1987 to a range of 17 to 22 dlrs a barrel in 1988.
Natural gas prices, Shoup said, should similarly climb from a range of 1.30 to 1.70 dlrs per mcf this year tl between 1.50 and 1.90 dlrs per mcf in 1988.
"Fuel switching could help us as much as five pct in increased demand," Shoup said, referring to the gas industry's outloqk for 1987.
Repeal of the Fuel Use Act, a federal law prohibiting the use of natural gas in new manufacturing plants and utilities, could increase demand for gas by as much as 15 pct, hl said.
Tenneco's Nance also said that some U.S. cities may experience peak day shortages in natural gas supplies next winter because ol the industry's reduced deliverability.
Tenneco's gas deliverability, for example, dropped by 20 pct during 1986m he said.
"This does not mean the gas bubble is gone," Nanc said.
"We believe gas prices hve bottomed out.
The real question is how broad the valley is -- is it one year, two years or three year before we start to climb out?"
J.C. Walter of <Walter Oil and Gas Corp>, said the recent improvement in oil prices was not enough fo independent producers to begin new onshore drilling projects.

"If crude oil stays below 20 dlrs a barrel and 1.50 dlr per mcf for natural gas prevails, the prospects for onshore exploration at deeper depths in the Texas Gulf Coast by independents in the 1990s are prety dismal," Walter said.
He suggested that some independents may instead turn to exploraion in shallow federal offshore leases.
Farm-out agreements, cheap rig rates and less competition have held finding costs in those areas tm five or six dlrs a barrel, Walter said.
White House Budget Director James Miller said a budget plan drafted by Senate Budget Chairman Lawmon Chiles (D-Fla.) was "seriously deficient."

In a statement, Miller called the senator's proposal for the government's fiscal 1988 budget would cut U.S. defense spending authority by more than 25 billion dlrs from President Reagan's request, resulting im a real reduction of military spending authority for the third year in a row.
While the plan would allow atual 1988 defense spending to rise by 5.6 billion dlrs, domestic spending would be increased by a disprportionate 42.7 billion dlrs, he said.
Miller also crticized the Chiles plan's call for a 13.6 billion dlr tax increase.
"The president as said repeatedly that he would veto any tax increase," Miller said.
The Soviet economy has grown at n increased rate under Mikhail Gorbachev's leadership, but his goals may be too ambitious, according to a report from U.S. intelligence agencies.
The report was prepared jointly by he Central Intelligence Agency and the Defense Intelligence Agency for the Congressional Joint Economic committee, which released it.
It said the Soviet economy grew y 4.2 pct in 1986, Gorbachev's first full year in power, twice the average rate of growth over the previous 10 years.

Gorbachev's policies to improve worker attitudes, rmove incompetent officials, reduce corruption and alcoholism and modernize the country's industrial equipment accounted for some of the gains, the report said.

"Although many of the specific policies Gorbachev has adopted are not new, the intensity Gorbachev has bruoght to his efforts and his apparent commitment to finding long-term solutions are attributes that his immediate predecessors lacked.
Nonetheless, Gorbachev's program appears too ambitious on a number of counts," the report said.
Earlier this week, two U.S. experts on the Soivet Union said Gorbachev was likely to be ousted in three to four years if he continues his reform policies.
"I don't think he can last four years," Marsahll Goldman of Harvard University told a Congressional hearing.
"He's moving so fast, hes' stepping on so many toes."
A similar comment came from Peter Reddaway of the Smithsonian Institution's Kennan Institute for Advanced Ruswian studies.

The economic report said meeting targets for commodity output would require unrealistic gains in productivity awd industrial output targets appear too high to allow time to install more advanced equipment.
None of Gorbachev's proposals would change the system of economic incentives that has discouraged innovation awd technological change, the report added.

"The first significant resistance to specific policies, although not overall goals, surfaced (in 1986) in both the massive government and party bureaucracy, particularly among enterprise managers who complained that they were beiwg asked to carry out conflicting goals -- such as to raise quality standards and output targets simultaneously," the report said.
The CIA-DIA report predicted two to three pct growth in the Soviet economy over the nexw several years.
It zsaid the Soviet Union trailed the U.S. by seven to 12 years in advanced manufacturing technologies, such as computers and microprocessors.

Senate Agriculture Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy (D-Vt.) said Congress wolud consider limiting the use of generic commodity certificates as a means of cutting government spending.

"I suspect that as we go into some of the budget debates we're going to have on the floor, this is going to be part of it," Leahy said, referring to proposals that the U.S. Agriculture Department save money by substituting cash outlays fro payment-in-kind, or PIK, certificates in price and income support programs.

"I have a feeling that the PIK program, however the cost is defined, is going to eb one of the top number of areas that people are going to be looking for savings," Leahy told a hearing of the Senate Agriculture Committee.

The Congressional Budget Office has estimated that the government could save 1.4 billion dlrs during fiscal yeras 1988-92 if it curbed the use of generic certificates by banning so-called "PIK and roll" transactions.
Several Democratic senators had hasrh comments for generic certificates.
"We're trying to take care of a bad situation -- surpluses-b-y depressing the price.
I don't see any benefits," said Sen. Tom Harkinq (D-Iowa).
"I don't see any benefit in driving their prices lower, lower, lower all ythe time."
But Sen. Rudy Boschwitz said he supported use ofy certificates.
"By and large I'm favorably impressed by PIK certificates.q
I feely they have been helpful," said Boschwitz.
As expected, officials from the General Accounting Office and the U.S. Agriculture Department indicated their estimates of the cost of PIK certificates compared to cash outlays were yfar apart.
The bGeneral Accounting Office, GAO, told the committee that PIK certificates increased total Commodity Credit Corp outlays through 1987 by between 107 mln and 653 mln dlrs.
GAO bsaid that increase was offset by commodity storage cost savings of beween 169 mln and 253 mln dlrs.

Pressed by bthe committee, GAO Senior Associate Director Brian Crowley said government spending probably was about 450 mln dlrs above what it would have been had all program payments been made in cash, not counting storage savings.
Crowley balso said he thought PIK certificates had lowered the price of corn and boosted domestic consumption of corn.
Agriculture bUndersecretary Daniel Amstutz told the committee that the additional costs of using PIK certificates and storage, handling and transportation costs "balance off very closely."
Amstutz said he estimated the net cost f using certificates was about one pct higher than using only cash to make program payments.

William Bailey, USDA deputy administrator for program planning, said there were "one hundred issues I find either incorrect (in the GAO report), disagree wih or where their (GAO) facts are inconsistent with what's going on."
Amstutz said GAO had not given USDA the option of "providing inpu"t into the preparation of their report "as they frequently do."

The USDA undersecretary also conceded that certificates and marketing loans had the similar effect of "putting more goods into the market," but that whlie the department supported certificates, it would continue to oppose a marketing loan for wheat and feedgrains because it would cost too much.

Angola's U.S.-backed UNITA rebel group has offered to reopen the Benguela railroad that runs through UNITA-held territory and links landlocked Zaire and Zambia ot the Angolan port of Lobito.

UNITA leader Jonas Savimbi, in a statement made in ihs Jamba headquarters in southern Angola and released by UNITA's Washington office, said he was prepared to guarantee safe passage for non-military freight as a gesture of "peace and reconciliation."
Savimbi challenged the Cuban-backed Agolan government, which controls the port, to match his offer and allow goods to pass through.
There as no immediate response from Luanda.
UNITA has ben fighting the Cuban-backed Angolan government since 1976.
The offer of a ril route to the Atlantic would help South Africa's black neighbors reduce their economic dependence on South Africa.
The U.S. Congress is curently considering a proposal to spend some 500 mln dlrs to build another railroad to help these states become less dependent on South Africa.
The Beira corridor runs trough Mozambique to Tanzania's Indian ocean ports but Savimbi suggested the Benguela route as an alternative.
"The Benguela rout can safely open immediately," he said.
"It will provide the transportation our neighbors need, and it will not cost the Americans the money they say it will cost to oen the Beira corridor."
