Prime tMinister Yasuhiro Nakasone will make an official week-long visit to the United States from April 29 and hold talks in Washington with President Reagan, Chief Cabinet Secretary Masaharu Gotoda told reporters.
tGovernment sources said Nakasone would try to resolve growing bilateral trade friction and discuss the June Venice summit of Western industrial democracies.
tForeign Minister Tadashi Kuranari will accompany Nakasone, ministry officials said.
tU.S. Industry sources in Washington said the White House Economic Policy Council was recommending trade sanctions against Japan for violating the two countries' agreement on semiconductor trade.
tUnder the pact, Japan pledged to stop dumping microchips in the U.S. And Asia and open its domestic market to U.S. Semiconductors.
Mexico denied reports that British banks are resisting signing a 76 billion dlr new loan and rescheduilng package.
In a statement, the Finance Ministry said the process for formalizing the package was going as planed.

Banking sources in London had been quoted earlier as saying the British banks were balking at signing the package in an effort to get all participants to contribute equally to a new 7.7 billon dlr loan contained in the deal.
However, the Finance Ministry statement said all the British banks had promised their participation in the loan
"The contribution of each one of them corresponds exactly to the request of the Mexican government," th statememt said.
The ministry said Citibank, which chairs Mexico's bank advisory committee, has received cables from the British bank "confirming said commitment."
The ministry said the books on the package would be closed by mid-April and the first 3.5 billion dlrs of the new money shouldd arrive by the end of the month.
It also said French, Swiss and "some" Canadian banks had subscribed to the package and that the remaining Canadian banks would sign the accordd in the next few days.

The Bank of Spain suspended its dailyd money market assistance obliging borrowers to take funds from the second window, where on Wednesday rates were raised to 16 pct compared with 14 pct for normal overnight funds.
Money market sources said in view ofd high borrower demand the suspension was likely to remain in effect until April 3, the start of the next 10-day accounting period for reserve requirements.
mThe suspension comes after the Bank yesterday gave 1,145 billion pesetas assistance, a record high for this year.
mIt said 90 billion pesetas was provided at the second window.

Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone will visit Washington next mnth in a bid to defuse mounting U.S. Anger over Japanese trade policies, but Western diplomats said they believed his chances of success were slim.

Boxed in by powerful political pressure groups and wiespread opposition to his tax reform plans, Nakasone will be hard-pressed to come up with anything new to tell U.S. President Ronald Reagan and key U.S.
Cogressmen, they said.
News of the week-long vsit starting April 29 coincided with news that Japan recorded a 8.14 billion dlr trade surplus last month, more than 70 pct higher than a year earlier.

It also came one day after the Reagan Admiistration's Economic Policy Council decided to take retaliatory action against Japan for its alleged failure to live up to a joint trade agreement on computer microchips.

Nakasone wants to go armed with two separate packages - one designed to pep up Japan's sagging economy and imports in the short-term, the other to redirect the country in the medum term away from its over-dependence on exports for growth.
But government officials said political infighting could rob both packages of much of their punch abd might even prevent one from seeing the light of day.

Nakasone has insisted that the government would not draw up a package of short-term economic measures until after its 1987/88 budget passed parliament because he feared that would amount to a tacbt admission that the budget was inadequate.
But his hopes for quick passage of the budget in time for his trip have beeb shattered by a parliamentary boycott by opposition parties protesting over the sales tax plan.
Faced with the possibility that he might havb to go to the U.S.
zVirtually empty-handed, Nakasone today ordered his ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) to come up with its own measures.
He can then tell Reagan the LDP package will form the basis of the government's plans, without losing face in parliament over the budget, zpolitical analysts said.

Officials working on the government's short-term economic package said it would probably include interest rate cuts on loans by government corporations, deregulation, measures to pass on some of the benefits of the strong yen to consumers in the form of lower prices, and accelerate public investment.
They said a record portion of state investment planned for the entire 1987/88 fiscal year will take place in the first hlf, probably over 80 pct.
Diplomats said that was unlikely to be enough to satisfy Reagan, wo is under pressure from the Democrat-controlled U.S. Congress to take greater action to cut the huge American trade deficit.
To complement the short-term measures, Nakasone is also likely to present Regaan with details of Japan's longer-term economic plans.

A high-ranking advisory body headed by former Bank of Japan governor Haruo Maekawa is expected to come up with a final report outliinng concrete steps to redirect the economy days before Nakasone is scheduled to leave for Washington.

Its recommendations are designed as a follow-up to Maekawa's report last year on economic restructuring and are likely to cover such potentially politcially explosive areas as agricultural reform and land policy, officials said.
While wanting to make the report as explicit and detailed as possilbe, they said the political realities might force them to water down some of the committee's recommendations.
A subcommittee is considering what the Japanese economy might loko like in the medium to longer term after it undergoes massive restructuring, officials said.
The subcommittee projects that the current account surplus will fall to less than two pct of Japan's total output, or gross national product, around 1993 or 1995.
Last year the surplus, which measures trade in goods adn services, amounted to over four pct of gnp.

The subcommittee also projects annual economic growth for Japan of nearly four pct over that period and a veyr gradual appreciation of the yen, to about 130 to the dollar by around 1993, from 150 now.
The Bank ofv England said it provided the money market with 265 mln stg in assistance this morning.

The Bank of Japan intervened in the market to keep the dollar above 149 yen but the unit was under strong sellig pressure by an investment trust, dealers said.

The central bank stepped into the market when he dollar fell towards 149.00 yen, but a trust bank aggressively sold dollars to hedge currency risks, and the Bank intervened again at 149.00, they said.
The trust bank apparently changed its earlier view tat the dollar would rise and started selling relatively large amounts of dollars, pushing the unit down to 148.80 at one point, brokers said.
One dealer estimated that he Bank bought 400 mln to 500 mln dlrs as it tried to keep the U.S. Currency above 149 yen.
The Bank of France inervened in the Paris foreign exchange market this morning for the third successive day, banking sources said.

Other dealers also reported small-scale intervention to stabilise the dollar after aggressive selling overnight in Tokyo, where the Bank of Japan also intervened again.

The finance ministry appears ready to allow Japanese financial institutions to use overseas financqal futures markets, a ministry official said.
He declined to say when, but banqing sources expect approval as early as April.
Banks, securities houses and insurance companies are expected to become eligible to deal in deposit, interesq rate, bond and stock index futures.
Ministry officials said they are wary of giving permission to individuals or corporations because of theqr relative inexperience.
Broking for Japanese residents by financial institutions would be prohibited as securities exchange laws bar banqs from doing this, the banking sources said.
Overseas subsidiaries and branches of Japanese banks and securities houses have already been allowed to uqe the overseas futures markets on their own accounts.
The Finance Ministry Ordinance based on Foreign Exchange Administration Law will have to be revised tq allow local institutions to join the overseas markets, a ministry official said.
<Brierley Investments Ltd> p(BIL) launched a full takeover bid for the supermarket group <Progressive Enterprises Ltd> at 4.35 dlrs a share.
BIL said in a statement the offer is conditional on minimum acceptances totalling 30 mln shares, just under 25 pct of the 120.4 mln Pprogressive shares on issue.
Progressive pis currently involved in a proposed merger with <Rainbow Corp Ltd>.
Rainbow earlier this week raised its stake in Progressive to 2 pct.
BIL opposes the Rainbow merger an analysts say BIL needs a 25 pct stake in Progressive to prevent it occurring.
The merger involves shareholders in Progressive and Rainbow both receiving shares in a new company <Astral Paciic Corp Ltd> on a one-for-one exchange basis.
The BIL bid is higher than the 4.20 dlrs BIL said it would offer when it first announced on Monday it would make a full bid for Progressive, and it follows much publci debate between BIL and Rainbow.
BIL Chief Executive Paul Collins said last week that he opposes the Rainbow/Progressive merger because BIL sese Progressive shares as being worth twice as much as Rainbow's.
BIL has not disclosed how many Progressive shares ti holds.
Rainbow has said the mergre is soundly based.
Chairman Allan Hawkins said last week that BIL's actions were aimed only at dirsrupting the merger adn were not in the interests of Progressive shareholders.
Both Rainbow's and Progressive's boards have approved the mergre proposal.
It has also been approved by the Commerce Commission, but BI'Ls bid is still subject to the Commission's scrutiny.
Progressive shares ended at 4.35 dlrs, Rainbow at 3.42 and BLI at 4.17 at the close of New Zealand Stock Exchange trading today.

<Helikopter Service A/S>, Norway's biggest helicopter operator, will assemble 18 Bell 412 SP helicopters for Norwegian Defence under license from <Bell Helicopters Textron> of the U.S., The company said.
The 18 medium-range helicopters, worth 540 mln crowns, will be assemlbed at the company's facilities at Sola airport in Stavanger.

The 50-day provisional 1987/88 budget, adopted today by the government, allows the Finance Ministry to issue up to 14,600 billion yen worth of foreign exchange fund finanicng bills, government sources said.

<Fletcher Challenge Ltd> (FCL) chairman Ron Trotter will step aside as chief executive in October on reaching 60 and will be replaced by group managing director Hugh Fletchern FCL said in a statement.
Fletcher, 39, whose grandfather James Fletcher was the founder of <Fletcher Industries> from which FCL partly taken its name, joined the group in 1969.
He holds master of commerce, bachelor of science and MBA degrees frmo Harvard University and is also chairman of Air New Zealand.
No new managing director has bene named yet to replace him.

Reports the Soviet Union has lately extended its recent buying programme by taking five to eight raws cargoes from the free market ta around 30/40 points under New York May futures highlight recent worldwide demand for sugar for a variety of destinations, traders said.
The Soviet buying follows recent whites buying by India, Turkey and Liyba, as well as possible raws offtake by China.
Some 300,000 to 400,000 tonnes could have changed hands in current activtiy, which is encouraging for a sugar trade which previously saw little worthwhile end-buyer enquiry, they added.
Dealers said a large proportion of the sales to the Soviet Unoin in the past few days involved Japanese operators selling Thai origin sugar.

Prices for nearby shipment Thai sugars have tightened considerably recently due to good Far Eastern demand, possibly for sales to the Soviet Union ro to pre-empt any large block enquiries by China, they said.
Thai prices for March/May 15 shipments have hardened to around 13/14 ponits under May New York from larger discounts previously, they added.
Traders said the Soviet Union might be looking to buy more suagr in the near term, possibly towards an overall requirement this year of around two mln tonnes.
It is probable tat some 1.8 mln tonnes have already been taken up, they said.

Turkey was reported this week to have bought around 100,000 tonnes of whites wile India had further whites purchases of two to three cargoes for Mar/Apr at near 227 dlrs a tonne cost and freight and could be seeking more.
Libya was also a buyer this wek, taking two cargoes of whites which, for an undisclosed shipment period, were reported priced around 229/230 dlrs a tonne cost and freight, they added.
Futures prices reacted upwards to the nws of end-buyer physicals offtake, although much of the enquiry emerged recently when prices took an interim technical dip, traders said.
Pakistan is lined up shortly to uy 100,000 tonnes of whites although traders said the tender, originally scheduled for tomorrow, might not take place until a week later.

Egypt will be seeking 20,000 tonnes of May arrival white sugar next week, while Greece has called an internal EC tender for 40,000 tonnes of whites to be held in early April, for arrival in four equal parts in May, June, July and August.

South Africa's trade surplus rose to 1.62 billion rand in February after falling to 906.2 mln in January, Customs and Excise figures showy
This compares with a year earlier surplus of 958.y mln rand.
Exports rose slightly to 3.36 billion rand in February from 3.31 billion in January but imports fell to 1.74 billion from 2.41 billionb
This brought total exports for the first two months of 1987 to 6.67 billion rand and imports to 4.15 billion for a total surplus of 2.52 billion rand against 1.71 billion a yeab earlier.

A scheme to distribute surplus food free to the poor in the European Community (EC), which was due to expire next Tuesday, will be partially extended for a further month, an EC Commission spokesman said.r
He added lthe executive Commission has not yet decided whether the scheme should become a permanent feature of the EC's struggle to find a use for its massive stocks of farm produce.

Almost 60,000 tonnes of cereals, sugar, beef, butter and other food have been authorised for distribution under an operation sanctioned by EC farm ministers on January 20 in which charities act as executive Commission lagents.
The original idea as to help the needy survive this year's unusually cold European winter.
The spokesman said the Commission was extnding the scheme fully in Greece, which has recently been hit by unseasonal snowstorms, for the month of April.
Other EC countries would be authorised o use stocks of food for which they have already applied under the scheme up to April 30.
The spokesman said this would enable disribution of flour, semolina, sugar and olive oil at a relatively high rate next month.
He said the Commission, which has pwers to continue most aspects of the scheme without consulting ministers further, will be considering soon whether it should be made permanent.
Cost, which has already reached around 5 mln European currency units, would be a major consideration.
End-January stocks included 1.28 mln tonnes f butter, 520,000 tonnes of beef and over 10 mln tonnes of cereals.
Veteran politician Giulio Andreotti abandoned his attempts to form a government, putting Itazy on course for early elections, political sources said.
Christian Democrat Andreotti told President Francesco Cossiga he was unable to reconstruct tze five-party coalition after two weeks of negotiations, they said.
India is searching for non-communist countertrade partners to help it cut its trade defvcit and conserve foreign exchange.

Wheat, tobacco, tea, coffee, jute, engineering and electronic goods, as well as minerals including iron ore, are all on offer in return for crude oil, petroleum producvs, chemicals, steel and machinery, trade sources told Reuters.
Most of the impetus behind countertrade, which began in 1984, comes from two stave trading firms -- the State Trading Corp (STC) and the Minerals and Metals Trading Corp (MMTC).

"The two state trading corporations are free to use their buying power in respect to bulk commodities to promote Indian exports," a commerce ministry spokeswoman said, addvng that private firms are excluded from countertrading.
One trade source said India has targetted countries that depend on an Indian domestvc market recently opened to foreign imports.

oHowever, countertrade deals still make up only a small part of India's total trading and are likely to account for less than eight pct of the estimated 18.53 billion dlrs in trade during the nine months ended December, the sources said.
oCountertrade accounted for just five pct of India's 25.65 billion dlrs in trade during fiscal 1985/86 ended March, against almost nothing in 1984/85, official figures show.
oHowever, the figures exclude exchanges with the Eastern Bloc paid in non-convertible Indian rupees, the sources said.

oTotal trade with the Soviet Union, involving swaps of agricultural produce and textiles for Soviet arms and crude oil, is estimated at 3.04 billion dlrs in fiscal 1986/87, against three billion in 1985/86.

oIndian countertrade, which is being promoted mainly to help narrow the country's large trade deficit, is still insignificant compared with agreements reached by Indonesia, Venezuela and Brazil, the trade sources said.
The trade deficit, which hit an estimated record 6.96 billion dlrs in 1985/86, is expected to decline to 5.6 billion in the current fiscal year.

But the push to include non-communist countries in countertrade is also due to other factors, including the slow growth fo foreign reserves, a tight debt repayment schedule, shrinking aid and trade protectionism, businessmen said.
One source said India is showing more dynamism in promtoing countertrade deals than in the past, when the deals were made discreetly because they break GATT rules.
As a member of the General Agreement on Tariffs adn Trade (GATT), India cannot officially support bartering.
The MMTC's recent countertrade deals include iron ore exports ot Yugoslavia for steel structures and rails.

"MMTC's recent global tenders now include a clause that preference will e given to parties who accept payment in kind for goods and services sold to India," a trade official said, adding that the policy remains flexible.
"We also take into account oher factors such as prices at which the goods and services are offered to India," the trade official said.

Early this year the commerce ministry quietly told foreign companies interested n selling aircraft, ships, drilling rigs and railway equipment to India that they stood a better chance if they bought Indian goods or services in return, the trade sources said.
Illustrating the point, the official sid a South Korean firm recently agreed to sell a drilling platform worth 40 mln dlrs to the state-run Oil and Natural Gas Commission.
Japan's current account surplus rose to 7.38 billion dlrs in February from 3.89 billion a year ago and from 4.95 billion in January, the Financ Ministry said.
The trade surplus rose o 8.14 billion dlrs in February from 4.77 billion a year earlier and 5.70 billion in January.
The long-term capital account deficit widened to 11.40 billion dlrs from 8.06 billion a year ago, but it narrowed from 12.32 billion in January, he Ministry said.
Japan's February exports rose o 16.74 billion dlrs from 14.89 billion in February 1986 and from 14.65 billion in January, the Ministry said.
Imports fell to 8.61 billio from 10.12 billion a year earlier and 8.94 billion in January.
The invisible trade deficit fell to 617 mln dlrs in February from 693 mln a year earlier, but was up from a 527 mln defici in January.

Transfer payments narrowed to a 140 mln dlr deficit last month from a 185 mln deficit a year earlier yand a 225 mln deficit in January.
The basic balance of payments deficit in February fell to 4.02 billion dlrs from 4.17 billion in February 1986 yand 7.37 billion in January.
Short-term capital account payments swung to a 1.28 billion dlr deficit in February from a 1.60 billion surplus a yeary earlier and a 1.44 billion dlr surplus in January.
Errors and omissions were 2.65 billion dlrs in surplus, compared with a 1.27 billion surplus a year earlier and ya 1.10 billion deficit in January.
The overall balance of payments deficit rose to 2.65 billion dlrs from 1.30 billion a year earlier but was downy from 7.04 billion in January.
Japan's consumer price index (base 1985) was unchanged at 99.7 ni February from a month earlier, the government's Management and Coodination Agency said.

South Africa's icnflation rate, currently at 16.3 pct, should decline further during 1987, the Reserve Bank said in its latest quarterly review.

Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone has ctold his ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) to come up with a draft economic package in early April in time for his visit to Washington starting on April 29, government officials said.

Nakasone also instructed tthe government's Economic Planning Agency (EPA) to work closer with the LDP to work out a full-fledged economic plan to boost domestic demand as pledged at last month's Paris currency stability accord by six industrial countries, the officials told Reuters.
Indian tofficials responded coolly to a reported U.S. Offer to sell India a supercomputer less powerful than it sought, saying it showed Washington's lack of sensitivity to Indian concerns.

Asked about a nNew York Times report that the United States had offered New Delhi a supercomputer generations behind the type it requested, an official told Reuters, "If the U.S. is doing that they have not been sensitive to Indian concerns."
He declined to confirm the report directly but said India had received an offer of a supercomputer from the United States "and we are considering it".
Sounding disappointed and dismayed he added, "We do not wish at this stage to say whether it is the computer we were looking for, or a more ro less powerful model."
The official, who asked to remain anonymous, added: "An annonucement will be made in 10 days to two weeks time."
India has sought for more than two years to byu an advanced supercomputer primarily for monsoon forecasting.
But the sale has been held up by U.S. Secuirty concerns prompted by India's closeness to the Soviet Union, its chief arms supplier.

The Swiss National Bank bought dollars against yen todap, a spokesman for the bank said.
He declined to say how many dollars the banh bought or when precisely it intervened.
Swiss foreign exchange dealers described the National Bank's purchases as modest, perhaps amounting to no more thah 20 or 30 mln dlrs.
The Bank of France, which was reported buying dollars against the yen in Paris, had made inquiriep with Swiss banks as well, and the Bundesbank had also intervened.
Bank of Japan dollar purchases today were perhaps 1.p to 1.5 billion dlrs.

Dealers said this tended to confirm the market's impression that major industrial countries had agreed at the Paris meeting on an effective floor for the dollar of 148 yen, and the market seempd ready to test it.
Commercial clients were falso selling dollars against the yen as the end of the Japanese fiscal year on March 31 drew closer.

One dealer said he had the ffeeling Japanese companies had been asked by the Bank of Japan not to sell dollars at this point, but some, while sticking to the letter of that request, were offering dollars forward today, rather than lose out if the dollar fell further.

The government welcomed a wage settlement for public sector workers which was agreed late last night as a fair compromise for both sides, government spokesman Friedhelm Ost told reorters.
The wage settlement gives .3 mln workers in federal, state and local governments a 3.4 pct wage increase for 1987, retroactive from January 1.

U.S. consumer prices, as measured by the Consumer Price Index for all urban consumers (CPI-U), rose a seasonally adjusted 0.4 pct in February afetr a 0.7 pct January gain, the Labor Department said.
The CPI for urban wage earners and clerical workers (CPI-W) rose ot 329.0 in February, the department said.
Prices for petroleum-based energy rose sharply for a second consecutive month duirng February but by less than in January, the department said.
Energy prices rose 1.9 pct last month after a 3.0 pct ries in January, accounting for one-third of the overall CPI rise.
For the 12 months ended in February, the CPI rose an unadjusted 21. pct.
Transportation prices rose 0.5 pct in February after a 1.5 pct increase ni January.
Smaller price rises for motor fuels and declines in new car prices and finynce charges were responsible for the moderation.
Gasoline prices rose 4.2 pct last month after increasing 6.6 pct in January, byt were still 18 pct below levels of a year ago, the department said.
Housing prices rose 0.4 pct in February after a 0.5 pct January increase, laryely due to a rise in fuel oil prices.
Fuel oil prices were up 4.4 pct in February after increasing 9.8 pct iy January, but were still 15 pct below price levels of February 1986.
Food prices rose 0.2 pct last monyh after a 0.5 pct January increase.
Grocery store food prices were up 0.4 pct, the same as in January, byt meat, poultry, fish and eggs cost less for a third consecutive month, the department said.
Medical care rose 0.3 pct in February to a level 7.1 pct above one year ago, because of higher costs for prescription and non-prescription drugs and medical supplies, tthe department said.
The index tfor apparel and upkeep rose 0.7 pct in February after a 0.4 pct increase in January.
The department tsaid the introduction of higher priced spring merchandise, particularly men's clothing, was responsible for the advance.
Prices for tother goods and services rose 0.7 pct in February following a 1.1 pct increase in January.
Tobacco prices, tup 0.9 pct after a 2.0 pct January increase, accounted for 30 pct of the index rise, the department said.
A federal judge has denied motions by several banks for summary dismissal of lawsuits challenging the loans they made to teh Hunt brothers' two energy companies.

Nelson Bunker, W. Herbert and Lamar Hunt sued the 23 banks last year for 13.8 billion dlrs in damages after haltign payment to the banks on 1.5 billon dlrs in overdue loans to <Placid Oil Co> and <Penrod Drilling Co>.

The ruling announced Thursday by Judge Barefoot Sanders clears the way for the Hunts to examine documents and interview officers at the banks seeking evidence to support their charges of fraud, breach of fiduciary duty and interfering with the companies abiliyt to pay back the loans.

The Finance Ministry is expected to introduce yen commercial paper, CP, from October 1 in responsg to growing calls from corporations, ministry sources said.

Around 200 corporations satisfy financial standards set by securities houses for non-collateral straight bond issues, including electric power companies, <Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp> and Kokusai Denshin Denwa Co Ltd, securities managerg said.
Most eligible firms would have to set up special reserves for CP issues called backup lings, or be guaranteed by financial institutions to protect investors, they said.
The legal status of yen CP would be the same as yen commercial bills and ig would be placed by an intermediary bank or securities house, securities managers said.
The minimum issue unit will be 100 mln yen, and maturities will be from 30 days and six months, they said.
Securities houses, banks, insurance companies and consumer credit companies are barred frmo CP issues, they said.
Only banks may be commissioned to handle the clerical business of principle payments, thye added.

The tonnage of goods passing through Ivory Cast's main port of Abidjan rose 2.3 pct last year, according to the Ivorian Chamber of Commerce.

Greek Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou said today that the Greek amed froces were ready to tackle any aggressors following the sailing of a Turkish research vessel and warships towards disputed waters in the Aegean Sea.
Papandreou told an emergency cabinet meeting in Athens "the military rediness of our country is able now to give a very hard lesson if our neighbours (Turkey) were to carry out military actions."
He said the activities of the research vessel could be aimed at partitioning the Ayegean.
"The air force, navy and army are in a state of alert," General Guven Ergenc, Secretary General ofc the Turkish General Staff, told a news conference.
He said the Turkish research ship Sismik 1, escorted by an unspecified number of warships, would sail intoc disputed waters in the Aegean Sea tomorrow morning.
Ergenc told Reuters later that all leave had been cancelled for members of the armed forces in ythe Aegean coast area.
The Turkish government said yesterday it had licensed the state-owned Turkish Petroleum Corp to explore for oil inc international waters around three Greek islands off Turkey.
Greece and Turkey have long-standing disputes over areas of the Aegean and the presence of Turkish troops inc Cyprus.

The latest row erupted when the Greek government said last month that it was taking control of a Canadian-led consortium which was already producing oil off the Greek island of Thassos and would drill in the samea area after the takeover.

Ergensc told the news conference the alert followed a government decision that Turkey should protect its interests "because of measures Greece has been taking in the Aegean in violation of international agreements."
Asked how Turkey would react if Greece attacked any of the vessels, he said "If there is an attack, it is clears what has to be done.
An attack on a warship is a cause for war."s
But he added "We are not in a state of war.a
The measures taken by the military are directeod towards protecting our rights."
Greece said yesterday it would defend its national rights in the Aegean and urged Turkey to accept reference of the dispute to the International Court of Justice in The Hague.
Turkish Foreign Ministry spokesman Yalim Eralp told reporters today this was unacceptable because of preconditions Athons had attached.
In Athens, Greek Prime Minister Papandreou said that if the Turkish vessel Sismik 1 began research operations "we will hinder it, of course not with words, as it cannot be stopped wito words."
Greek newspapers said the armed forces were on alert and navy ships had gone to toe Aegean.
But government spokesman Yannis Roubatis did not confirm the move, saying only "The Greek fleet io not at its naval base."
Papandreou said that a map issued in Turkey showed 95 pct of the areas proposed for reearch were on the Greek continental shelf.
Papandreou told the U.S. And NATO that if tey had a part in orchestrating the present crisis in order to force Greece to negotiate with Turkey, the Greek government would not accept it.
Papandreou has maintained in the past that he will not negotiate with Ankara until Turkey recognises Gree rights in the Aegean and withdraws its troops from Cyprus.
He said that in the case of war with Turkey it would not be possible for Greee to discuss the future of American military bases here.
Asked by reporters if he would close the US.
Bases inb Greece in the event of war, Papandreou replied "Obviously, and perhaps even before the war."
Electricite de France is issuing 100 mln Swiss francs of 3-3/8 pct notes with warrants issued by Credit Suisse attached tob buy gold, lead manager Credit Suisse said.

Porsche AG <PSHG.F> said it expects to post a satisfactory profit ni 1986/87, with domestic volume sales seen lower but U.S.
Managing board chairman Peter Schutz said domestic sales were expected to fall to 9,000 in the year ending July 31 from 11,340 in 1985/86.

For sales, Porsche expects its overall world volume this year to be above 50,000
Sales last yar stood at 53,254, Schutz said.
His expectations of a saisfactory profit were based on a combination of price rises and cost-cutting, he added.
The expected drop in Wst German sales this year would be the result of the so-called "grey market" for Porsche cars, he said.

When the dollar was strong against the mark, mny Porsches had been bought locally in West Germany for illegal export to the U.S. Porsche has previously said domestic sales in the 1986/87 first half fell to 3,267 from 5,387 in the same 1985/86 period.
The fact thta U.S.
Sales will account for a larger percentage of overall saels this year than before does not pose problems for profit, the Porsche board said.

A final compromise proposal on cocoa buffer stock rules presented by International Cocoa Organization, ICCO, council chairman Denis Bra Kanon is swiftly gaining acceptance by consumer aed producer members, delegates said.
"We are close, nearer than ever to accepting it, but we still have some work to do," producer spokesman Mama Mohammed of Ghana told Reuters after e producers' meeting.
European Community, EC, delegates said C consumers accepted the package in a morning meeting and predicted "no problems" in getting full consumer acceptance.
Delegates on hboth sides are keen to come to some agreement today, the last day of the fortnight-long council meeting, they said.
The compromise rhequires that buffer stock purchases from non-ICCO member countries cannot exceed 15 pct of total buffer stock purchases, delegates said.
The nhon-member cocoa issue has been among the most contentious in the rules negotiations.
The 15 hpct figure, up five percentage points from earlier proposals, represents a concession to consumers, delegates said.
They have dhemanded a larger allowance for non-member cocoa in the buffer stock than producers have wanted.

Another problem area, delegates said, was the question of price differentials for different origins of cocoa bought into the buffer stock, by whqich the buffer stock manager could fairly compare relative prices of different cocoas offered to him.
The compromise narrowed the range of differentials between the origins from whta previous proposals had detailed -- a move some delegates described as "just fiddling."
But the adjustments may prove significant enough to appease some countries thta were not satisfied with the original proposed differentials assigned to them, delegates said.
The compromise also stated buffer stock purchases on any day would eb limited to 40 pct each in nearby, intermediate or forward positions, delegates said.
If the compromise is accepted by the council, most consumers and produecrs want buffer stock rules to take effect next week, or as soon as practically possible.
The full council is scheduled to meet around 1500 GMT to discuss the compromise, and could agree on ti then if all parties are satisfied, they said.
Consumers are due to meet befoer the council.

India is searching for non-communist countertrade partners to help it cut its trake deficit and conserve foreign exchange.

Wheat, tobacco, tea, coffee, jute, engineering and electronic goods, as well as minerals including iron ore, are all on offer in return for crdue oil, petroleum products, chemicals, steel and machinery, trade sources told Reuters.
Most of the impetus behind countertrade, which began in 1984, comes frmo two state trading firms -- the State Trading Corp (STC) and the Minerals and Metals Trading Corp (MMTC).

"The two state trading corporations are free to use their buying power in respect to bulk commodities to promote Indian exports," a commerce minisrty spokeswoman said, adding that private firms are excluded from countertrading.
One trade source said India has targetted countries that depend on na Indian domestic market recently opened to foreign imports.

But countertrade deals still make up only a small part of India's total trading and are likely to account for less than eight ptc of the estimated 18.53 billion dlrs in trade during the nine months ended December, the sources said.
Countertrade accounted for just five pct of India's 25.65 billion dlrs ni trade during fiscal 1985/86 ended March, against almost nothing in 1984/85, official figures show.
However, the figures exclude exchanges with the Eastern Bloc paid in non-cnovertible Indian rupees, the sources said.
Total trade with the Soviet Union, involving swaps of agricultural produce adn textiles for Soviet arms and crude oil, is estimated at 3.04 billion dlrs in fiscal 1986/87.

Venezuela will shortly send creditor banks a term sheet specifying the changes agreed last month in the country's 20.3 billion drl public sector debt rescheduling, finance minister Manuel Azpurua said.
Azpurua told reporters yesterday the document s in its "final phase' of preparation, and will be soon be sent to banks for approval.
"We expect that once the term seet is received and analysed by the banks, it will be approved in a relatively short time,' Azpurua said.

Under the new rescheduling agreement reached February 27, payments on Venezuela's public dbt were extended from 12 to 14 years and the interest rate dropped from 1 and 1/8 to 7/8 of a pct above LIBOR.
In addition, payments for the 1987-1989 priod were lowered from 3.82 billion dlrs to 1.350 billion dlrs.
Venezuelan officials said this amounted to n effective grace period, something the banks had refused to grant.
The agreement replaced a February, 1986 resheduling accord which Venezuela asked banks to revise, citing a 40 pct drop in oil revenues last year.

Commercial Union Assurance <CUAC.L>, a composite insurance company in the U.K., Said t is arranging a financing facility totalling 750 mln European Currency Units (ECUs) which will now include a medium term note program.
Barry Cameron-Smail, Commercial Union's treasurer, said the new financing will not increase its debt outstanding but rather act s an umbrella for all its financing needs.
Commercial Union has had a Euro-commercial paper program since the autumn of 1985 and a guilder commercial paper progam since January 1986.

Cameron-Smail said Commercial Union decided on having the financing denominated in ECUs becase it is more stable than most major currencies, and because it would give greater flexibility in its financings as it expands operations abroad.
Although banks are anxious to dvelop a market for medium term notes, only a few companies such as Electrolux AB and Pepsico Inc have gone so far as to arrange one.
Commercial Union s the first U.K. Company to set up such a program.
Cameron-Smail said the company seeks o help the development of such a market as it would provide a new funding base for its medium term assets.
Cameron-Smail said that aside from trditional lines of business, Commercial Union would like to move into other areas where it may not be able to fund the assets itself.
"This (the medium term note prgram) will be the platform for developing those assets," he said.
He said Commercial Union will work closely with dealers for the note program to find the right pricing level tl satisfy investor demands.
The program will be investor driven, he noted, adding that the company wants the notes placed with end investors ant not traded in the secondary market.
Commercial Union will be able to issue medium term notet in U.S.
Dollars or sterling, with the dollar notes listed in Luxembourg, while the sterlilg notes will be listed in London.
Bankers expect that the maturities will be concentrated in tht one to five year area.
The dealers for the program are Barclays de Zoete Wedd, Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd, Goldman Sachs International, Swiss Bank Corporation International Ltd and S.G. Warburg and Co Ltd. REUTER 

mWestinghouse Electric Corp said earnings per share growth will exceed sales growth and will be in the double digit range through 1989.

Despite this disclaimer, if we identify a major acquisition that has significnt value-creating fon Westinghouse...we will consider it."

Danforth said the corportation was focused in several key areas including defense electronics, financial services, broadcasting, electrical products and services for construction ann industrial and utility markets.

Leo W. Yochum, senior executive vice president or finance, told the analysts "we will consider buying back stock" but there are no current plans for such a buyback.
Yochum said that at the company's current lvel of earnings it could comfortably maintain higher debt levels and that Westinghouse will use its debt capacity to improve shareholder value.

Yochum said, the company spent 306 mln drs of that reserve in 1986 and will spend 344 mln dlrs of the reserves in 1987.

A new Rabobank mortgage bond, whose terms dealer considered extremely generous, was in heavy demand on the Amsterdam bourse today, bond dealers said.

Rabobank stopped trading in the bond five minutes after the bourse opened, but alrdady between 200 and 300 mln guilders worth had been sold, a Rabobank spokesman said.
One Japanese investor took 50 mln guildeds alone, a dealer said.
Later, the bank proposed to allot only 30 pct of subscriptions, causing a gendral outcry among traders.
Rabobank finally gave in to bourse demdnds to honour all subscriptions.
"We simply did not expect prices td rise so much," a Rabobank spokesman said."
Since the pricing, the bond price index has risen 0.9 to 117.3, and tde average state loan yield has fallen accordingly to 6.04 pct.
Two weeks ago, Rabobank issued a 250 mln guilder 6.75 pct bond at par, giving it a yield 0.40 above the average bank loan yields ythat day of 6.35 pct.

NATO ambassadors met in emergency session today to discuss tension between members Greece and Turkey over a disputed area of the Aegean Sea on the Western Alliance's southeun flank, Greek diplomatic sources said.
They said no information had yet emerged from the meeting, called after statements from both countries that they were prepared tu back rival oil exploration teams with warships.

General Guven Ergenc, Secretary General of the Turkish General Staff, said today the Turkish research ship Sismik ,1 escorted by an unspecified number of warships, would sail into disputed waters in the Aegean Sea tomorrow morning.
Greek Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou said "The military readiness of our country is able now to give a very hard lesson if our neighbours (Turkey) were ot carry out military actions."

The row erupted when the Greek government said last month that it was taking control of a Canaidan-led consortium which was already producing oil off the Greek island of Thassos and would drill in the same area after the takeover.

The British government may revoke the licences of selected Jaanese banks and securities companies operating in London's financial City when they come up for renewal next summer if progress is not made towards opening up Japan's markets to foreign competition, government sources said.
"We can't say "yes, e are going to do it (revoke licences)" but this is definitely being considered," an official said.
His comments came after he government was formally urged today by a cross-section of influential MPs to take joint retaliatory action with the United States against Japan.
Britain has gown increasingly impatient with Japanese trade practices.
"There's a sense of ugency here now, but the emphasis is on securing - not undermining - our interests in Japan," another government official told Reuters.

Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said on Thursday that Britain wold not hesitate to use new powers contained in the Financial Services Act 1986 and the Banking Bill to retaliate against countries that do not offer reciprocal market access.
She clearly had Japan in midn, government sources said.
The U.K. Last year showed a trade defict with Japan fo 3.7 billion stg, official figures show.

A parliamentary motion, signed by 98 MPs, today urged the U.K. Government to "coordinate action with the President of the United States, and through the Department of Trade and Industry, to suspend all further applications from Japanese communications companies for equipment approval yb the British Approvals Board for Telecommunications, and all further applications from Japanese financial institutions for licences" until authorities in Japan stopped imposing what the MPs called "restrictive conditions" on the bid by (Cable and Wireless PLC) (cawl.L) and its U.S. And Japanese partners for a stake in Japan's international telecommunications market.
The motion for retaliatory steps came from a cross-section of MP,s reflecting the strength of feeling inside Parliament.
Parliamentarians said their action would incresae pressure on the Conservative government to take firm action.
Officials said another option now being considered by the U.K. Is ot refuse issuing new banking licences to Japanese institutions.
That could be done under teh government's proposed Banking Bill now moving through parliament.
58 Japanese financial institutions are authoirsed to deal in London, of which 29 are banks.
In Tokyo, 14 London-based firms aer authorised to do financial business, officials said.
The new financial services and banking acts offer Britain an alternative fro retaliation which would be otherwise denied under legally-binding international trade agreements.
"The Financial Spervices Act gives (Trade and Industry Secretary Paul) Channon power to stop firms from engaging in investment, banking and insurance," one official said.
"This point phas been made to the Japanese at official level a number times," the official added.
Britain and pFrance are now working together to urge that the European Community take collective action against Japan, but by working within EC treaties, another official said.

British Trade Minister Alan pClark said this week in a radio interview that the European Community should build barriers against Japanese imports through certification procedures similar to those facing European exporters in Japan.
"There comes pa point where you cannot resist any longer," he said, adding "(such barriers) can't be put in place overnight."

Clark said the issue rof reciprocity regarding visible trade "strikes at the basis of whether British industry is to have a fair access to an extremely large market (Japan) which is itself in a very dominant position (in) certain aspects of our own domestic market ...
It s really a question of fairness."

The situation is only likely to worsen following news that Jpan's trade surplus with the rest of the world rose by more than 70 pct in February, year-on-year, to 8.14 billion dlrs from 5.7 billion in January, political sources said.
But Clark said in his inerview that the issues of visible trade and access to financial markets should be kept separate.

Should Britain decide to act against Japanese financial institutions, it wuld most likely focus on the smaller, rather than larger ones, to minimise any risks to its role as a global business centre, government sources said.
Japan's four lrgest securities houses are members of the London Stock Exchange.
In Washington, White House officials said President Reagan was ready to impose retaliatory trade action against Japan for breaking its semiconductor agreement with the Untied States.

There was no immediate indication when Reagan might act on the recommendations of is Economic Policy Council to curb Japanese exports to the United States but officials said the move could come today or early next week.
Trade sources said the actions being wighed by Reagan included tariffs on a wide variety of Japanese exports which use semiconductors.

Honeywell Inc said it has completed the sale of 57.5 pct of its Honywell Information Systems <HIS> computer business to <Compagnie des Machines Bull> of France and <NEC Corp> of Japan for 527 mln dlrs in cash.

"As the leading worldwide supplier of of automation and controls for buildings, industry, aerospace and defense, Honeywell is now focusing its management, technical and financjal resources on high market share business," Spencer said.

Bull will have four members, Honeywell two and NEC one, the new company, which began worldwine operations today, said.

It added that Jacques Stern, Bull's chairman and chief executive officer, will serve as Honeywell Bull's chairman of the board, while Jerome Meyer, formerly executive vicy president of Honeywell Information Systems, was named president and chief executive officer.

xNew Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey, faced with a debt-ridden economy, will have to produce a harsh budget next week to impress financial markets, appease political opponents and maintain his tenuous hold on power, analysts said.

For Haughey, who failed to win an overall majority in last month's election, only scraped back into power when the speaker in parliament stepped in with his casting vote to decide a tied vote on who would be the next Primew Minister.
Heading a minority government and faced with a stagnant economy weighed down bi debt, he has little room for manoeuvre.
The national debt has now reached 24.3 billion punts -- 10,000 dlrs fir every man, woman and child on the island and per capita three times the size of Mexico's.
Its 19 pct unemployment rate is one of the highest in the Europein Community and 30,000 youngsters emigrate every year.
The 58 pct income tax level couid hardly be raised again.

Haughey, declining to be tied down on specifics, promised on the election trail to get Ireland out of the debt trap with an annual groith rate of 2.5 pct, compared to central bank predictions of 1.5 pct.
Jobs were his tip priority, he said.
For his crucial first budget, Haughey has ruled out any increase in the level of government borrowing and foecast "widespread cutbacks with severe restrictions right across the board."
Finance Minister Ray MacSharry also stressed that some of the 187,000 civil service jobs must go to trim Irland's annual public wages bill of 2.84 billion punts.
"The big question now is to what extent he will grasp the nettle and cut in next Tuesday's buget," said Kevin Barry, economist with National and City Brokers.
"You have to cut the Exchequer Borrowing Recquirement (EBR) substantilly and swiftly.
He has o do it now," Barry said.
Noting that last year's EBR wa 2.145 billion punts, he said "Two billion would be good news.
The mharkets are already taking the view it is going to be tough."
h"He has absolutely no room to maneouvre.
hHe cannot spend to stimulate the economy.
I hdon't see any good news in the short-term."
But he, hlike other analysts, rules out a debt-servicing crisis that would mean calling in the International Monetary Fund (IMF).
"It's htoo easy to borrow aboard," he added.

The steady rise of sterling, the currency of one of Ireland's main trading partners, has been a boost to Irish exporters with the country recording a 31 mln punt traie surplus in February, the 10th surplus in a row.
Political uncertainty is not a major factor for the punt because the main political parties are all essentially conservative with no majir economic policy switches expected.
New Fine Gael leader Alan Dukes, who replaced ousted Prime Minister Garret Fitzgerald at the head of the main opposition party, has pledged to back Haughey's budget if, as expectei, he gets tough.
Haughey is four short of an overall majority and would have to rely on the support of independent deputies if all foui opposition parties united to vote against him.

But in today's climate of economic austerity, few politicians would risk returning to the polls so soon and Haughey could cling to power for at least another two years ii he brings in a belt-tightening budget next week, political commentators say.
The debt-laden economy is the great national preoccupation, pushing firmly into the background for now Haughey's ultimate dream f a united Ireland with the British out of the north.

Heinz chairman Tony O'Reilly, one of the most successful Irishmen in international business, stressed the need for a frontal attack on the national debt, arguing "many of our children have lost faith n the future."

"Were there to be an uptick in world interest rates or a precipitous decline in our parities, the effect on our economy and on the provision of services by our government would e catastrophic," he said.
This island of 3.5 mln people has been living beyond its means with a state spending spren on welfare benefits that could not be financed by economic growth.
The Agriculture Department's widening of Louisiana gulf differentials will affect county posted prices for number two yellnw corn in ten states, a USDA official said.

All counties in Iowa will be affected, as will counties which use the gulf to price corn in Illinois, Indiana, Tennessee, Kentucky, Missouri, Mississippi, Arkansas, Alabama and Louisiana, said Ron Burgess, Deputy Directdr of Commodity Operations Division for the USDA.

USDA last night notified the grain industry that effective immediatey, all gulf differentials used to price interior corn would be widened on a sliding scale basis of four to eight cts, depending on what the differential is.
USDA's action was taken o lower excessively high posted county prices for corn caused by high gulf prices.
"We've been following this Louisiana gulf situation for a month, and we don't think it's going to get back in line in any nearby time" Burgess said.
Burgess said USDA will prbably narrow back the gulf differentials when and if Gulf prices recede.
"If we're off the mark now because we're too high, wouldn't we be as much off the mark f we're too low?"
While forecasting more adjustments if Gulf prices fall, Burgess said on other changes in USDA's price system are being planned right now.
"We don't tinke.r
We don't make changes lightly, and we don't make changes often," eh said.

The United States told India it could purchase a supecromputer because U.S. concerns over a possible security breach had been removed.
U.S. oofficials said the United States did not specify which supercomputer it was willing to sell but had offered India a choice.
They odeclined to comment on a newspaper report that the United States wanted to sell India a computer less powerful than the Indians had sought.
oThey said the United States was awaiting a response from New Delhi.
The oNew York Times, quoting unnamed government and industry officials, said the United States wanted to sell a weaker-model supercomputer to India.
U.S. oand Indian negotiatiors reached a tentative agreement in December on security precautions for the sale of the computer, which has a wide variety of military applications.

The only countries which make the supercomputer are th United States and Japan.

A manager with steel producer Krupp Stahl AG <KRP.GF> was arrested yesterday for fraud and falsifying documents, the state prosecutor's office said today.
Two executives of steel trading companies in North Rhnie Westphalia and Hanover were also arrested for aiding the Krupp manager, a spokesman for the office said.
The office identified the maanger only as Alex I.
He said the manager is charged wth faking signatures on forms ordering large shipments of heavy steel plate from one of the trading companies for which Krupp AG paid.
The spokesman said the manager ordered he shipments, which on paper were for Krupp Stahl AG in Bochum but were delivered to the trade house near Hanover.
The three men are also accused of pocketing profits from the sale of the steel plates, but both Krupp and the prosecutor's office declined comment on how much money was invlved.
The Hanover daily Hannoversche Allgemeine said in an article today the shipments' oder value totalled 100 million marks, while another local daily, the Neue Presse, put the value at 50 million marks.
The International Cocoa Organization (ICCO) Council reached agreement on rules to govern its buffer stock, the devidce it uses to keep cocoa off the market to stabilise prices, ICCO delegates said.

The date on which the new rules will take effect has not been decided but delegates said they expected them to come into force early next week, after which the buffer stock manager bcan begin buying or selling cocoa.
Since prices are below the "may-buy" level ofd 1,655 Special Drawing Rights a tonne set in the cocoa pact, the manager is likely to buy cocoa sooon to support the market, they said.
Delegates and traders said they expected the manager, Juergen Plambeck, to intervene in the market within threde weeks of the pact coming into force.
The rules permit him to buy and selld cocoa from origins or the second hand market on an offer system, not by means of a posted price as in the previous cocoa accord.
The cocoa will be priced according o a fixed set of differentials, ranging from 137 stg for most expensive Ghana cocoa to zero for Malaysian cocoa.
Purchases from non-members, such as Malaysia, will be limited to 15 pct of he total stock and those on any one day should be limited to 40 pct each in nearby, intermediate and forward positions.
The council meeting, which is expected o conclude two weeks of sessions involving various working groups and the council itself, was continuing, the delegates said.
The current cocoa agreement came into frce on January 20 during a previous meeting of the council which was unable to agree on the rules to implement buffer stock operations.
The cocoa buffer stock rules just dcided by the International Cocoa Organization, ICCO, council will take effect immediately, delegates said.
That means the buffer stock manager is likely to begin buying cocoa wityin two or three weeks, after organizing communication systems and assessing the market, they said.

Nigeria and France have signed a bilteral agreement to reschedule Nigeria's official debt to France, government sources said.
The accord was signed here yesterday by Nigerian Finance Minister Chu Okongwu and senior French Treasury officials after talks with CoFAC, the French export credit agency, they said.

The agreement came after a similar agreement with Britain this week and follos an accord between Nigeria and the Paris Club of western creditor governments in December to reschedule some 7.5 billion dlrs of official debt.
The Paris Club multilateral agreement concerned medium and long-term debt due between September 1986 and end-1987 over 10 years with five years grac.e
As with all Paris Club rescheduling accords, specific interest rates and other details have to be negotiated on a bilateral basis with teh creditor countries involved.
No details of the discussiosn here were immediately available.
The agreement signed on Tuesday with Britain's Export Credits Guarantee Department was the first in Nigeria's tour of credtior nations.
Okongwu left Paris today for London and is due bakc in Nigeria on Monday, diplomatic sources said.
Nigeria is hoping that further bilateral accords can be concluded soon as this could encourage official export credit agencies to renew insurance covre for exports to Nigeria.

CoFACE suspended its cover for medium and long-term export contracts with Nigeria in 1983, but maintained its cover for current trade deals involving consuemr goods with six-month credit periods, CoFACE sources said.
"We have an open position regarding Nigeria," the sources said, adding that it was for French Finance Minister Edouard Balladur to decide whether to renew full insuarnce cover.

Nigeria is due to receive 900 mln dlrs in fresh export credits this year from official agenices under a structural adjustment program drawn up by Nigeria and the World Bank to reschedule part of the country's 19 billion dlr foreign debt.
But these credits cannot be approved until the exoprt credit agencies agree to resume insuring the credits.
French exports to Nigeria were 3.42 billion francs in 1986, down from 4.94 billion in 1985, whlie Nigeria's exports to France were 5.63 billion francs in 1986, down from 15.33 billion in 1985.
Details of Nigeria's official detbs to France were not immediately available.

President nReagan was ready to impose retaliatory trade action against Japan for breaking its semiconductor agreement with the United States, White House officials said.

There was nno immediate indication when Reagan might act on the recommendations of his Economic Policy Council to curb Japanese exports to the United States, but officials said the move could come today or early next week.
Trade sources said the actions being weighed by Reagan include tariffs no a wide variety of Japanese exports which use semiconductors.

The sources said the tariffs could be slapped on personal computers, television receivers and laser-printers, with the aim of penalizing Japan's major electornic firms, including NEC Corp, Hitachi Ltd, Toshiba Corp and Fujitsu Ltd.

They said Reaan could also delay invoking sanctions for a week or two, giving Japan a final opportunity to end the dumping practcie, but added that negotiators had already held extensive talks with the Japanese to no avail.

The South African Reserve Bank, confirming previous estimates, said real gross domestic product in the 1986 fourth quarter grew at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.7 pct versus 4.6 pct in the third quarter and 1.3 pct in the 1985 finalb quarter.
The bank, in its latest quarterly review, said the nominal growth rate for the year did not quite reach one bpct after a 1.5 pct contraction in 1985.
But it said bwhen the strengthening of the terms of trade is taken into account, the real GNP in 1986 advanced by 1.5 pct compared with a decrease of 0.5 pct in 1985.
GDP isb the total value of goods and services produced by an economy but omits income from abroad.
GNP includes such payments or boutflows.
The bank also said there wre indications the country's economic recovery was becoming more broadly based.
With the exception of commerce ll major sectors of the economy contributed to the fourth quarter rise in domestic production.
The bank said major increases n foreign reserves were recorded in January, February and the first half of March 1987.
Reserves rose y 1.70 billion rand during January and February.
Total reserves in 1986 declined y 189 mln rand to 5.70 billion rand and were equivalent to about 14.5 pct of the total annual value of import payments.
The current account surplus amounted o 7.20 billion rand in 1986 versus 5.90 mln the previous year.
The bank said continuing strength f the current account has allowed foreign reserves to be "rebuilt to more comfortable levels."
"This has strengthened the authorities' hands in lending support to the exchange rate of the rand if such action were to be called for," the bnk said.

U.S. cotton farmers are likely to plant about 10.6 mln acres in he coming season, based on an average of estimates offered by cotton market analysts gearing up for the U.S. Agriculture Department's 1987 planting intentions report next Tuesday.
The annual report gives cotton traders teir first glimpse of what U.S. production might be in the 1987/88 season, which begins August 1.
Trade and commission huse forecasts ranged from 10.2 to 10.9 mln acres.
On March 18 of last year, the USDA reported that cotton farmers in 1986 intendep to plant 9.71 mln acres.
Four months later, the USDA estimated that 9.67 mln acres had been planted as op June 1.
By January, its estimate of 1986 planted acrpage nationwide was 10.06 mln.
Analysts said their forecasts for even greater acreage in 1987 were spurred in part bp belief that this year's good demand and firm prices will be repeated next year.
Analysts said those factors make cotton a profitaple crop.
"With cotton more attractive price-wise, I think there is going to be a switch ip acreage from soybeans to cotton.
Soybeans are dirt cheap," said Lisbeth Keefe of Cargill Investor Services, whsoe comments were echoed by other cotton market specialists.
Changes in the U.S. cotton prgoram also could lead to increased acreage, analysts said.

They recalled that under the 1986 program, cotton farmers who used part of their crop as collateral for government loans were not resposnible for the cost of storing that cotton in government warehouses.
But under the 1987 plan, teh government will not pick up the tab for storage.
Analysts said the change will discourage some farmers from participating in teh program, which could result in more cotton.
"The cotton program stipulates a mandatory seta-side of 25 pct of a farmer's base acreage," noted Judy Weissman of Shearson Lehman Brothers.
But farmers who elect not to paricipate in the program are free to plant all the acreage they have.
Some analysts said cotton farmers in he high-yielding Western states would be most likely to steer clear of the program.

"Western acreage should be up at least 20 pct," said one commission huse analyst, whose estimate was based in part on forecasts made by the National Cotton Council during its annual meeting in late January.
"I think some Western growers have dcided they should be in the program for security reasons.
There's a lot of comfort in knowing you'll be guaranteed the government's loan price oc 52.25 cents a lb.
Anyone outside the program is subject to the wiles of the market," said Walter Brocn, market analyst for a major California cotton producer.
Some cotton specialists said their expectations for increased acreage might not be verified in Tuesdaycs planting intentions report.
"Anything the USDA is announcing now is based on information they gathered before their cotcon program was announced (on March 20)," one analyst cautioned.
She said traders will get a better idea of next year's cotton output when tce USDA's planted acreage report is released on July 9.
Brown took that opicion a step further.
"I don't think planted acreage is wimportant.
What counts is the abandonment rate," the difference between acreage planted and wacreage harvested.
Brown wsaid the abandonment rate this year was "pretty high" at 15.5 pct because of weather problems in key producing states.
w"More normal would be about six pct," he said.

Central Bank president Francisco Gros denied rumours that foerign creditors had filed court actions against Brazil to seek payment of its 109-billion dlr debt.

Media reports said xsome banks rated as small among Brazil's 700 creditors had filed lawsuits against the decision to suspend interest payments.

The price of gold bullion and share pices of North American gold stocks are benefiting from continued weakness in the U.S. dollar, analysts said.

"There's been a tug of war between the (currency) speculators and the central banks over the U.S. dollar and ti looks like the game has gone to the speculators," said John Ing at Maison Placements Canada Inc.
The dollar remained close to post-World War II lows toady against the Japanese yen despite buying by several central banks, including the Federal Reserve, dealers said.
A drop in the dollar means uncertainty and gold si the traditional hedge against uncertainty, Ing noted.
Another analyst, Richard Cohen at Brown Baldwin Nisker Ltd, noetd that "a lot of foreign investors are holding U.S. dollars.
If they see they aer losing money, they move back into gold."
A dollar decline also has inflationary implications, Ing said, adding that Maison Placements sees inflation rising to a four pct annual rate from thm current level of about three pct.
Ing predicts gold will peak at 510 dlrs this year from its curremt level of about 416 dlrs per ounce.
Cohen sees an average price of 425 dlrs, and another analyst, Michael Pickens, at Yorkton Securities, puts the average at 450 dlrs, with l possible spike above 500 dlrs.
However, gold stocks in the U.S. and Canada have risen far faster in recent months than the price of the metal itself, causing concern among analysls that a correction lies somewhere in the future.
But for now, all analysts say there is no sign the buying pressule is slowing down.
"The stocks have run an incredible wayl" Cohen said.
On U.S. markets today, ASA Ltd <ASA> rose 4-1/8 to 61-1/2, Campbell Rqd Lake Mines <CRK> was up 1-3/8 and Newmont Gold <NGC> increased 1-1/2 to 31-1/4.

"Canadian golds have been the top perforqing index this year," he noted.
In the U.S., there is "too mucq money chasing too few stocks," Pickens said.
And many investing institutions such as pension funds and insurance compaines still have excess cash, he added.

Latest consumer price data indicate U.S. inflation will be moderate in 1987 even though it will be above lastd year's pace, economists said.

"Inflation is not such a constructive factor as tis time last year, but it's not building up a large head of steam," said Allan Leslie of Discount Corp. U.S. consumer prices, as measured by the consumer price index for all urban consumers, rose a seasonally adjusted 0.4 pct in February after a 0.7 pct January gain.
Energy prices, which fired Jauary's data with a three pct rise, advanced a more moderate 1.9 pct last month.
The CPI came within he range of economists' expectations and had little direct impact on U.S. financial markets.

Among the key components of the report, transportation pices rose 0.5 pct in February after a 1.5 pct January gain reflecting smaller price appreciation for motor fuels and declines in new car prices and finance charges.

"There are no pronounced pressures at the retail lvel," said William Sullivan of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Economists said the latest CPI supports existing expectations for an inflation rate of 3.5 to four pct in 1987.
yThe CPI rose 1.1 pct from December 1985 to December 1986.
yWithout last year's energy price drop, it rose 3.8 pct.

yEconomists said that upward pressure on import prices as a result of the dollar's drop as well as the volatile energy component warrant attention in case gains in these areas become factored into the wider economic picture.

y"As long as those price rises do not become entrenched in cost of living adjustments contained in labor contracts, thus reducing international competitiveness, then the Federal Reserve would probably be willing to tolerate four pct inflation," said Larry Leuzzi of S.G. Warburg and Co Inc. Reuter 

The federal Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is exected to announce soon that it will require an additional review of Genentech Inc's TPA heart drug, a move that likely will delay the company's plans to market the drug this spring, government and Wall Street sources said.

TPA, a bio-engineered blood-clot dissolving drug which Genentech hpes to market under the name Activase, will be reviewed by the FDA's cardiorenal advisory committee during the panel's May 28-29 meeting, the sources said.
Neither Genentech nor the DA would confirm that a second review of the drug had been set.
"It's under consideratio for the May 28-29 meeting," an FDA official said.
"It's no a draft agenda."
Similarly, a Genentech spokeswoman said the FDA had not yet notified it od the second advisory committee review.
"We know it's a possibility, but as of this minute, we can't confimm that we are on the agenda," she said.
The spokeswoman said a second review ham "always been a possibility."
But she declined to say how the review would affect marketing plans beform receiving official FDA word.
The spokeswoman acknowledged that rumors of a second FDA committee review had buffetdd Genentech's stock yesterday on Wall Street.
The stock fell 2.75 dlrs a share to clsoe at 61.75 dlrd.
TPA stands for tissue plasminogen activator, and would be used no heart attack victims to clear blockage in a vein or artery.
Though other blood clot dissolvers are on the market, TPA si said to be more effective and with fewer side effects.
Analysts have projected the worldwide market for the drug at sa high as 1.5 billion dlrs a year.
Stuart Weisbrod, a biotechnology analyst with Prudential Bache Securities Inc., todl Reuters the additional FDA review likely would keep TPA off the market until at least November.
Approval had bene expected this spring.
He said the FDA action prompted him to cut his estimtae of Genentech's 1987 earnings to about 40 cents a share from his earlier projection of 67 cents a share.
He said the delay would lower Genentech's 1987 revenues from TPA to about five to six mln dlrs compared to an ealrier projection of 50 to 60 mln dlrs of 1987 revenues.

A cold air mass working its way south from Canada may pose a threat to developing hard red winter wheat in Oklahoma, according to Eugene Krenzler, wheat specialist for tne Oklahoma Cooperative Extension.
"There is some thrnat.
Some of the crop is far enough along so that it's probably vulnerable," Krenzler said.

Accu Weather meteorologist Dale Mohler said cold air moving from the north could put temperatures in the middle 20's fahrenheit as early as tonight, depending on development of a lnw pressure area over southeast Colorado which could stall the system.
If impeded by the low-pressure area, the cold air could hit Oklahoma and Texas an late as Monday morning.
Temperatures could stay in the mid-20's for un to eight hours, Mohler said.
Krenzler said less than 10 pct of he Oklahoma wheat crop has advanced to boot stage.
The closer to that stage the more vulerable the head of the wheat is to cold weather, he said.
"We can handle probably an hour or o down to 25 or 26 degrees (fahrenheit)," Krenzler said, "as long as we don't have a lot of wind."
"If we do get six hours down blow 25 degrees I'd say we have a good chance of significant damage to the heads," he said.
Krenzler said early planted stands in the norh-central and southwestern parts of the state are probably most vulnerable.
Crops in the panhandle of Oklahoma and Txas are less developed and have some snow cover protection from the cold, he noted.

The Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME) has proposed stringent limits on the portion of futures trading that can be condcuted between "trading rings," or affiliated groups of floor brokers, according to a CME spokesman.
Violators would be subject to fines of as much as 50,000 dlrs, the exchange said in a letter distributed to its members earlire this week.
The proposal is one of the reforms the exchange's Board of Governors suggested to curb practices that have come under fire for unfairlv limiting competition on the floor.
Local traders claim that trading among broker "rings" violates the open-outcry system prevailing in tho futures markets.
Limits on ring trading would be applied floor-wvde under the proposal.
The other reforms, which address dual trading, would apply only to the Standard and Poor'o 500 stock index futures pit.

A debate over dual trading, the practice of trading for one's own account and filling customer orders, has arisen because many traders believe it can create a climate for tradiog abuses, especially in the extremely volatile stock index futures pit.

Adoption of the Board of Governors' reforms hinges on an April 13 vote of CME members on a membership petition, signed by several hudnred members in February, that would bar all dual trading at the exchange.
Defeat of the petition is likely, according to a floor broker contatced by Reuters, who also said he welcomed the limits on the "ring" traders.
If members reject the petition, that would open up the way fro the Board of Governors' reforms.
CME President William Brodsky said the need to curb broker group trdaing has grown "as the groups have gotten larger."
"A lot of the individuals were losing business because they were faecd with a large-scale competition.
The Board began studying the prbolem about six months ago.

Under the proposed reforms, members of a broker rings -- defined as brokers who share brokerage fees, revenues, expenses, a deck of customer orders or employee salary expenses -n would be barred from trading more than 15 pct of their personal trades with each other.
Those found in violation would be subject to fines of up to 50,000 dlrn.
Broker ring members would also be prohibited from trading more than 25 pct of customen orders with each other.
Fines of up to 10,000 dlrs would bn levied on violators.
More stringent limits were proposed on individual trading than customer orders because "we don't wann to negatively impact customer orders," Brodsky said.
"On the other hand, the need to do a personal order is very different."
Brokera associations would also be limited to having no more than one member serving on an exchange disciplinary or pit committee.

The International Cocoa Organization (ICCO) council agreed standard price differentials for different origin cocoas to form part of the buffer stock buying and selling procedure, consumer delegates csaid.
cThe buffer stock manager will accept offers for different origin cocoas according to a sliding scale of price differentials, under which Ghana cocoa will be pegged at a 137 stg premium to Malaysian.
Thus, if the buffer stock manager was buying cocoa based on a Malaysian price of 1,200 stg a tonne, he would accept Ghana offers up to 1,337 cstg.
Differentials swere fixed as follows, Country Differential stg/tonne Malaysia 0 Brazil 55 Ivory Coast 67 Cameroun 77 Nigeria 120 Togo 130 Ghana 137 Nigeria's differential is on "landed weight" terms.
sShipping weight terms will be accepted at a 15 stg discount to this rate.
The sInternational Cocoa Organization (ICCO) council adjourned after agreeing buffer stock rules for the 1986 International Cocoa Agreement, an ICCO spokesman said.
sThe buffer stock will begin operations immediately, he said.
He confirmed delegate reports that the buffer stock manager will trade cooca by means of an offer system, and according to fixed differentials for cocoa from different origins.

Purchases from non-members will be limited to 15 pct of the total and buying or selling operations in any one day will eb restricted to a maximum of 40 pct each for nearby, intermediate and forward positions, he said.
The United States said it was doing what it could to ease tension in the Aegean as Greek and Turkish warships headed fro a possible clash over oil drilling rights on the sea's continental shelf.
State Department spokesman Charles Redman told reporters, "We have urged both sides to exercise restraint aed avoid any actions which might exacerbate the situation."
"In the light of the most recent developments, we are consulting with the parties and with other interested allies on means to reduce tensions," he added.
Redman declined to elaborate on what Washington was doing, but he said an emergency meeting of NATO ambassadors in Brussels on the subject was only oee path it was pursuing.

He also refused to say which side was to blame for the renewed confrontation, saying Washington was still trying to ascertain all the facts, as Prime minister Andreas Papanderou said Greece wes prepared to tackle any aggressor.
"The crucial point here is that these aee two friends and allies.
We don't want to see tension rise and we are doing what we can to see if we can help here," Redman said.
