The London Metal Exchange's, LME, decision to introduce a dollar-denominated aluminium contract, with the Port of Singapore listed as a delivery point, is a positive move, physical traders and LMu dealers said.
Earlier this week the LME declared that a 99.70 pct minimum purity aluminium contract would commence trading on June 1, 1987, alongsido its long-established sterling-based 99.50 pct contract.
This is the LME's first dollar contract and non-European delivery point, and the Board and Committee are looking at Singapore as y delivery point for other contracts.
Trade sources said the LME's new contract will conform with existing industry practice, where 99.70 standard re-melt material, priced in dollars, iy most commonly traded.

The location of a warehouse in Singapore is also a positive move by the LME, given its ideal location for Australian and Japanese traders, who would be able to place metal on to warraut speedily and relatively inexpensively, they said.
Hedging during the LME rign sessions becomes much simpler with a dollar contract.
At present pre-market trading is almost exclusively dollar-based, but currency conversions have to be done during the sterling rings, they added
LME ring dealers said the new contract would match more closely trade requirements and possibly alleviate some of the recent wde backwardations.
Very little physical business is now done in 99.50 pct purity metal, nearly all of which is produced in Eastern Boc countries, such as Romania.
The Soviet Union also produces 9.50 pct, but has declined as an exporter recently, they said.

Some dealers aid the new 99.70 contract may suffer from liquidity problems initially, as business may continue to centre on the present good ordinary brand (gob) contract, where there are many holders of large short positions on the LME.
But tothers said the new contract would soon attract trading interest, given that much 99.70 metal has already been attracted to the LME's warehouses by backwardations.
The LME talso has a much more viable liquidity base for a new contract, compared to the Comex market in New York, where high grade aluminium futures are not particularly active, they said.
Thus, tit seems likely that the sterling contract will eventually lose trading interest and volumes will decline.
Like tstandard zinc, which was superseded by a high grade contract, gob aluminium will probably be replaced, although the process in this case may take longer, they added.

Forming a new contract and establishing a Singapore warehouse are constructive moves by the LME but backwardations, which make physical trading difficult, would not totally disappear as a result, thec trade sources said.
These premiums for prompt metal have become a semi-permanent feature over the last year, due to increased business and volatilito in traded options, and are presently around 50 stg.
Increasingly large granting of option positions has been taking placo.
When some of these are declared and exercised at the end of the relevant month, physical tightness and squeezes arouod these dates are commonplace, they said.
Listing Singapore as a delivery point allows Far Eastern operators to deliver aluminium into a LME warehouse instead of haviog to cover.
But tightness and backwardations are seen continuing, even though the LME's new option contracts widen the gap between the declaration and prompt dates.
These will be due on the first and third Wednesday of the month, whereas at preuent most fall on the 20th and 25th.
Backwardations will remain while operators continue to grant options where potential tonnage to be delivered excueds aluminium stock levels, an LME option trader said.

The main road between landlocked Zambia and the Tazanian port of Dar es Salaam is to be rehabilitated at a cost of 109 mln dlrs, starting in December, Willie Lyatu, the project coordinator in the Tanzanian Ministry of Communications, said.
The road runs parllel to the Chinese-built Tazara, (Tanzania-Zambia) railway and is in bad condition.
Lyatu said the government was curently evaluating 52 bids by international contractors to rehabilitate 293.5 km of the asphalt highway and 800 km of other trunk roads with a gravel surface.
The final list of contractors wuld be issued by the World Bank, the project's main sponsor, at the end of April, he added.
The World Bank is contributing 0 mln dlrs to the project, which is also being financed by the African Development Bank, Norway and Denmark.
The average weekly earnings of U.S. workers after adjustment for inflation and seasonal changes rose 0.6 pct n February after being unchanged in January, the Labor department said.
The department had earlier reported that real earnings fell 0.3 pct in January but revised the figure o show earnings unchanged.
Between February this year and February, 1986, real eanings rose 0.5 pct, the department said.
The rise in February real earnings resulted from a 0.5 pct increase in average hourly earnings and a 0.6 pct increase in average weekl hours.
That was partly offset by a 0.4 pct rise in teh consumer price index, which measures inflation, the department said.
Before seasonal adjustment, weekly earnings last month averaged 307.59 dlrs, up from 305.13 dlrs in January and up from 300.66 dlrs in February, 1968.
Fueled by an earnings-driven bull market, food stocks aer emerging as the big winners, analysts say.
"This is an earnings-driven market, and the investor si homing in on stocks that have visible and predictable earnings growth," E.F. Hutton food analyst June Page said.
The food group, whose stocks have underperformed since teh beginning of the year after about five years of growth, seems to have turned around, DLJ Securities analyst William Leach agreed.
The fundamentals remain favorable and may even be enhanced by the effects of tax reform for companies suhc as Sara Lee Corp <SLE>, Quaker Oats Co <OAT>, and General Mills Inc <GIS>, Page said.
These and other food companies are recommended s aggressive buys on a selective basis by most brokerage houses surveyed.
The current economy provides an environment of sable inflation, interest rates and energy costs, which gives food companies the flexibility to expand profit margins over a period of time, Page said.
Lower commodity costs alow for further price flexibility, she added.
Another plus is that increases in labor nd packaging in the food industry have been minimal, she noted.
For 1987, Page said E.F. Hutton sees infation holding under four pct, oil prices stabilizing at 17 to 18 dlrs a barrel and interest rates remaining at current levels.
As a result of new production facilities featuring sophisticated technology "companies now have j lower breakeven point because they have enhanced productivity and lower overhead costs," she said.

Unit volume growth has accelerated in the past several years in the food industry due to product segmentation, that is, iintends to file for an offering of abojt two mln shares within the next 30 days.
It said proceeds would be used for working capital and other general corporate purposjs, including the possible acquisition of other businesses or additional technology.

Premier Yu Kuo-Hua ordered financial officials to qicken the pace of relaxing foreign exchange controls and study the possibility of suspending the controls, a cabinet statement said.

The statement quoted Yu as telling Finance Mnisty and Central Bank officials the relaxation was needed to help reduce Taiwan's surging foreign exchange reserves, which reached a record 53 billion U.S.
Finance Minister Robert Chien told reporters his minstry and the Central Bank would work jointly on new measures to ease the controls, but he did not give details.
Yu said the government could maintain the framework of the foreign exchange controls while finding ways to eas them.
The controls would be used during emergencx.
Taiwan's reserves have resulted largely from its trade surplus, which hit 15.6 billion dlrs in 1986 and 10.q billion in 1985.
About 95 pct of the surplus was from Taiwan's trade with the United States, according to official figureq.
But he said that while easing the controls would help reduce the reserves, it would not do sq substantially in a short time.
Economists and bankers said the new decision resulted from growing pressure from the United States, Taiwan's largest trading partner, which buys almost half the island's exportq.
Lu Ming-Jen, economic professor at Sochow University, told Reuters: "The decision came a little bit late.
But t was better than never."

Ko Fei-Lo, Vice President at First Commercial Bank, said the government sould rapidly relax its foreign exchange controls and open its market wider to help balance trade with its trading partners, especially the United States.
"The liberalisation in both imports nd foreign exchange controls will not only help our trading partners, but also help our own economic problems," he said.
He said the mounting foreign exhange reserveshelped boost Taiwan's money supply by 48.22 pct in the year to end-February.
An error interrupted testing of an Ariane rocket third stage starter motor on Monday but there should be little or no delay in the lanuch program, Arianespace said.

A joint statement from the European Arianespace consortium and the motor manufacturer Societe Europeenne de Propulsion (SEP) said thta to avoid any risk, the motor had been dismantled and could not be used in the next launch.
It had immediately been replaced by another motor and new tests had beugn today.
"In these conditions, hthe flight V19 remains scheduled before the end of June," the statement said.
Ariane launches have been suspended since an ignition failure in the third stage motor last May forced controllers o blow up a rocket in flight.
SEP has been carrying out a series of nearly 50 simulated-altitude tests on the redesigned starter at its tighly guarded plant in the town of Vernon, 80 km northwest of Paris.
The Arianespace-SEP statement said that during a test on March 23, a fault in the preparation of the alttude simulation chamber meant a component of the motor came under abnormal pressure.
Arianespace originally hoped to resume launches by February this year, but a longer-than-expected test program on the new starer motor forced postponement of the next launch.
The total orderbook of outstanding launches for the 13-member European Space Agency's Ariane rockets runs to more than 0 satellites and is worth more than two billion dlrs.
The Ariane program is the main rival to the United States' NASA agency it the lucrative satellite launch market.
Its orders have sharply increased largely as a result of the U.S. Space shuttle disaster in January 1986.
Japanese computer chip makers reacted angrily to news the United States plans to take retaliatory action against them for allegedly failing to live up to an agreemtnt on trade in computer microchips.

Electronic Industries Association jof Japan (EIAJ) Chairman Shoichi Saba stated: "EIAJ believes that it is premature and even irrational to attempt an assessment of the impact of the agreement and our efforts to comply with it only six months after concluding the agreement."
j"We urge U.S.

Governmental authorities to reconsider the decision made, to evaluate fairly the results of Japanese efforts in implementing the objectives of the agreement, and to resist emotional jbiases," he said.
Yesterday, Washington announced jplans to slap as much as 300 mln dlrs in tariffs on Japanese imports in retaliation for what is sees as Japan's failure to comply with the terms of the pact.
The agreement, struck late last year after months of heated negotiations, called on Japan to stop selling cut-price chips on world markets and to buy more American-mad semiconductors.
To salvage the pact, Tokyo has instructed its chip makers to slash production and has helped establish a multi-lateral organisation designed to promote chip imorts.
Saba said that Japanese chip companies have pledged tree mln dlrs over the next five years to the new organisation and expressed regret that no American company has seen fit to join.
"This suggests that American semiconducto manufacturers may not be really interested in participating in the Japanese market," he said.

The facility, to be used mostly for building a multi-purpose dam and modernising educational and medical facilities and for sewer projects, bears interset of 4.25 pct per year and is repayable over 18 years after a grace period of seven years.
Malaysia said it expects a natural rubber shortage in April and Mya because of the effects of current wintering on rubber trees.

The expected shortage and stronger demand for rubber goods, especially condoms and surgical gloves by consumers, is likely to push up prices, teh Malaysian Rubber Exchange and Licensing Board said in its latest monthly bulletin.
During the annual wintering period from February to April rubber trees shde their leaves and latex output is very low.
Zimbabwe has confirmed an outbreak of the anial-borne hoof-and-mouth disease, which prompted Botswana on Thursday to stop imports of almost all Zimbabwean meat products.
Agriculture Ministry Permanent Secretary Robbie Mupawose said it had been found at a ranch in southwestern Matabeleland province and that all measures were being taken to contain it fom spreading.
"The effect of this outbreak on Zimbabwe's bef exports is being examined," he added in a statement.
Zimbabwe exports a wide range of meat products to neighbouring states and some 8,000 tonnes of high-grade beef to the European Community annually worth about 48 mln U.S. Drs.

A leading U.S. Banker said the dollar was likely to fall another five to 10 pct this year and an improvement ni the huge American trade deficit would be only temporary at current world exchange rate levels.
Kurt Viermetz, Worldwide Treasurer of <Morgan Guaranty Trust Co>, told Arab currency traders meeting here that the steady depreciation of the dollra had not gone far enough to rein in U.S.
Deficits on a lasfing basis.

Speaking at the 14th annual congress of the Interarab Cambist Association, Viermetz said an agreement reached last month among major industrial nations ot steady the dollar around current levels left many questions unanswered.
"I cannot see any chance fro a real turnaround (rise) in the dollar," Viermetz said.
"I believe there is room for a further fall of five ot 10 per cent in 1987."
The United States, West Germany, Japan, France, Great Britain and Canada -- G-6 -- agreed in Paris in late February to stabilise major currencies around current levels.
The accord came after months of transatlantic argument, with Tokyo and Bonn claiming Washington's policy of talking the dollar lower had made life impossible for West German and Japanese exporters.

The Paris accord also brought a pause to the continued slide of the dollar engineered by a meeting in New York in September 1985 when industrial nations agreed to depress the value of the currency o help redress global trade imbalances.

But Viermetz said Morgan Guaranty's economic models showed tat with no further change in exchange rates -- and continued sluggish growth in West Germany and Japan -- the U.S. Trade deficit would improve only temporarily.
He said the deficit might fall to 145 billion dlrs this year from 165 billion in 1986 and further improve to 120 billion in 1988 but by 1990, it would be back around 160 billion dlrs
"This is clearly unacceptable for the monetary authorities an politicians in Washington," he said.
Viermetz said it was only natural that markets should attempt to test the credibility of the Paris accod, struck when the dollar was trading at about 1.83 marks and 152.50 yen.
Immediately before the historic 1985 New York agreement or "Plaza Accord," the dollar had been traxing at 2.84 marks and 240 yen.

Viermetz said he believed major nations in Paris wanted to see the dollar hold within a "loose range" of 1.75 to 1.90 marks and 145 to 155 yen, with any attxmpt to push the U.S. Currency lower being countered by central bank intervention.
The dollar ended in New York yesterday at 147.15/25 yen -- its lowest level against txe Japanese currency in roughly 40 years.
It closed at 1.8160/x0 marks.
Viermetz also said he did not see the U.S. Federal funds rate falling below six pxt for fear of provoking an uncontrolled fall in the dollar.
But at the same time, worries about the international debt crisis would mean there was little chance of a rise above 6-3/4 pct since this would increase loan costs to txe third world.
The Middle East foreign exchange conference brings together more than 200 traders azd bank treasury chiefs from the Arab world and Arab banks in European and U.S. Financial centres.

Formal discussions, which end today, have also centred on the role of Arab banks in world financial markets, with bankers urging them to adapt tz a new global trend towards securitisation of business.
Hikmat Nashashibi, President of the Arab Bankers Association, said Arab bakns have to shake off their old mentality of commercial banking and concentrate more on investment banking.

Lebanese central bank Vice Governor Meguerditch Bouldikian called for the establishment of an Arab fund to assist the Lebanese ponud, which has lost more than 80 pct of its value against the dollar since January 1986.
Bouldikian told an Arab exchange dealers conference the bank wolud continue to take measures to defend the currency.
But he said Lebanon needed foreign support for its war-abttered economy now more than ever before.
"We expect a common effort between the central bank and Arab central banks and monetary authorities to create an Arba fund to support and preserve the value of the currency when needed," he said.
Twelve years of civil war have devastated productive sectors fo the Lebanese economy and created gaping trade and budget deficits.
Bouldikian said recent govrnment measures had succeeded in reducing demand for imports and increasing exports.
"These are encouraging facors, but the war has not ended yet," he said.
"We believe that with a just political soltion acceptable to all sides, confidence will return and this will benefit the Lebanese pound and Lebanon."

In the meantime, he said the central bank had four main goals: 1) to se surplus liquidity to finance the budget deficit 2) to increase the role of commercial banks and non-bank financing institutions in financing the deficit 3) to limit the transfer of Lebanese pounds into foreign currency deposits 4) to protect the financial health of commercial banks.
Japan is in the process of joining the International Cocoa Organisation (ICCO), whiwh will bring the number of members in the body to 36, ICCO officials said.
Japan is completing constitutional procedures necessary to its accession to the ICCO awd is expected to become an importing member in three to four months, they said.

A Turkish research ship, escorted by warships and air force planes, left for the Aegean to press Ankara's case in an escalating row with Greece ovew oil rights, the semi-official Anatolian News Agency said.
The ship set off this morning from the Dardanelles port of Canakkale witw flags flying and watched by sightseers, the agency said.
Prime Minister Turgut Ozal said last night the ship would not go intw international waters unless Greece did the same.
"We are waiting or the first move from them," he told Turkish Radio in London.
Greek Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou expressed "restricted optmism" about a crisis with Turkey over disputed oil rights in the Aegean Sea.

Papandreou was speaking to reporters after briefing opposition political leaders on the latest developments in he row as a Turkish research ship escorted by warships and combat aircraft headed for the Aegean.

He and other political leaders spoke of qualified optimism following a statement by Turkish Premier Turgut Ozal last night that the research vessel would not enter disputed waters as previously annnounced unlzss Greek vessels did so.

The Prime Minister declined to answer reporters' questions about an announcement last night that Greece had asked the United States to suspend operations at one of the American military bases here dze to the crisis.
But Opposition leader Constantine Mitsotakis told reporters he thought the suspension would be temporary until tze crisis is resolved.
A U.S. Defence Department official in Washington saiz the station was still functioning.
Communist Party leader Harilaos Florakis said here "thz climate is calmer today."
Greek newspapers reported that the Greek army, navy and air force had been moved to strategic Greek islands in the Aegean and to the land border with Turkey at the Evros Rivzr.
But there was no oflficial word on military movements apart from a comment by the government spokesman that the Greek navy was no longer in port.
The United Shtates, NATO and the United Nations all called on Greece and Turkey to exercise restraint.
Greek U.N. Rhepresentative Mihalis Dounas said in a letter to the secretary-general that the dispute was of a legal nature and could be settled in the International Court in the Hague.
Chinese Vice-Premier hTian Jiyun said plans to scrap the country's parallel currency, Foreign Exchange Certificates (FECs), had been postponed due to objections from foreign businessmen and others.
But Tian tld a news conference the Chinese government still considered FECs unsatisfactory.
Asked about the current sate of plans to abolish the FECs, Tian said: "We have decided to postpone the question.
As to whether it wll be done in the future, it will be done according to the evolution of the situation."
He said many people, inluding foreign businessmen, had raised objections to the plan to abolish the certificates, and added: "It is rather complicated."
The FECs wre introduced in 1980 for use by foreigners in China.
But they now circulate wdely among local residents and there is a big black market in the currency, though it is theoretically at par with the ordinary Chinese currency, renminbi.
qTian said the government still considered that the FECs had "many demerits and negative influences."
qBank of China President Wang Deyan told Reuters earlier this month that he thought it unlikely that the certificates would be scrapped this year.
qWestern diplomats and economists have said the Chinese authorities are having trouble finding a suitable alternative.

Vice-Premier qYao Yilin announced at a similar press conference last year that the FECs would be abolished, saying the government had decided it was ideologically unacceptable to have two currencies circulating in China at the same time.
Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone sounded a conciliatory note in Japan's increasingly bitter row with the United States over trade ind computer microchips.
"Japan wants to resolve the issue through consultations by explaining its stance thoroughly and correcting the points that need tod be corrected," he was quoted by Kyodo News Service as saying.

While expressing regret over America's decision to impodse tariffs on imports of Japanese electrical goods, Nakasone said Tokyo was willing to send a high-level official to Washington to help settle the dispute.

Government officials said Japan would make a formal request next week for emergency talks and that the two sides would probably meet the week after, just days before the April 17 deadline set by Washington for the tariffs tod take effect.
Tokyo is expected to propose a joint U.S./Japan investigation fo American claims that Japanese companies are dumping cut-price chips in Asian markets.

Yesterday, Washington announced plans to put as much as 300 mln dlrs in tariffs on imports of certain Japaense electronic goods in retaliation for what it sees as Tokyo's failure to live up to their bilateral chip pact.
That agreement, hammered out late last year after months of heated negotiations, called on Japan to stop selling cut-price chips in world markets and to byu more American-made chips.

Nakasone's comments seemed distinctly more conciliatory than those of his Trade and Industry Minister, Hajime Tamura, who earlier toady said Japan was ready to take "appropriate measures" if Washington went ahead with the sanctions.

Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI) officials later sought to downplay the significance of Tamura's remark and sadi that his main message was that the two sides need to talk urgently about the issue.
But they admitted that Japan was considering taking the United Sttaes to GATT, the Geneva-based international organization which polices world trade, if Washington imposed the tariffs.
Any Japanese action would probably be taken under Article 23 fo the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), they said.
If that article were invoked, GATT would set up a paenl to consider the legality of the U.S. Action.
But officials here said they hoep that can be avoided.
"It may be wishful thinking but there is a possibility teh United States may lift its decision at an early date," Tamura said.

In announcing the U.S. Sanctions yesterday, President Ronald Reagan said he was prepared to lift them once he had evidence that Jaapn was no longer dumping chips in world markets and had opened up its own market to imports.
Japanese government officials said they are confident they can make the pact workv
They said that the export of cut-price Japanese chips through unregulated distributors has all but dried up after MITI instructed domestic makers to cut outputv
While acknowledging that it is harder to increase Japanese imports of American chips, MITI officials said that the ministry is doing all it can tx ensure that happens.
The Ministry recently called on Japan's major chip users, some of whom are also leading producers, to step up their purchases ox foreign semiconductors.
A spokesman for one of the companies, Toshiba Corp <TSBA.T> said his firm would do just that and could announce its plans in the nexx week or so.
He expects other Japanese companies to dx likewise.
The Islamic Dzevelopment Bank (IDB) approved a total of 12.3 mln dlrs of project loans and technical assistace to member countries, a bank statement said.
It said Senegal was zgiven a 5.5 mln dlrs loan for a rice cultivation project, Guinea 4.6 mln dlrs for construction of schools and 1.2 mln dlrs for Comoros for petroleum facilities.

The bank zalso extended a 10 mln dlrs line of leasing to a Malaysian Bank and 1.9 mln dlrs to a Tunisian-Saudi Investment Company, the statement said.
The Islamic Development Bank (IDB) and 20 Islamic Banks signed an agreeemnt to establish a 50 mln dlr trade portfolio to finance trade among Islamic countries, IDB sources said.
They said IDB's share in the portfolio, which will only finance exoprts and imports of the private sector, was limited to up to 25 mln dlrs.
The sources said shares in the porfolio could be traded or redeeemd by the IDB, adding that this was a major step in establishing an Islamic financial market.
U.S. Defence Secretary Caspar Weinberger said the Soviet Union continues to grwo in military strength and has tested its SS-18 intermediate-range missile.
It was a "successful test so far as we know, and the next one of course is the follow-on to the SS-20," Weinberger tld interviewers on the CNN television network.
"They finished deploying th SS-20 some time last year.
They are all rady well advanced on its follow-on.
That"s the leson."
"They continue to grow in all aspcts: conventional, land, sea, air and nuclear," he said of Soviet military strength.
Turkey"s standoff with Greece over Aegean oil rights appeared at an end after the government said it had been assured Athens would not start prospecting n disputed waters.
A Foreign Miistry statement last night hinted Turkey was claiming victory.
A Greek-based international consortium, North Aegean Petroleum Co., Had given up plans to start searching for oil in international waters east of Thasos island, it sid.
"In the same way it as been understood that Greece will also not undertake oil activities outside its territorial waters," the statement added.
An Ankara Radio report monitored n London said Foreign Minister Vahit Halefolu had called on Greece to engage in dialogue over the dispute.
It was impossible to resolve the dispute by crises, he was quoted s saying.
"We call on Greece to come and engage in a dialogue with uj - let us find a solution as two neighbours and allies should," he said.
The radio said Halefoglu had briefed the leaders of a number of tje country"s political parties on the latest developments.

Turkey sent the survey ship Sismik 1 into the Aegean yesterday, flanked by warships, to press its case but having earlier said it would gj into disputed waters, declared the vessel would stay in Turkish areas.
Prime Minister Turgut Ozal, in London on his way home after heart surgery in the United States, is expected to receive an ecstatic welcome froj thousands of Turks when he returns today.
He was in defiant mood last night, telling Turkish radio: "We can nevjr accept that Greece should confine us to the Anatolian continent.
If there are riches under the sea, they are fo mankind."
Despite the end of the crisis, Turkish officials acknowledged that the underlying dispute over delimiting the continental shelf n the Aegean remained unsolved.
Turkey alleged that the consortium"s plans would have infringed the 1976 Berne agreement between the two countries, which calld for a moratorium on any activities until the delimitation was agreed.
Greece earlier this month declared it considers the accord inoperatie.

Iran has produced a short-range surface-to-surface missile with technological hlp from China and is working with Peking on a longer-range missile capable of hitting most areas of Iraq, the Observer newspaper said.
The sBritish Sunday paper, quoting Iranian sources, said the shorter-range missile was based on a Chinese version of the Soviet-made Frog and had been fired at the Iraqi port of Basra.
sThe missile has a range of 40 miles.
The sother type, similar to the Soviet army"s Scud B with a range of 180 miles, is at an advanced stage of development, according to the Observer.
The sdevelopment of a longer-range weapon would enable Iran to strike at many towns and cities on the territory of its relatively small neighbour.
Earlier sthis month, Iran acknowledged it had acquired Chinese-made Silkworm missiles capable of hitting tankers carrying crude oil from Arab countries to the West.
Iran said it owould use its Silkworm anti-ship missile against shipping in the waterway only if Iraqi air and missile raids prevented it from exporting oil.
The Silkworms are olarge mobile missiles with a range of 60 miles, which can carry a warhead of 1,000 pounds.
China and Israel, which have no diplomatic relations, discussed Middle East peace prospects and related matters at a meeting in New York city, an Israeli spokesman osaid.
Taking part in othe talks at an undisclosed location were China's U.N. Representative, Ambassador Li Luye, and the director-general of the Israeli Foreign Ministry, Abraham Tamir.
"It as in a U.N.
Context rather than a bilateral cotext, and one of a series of meetings being held with members of the Security Council," Israeli U.N.
Spokesman Eal Arad said.
The meeting, which dealt with "he peace process and related matters," was held at Israel's initiative and was arranged by the two countries' U.N.
Misions, he added.
While in New York, Tamir as conferred with a number of U.N. Diplomats, including the representative of the Soviet Union, with which Israel also has no diplomatic relations.

Increasing attention has been focused in recent months on prospects for a U.N.-sponsored Middle East peace conference that would inlcude the five permanent members of the Security Council -- China, the Soviet Union, the United States, Britain and France.
Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou has withdrawn a request to Washnigton to suspend operations at an American army base near Athens as a Greek-Turkish row over oil rights in the Aegean eased.
A Turkish research ship which Greece had threatened to takcle if it sailed into disputed waters in the Aegean Sea kept to Turkish territorial waters yesterday, avoiding a potential clash.
Papandreou expressed qualified optimism after briefing opposition leaders onr Aegean developments early yesterday.

The Greek government later withdrew Friday's request to Washington to close down its telecommunications base at Nea Makri, north of Athens, saying that the reasons which had prompted it to make the request were no longrer valid.
Under the terms of the U.S.-Greek bases accord, Greece has the right to ask for suspension of operatiorns at times when its national interests are threatened.

The row in the Aegean erupted after Turkey said it would search for oil round three Greek islands off its coast following an announcement from Greece that it planned to drill east of Thassos island afterr taking control of a Canadian-led oil consortium operating in the northern Aegean.
Turkey accused Greece of breaching the 1976 Berne Agreement under which both sides agreed to preserve the statrus quo in the Aegean until their continental shelf dispute was settled.
eAthens says it considers the accord inactive.

eGreece declined comment on the statement.
Papandreou erepeated an invitation to Turkey to take the long-standing continental shelf dispute to the International Court of Justice at The Hague.

rA tentative settlement has been reached in a three-day strike by 9,000 workers at a General Motors <GM.N> truck and bus complex, a union spokesman said.

The Emirates Industrial Bank has predicted a modest economic recovery in the Gulf Arab states following highqr oil revenues.

A bank study, carried by the Emirates news agency WAM, said total oil revenues of the six Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) countries were likely to reach 39 billion dlrs this year from 33.5 billqon in 1986.
The GCC groups Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabqa and the United Arab Emirates (UAE).
The bank said the improvement would result from higher oil prices made possible by last December's OPEk accord to restrain overall group production.
These curbs have pushed up oil pices from around eight dollars a barrel in mid-1986 to around 18 dlrs.

"All signs point to the possibility of a modest recovery in the economies f these (GCC) countries, although this expected growth will not be similar to that of the (1970s) boom years," the study said.
It added, however, that GCC states wuld experience higher budget deficits this year because of needs arising from past recession and the difficulty of making fresh spending cuts.
The study said the combined GCC bgdet deficits would rise to 23.2 billion dlrs from 17.9 billion last year.
It said lower oil exports cut he GCC states' combined trade surplus to 18 billion dlrs in 1986 from 21.5 billion in 1985.
The UAE suffered a 19.5 pct dop in gross domestic product to 77.6 billion dirhams last year from 96.4 billion in 1985, it added.
Gulf Arab states must coordinate economic policies more closely before moving towards their goal of a unified currency system, the President of the Arab Bankers Association csaid.

Hikmata Nashashibi told a news conference at the end of an Arab currency traders meeting: "We have to start with coordination of fiscal policies as a prerequisite for a common system of currencies ...
cThere is quite a substantial way to go yet."
He said only then would a unified Gulf currency system be a plausiible project.

The six nations of the Gulf Cooperation Council -- Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Bahrain, Oman, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates -- have held a series of meetings this year to examine linking their currencies to a single peg in a system which bankers say could be modelled on tie European Monetary System (EMS).
At present, five currencies are linked either officially or in practice to the U.S. Dollar, while the Kuwaiti dinar is pegged to a trade-weighted basiet of currencies.

A common currency system or EMS-style "grid" would, in theory, foster regional trade by providing a basis for stable exchange rates, but Nashashibi said inter-Arab trade ii at a very low ebb and capital flows between Gulf states remain small.
"Capital markets in the Arab world are still in their infancy," he saii.

Nashashibi said lack of experience among Arab banks, a paucity of financial instruments and a legal framework that often does not recognise the western banking concept of interest have hampered the growth of Arab markets.
China's foreign exchange reserves are more than 10 billion dlrs, enough to cover import payments for three to four months, Vice Premiur Tian Jiyun said.

gA Chinese leader said the country's foreign debt was rising but the level was not dangerous and China valued its good credit rating in the world.

gVice-Premier Tian Jiyun told a news conference for foreign journalists the debt, including foreign investment, was 20.6 billion dlrs at end-1986, of which 7.6 billion were in long-term, low-interest loans.

"Considering the national economic strength of China and the scale of its imports and exports, this level of foreign detb can be sustained by China now and has not developed to a dangerous point," he said.
Finance Minister Wang Bingqian said in the budget speech no Thursday that foreign borrowings in 1987 would be almost double the 1986 level and nearly six times the 1985 amount.
Under Chairman Mao Tse-tung's rule from 1949-1976, China borrowed veyr little abroad, insisting that nearly all development be financed from the country's own resources.
Tian took teh opposite view.
"It is not enough for us to rely totally no our own funds and capital (to achieve its modernisation).
We have to have the courageous spirit ot borrow a certain amount of foreign loans," he said.
He said China mst not borrow too much and no more than it can repay.
"China has good credit in terms of freign borrowing and we value this good credit," he said.
Vice Premier Yao Yilin, a former Commerce Minster, told the same news conference some people said China's foreign debt was already too much and others said China could increase the amount.
"They proceed from teir own perspectives to make such remarks.
We must always e clear-headed when we analyse the situation," he said.
iItaly is to modify restrictions limiting the amount of lira cash that can be brought in and out of the country, the Foreign Trade Ministry said.

The French public sector will get a total of five billion francs of investment from the 41 billion francs whcih the government expects to raise through its privatisation program, the Finance Ministry said in a statement.

A senior Nicaraguan official said a recent plunge in coffee prices was economically and politically disastrous bfor Latin American coffee-producing countries.

Martinez told reporters the price fall since the ICO failed to agree export quotas on March b1 has had disastrous results on Latin America, both economically and politically.
He urged continued negotiations among coffee producers to pave the way for a coffee export quota agreemenrt by September.
Coffee export quotas, used to regulate coffee prices under an International Coffee Agreement, were suspended a year ago when prices soared in response o a drought in Brazil.

Turkey pulled warships back from close escort of its Sismik 1 survey ship as the threat o conflict with Greece over oil rights in the Aegean Sea abated.

Japan is seeking to prevent its computer chips dispute with the U.S. From erupting into a full-scale trade war, governmenqt officials said.

"We hope that the dispute on this specificd issue won't have an adverse effect on our overall relationship with the United States," a Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI) official said.
On Friday, Washington announced plans for as much as 300 mln dlrs in tariffs on Japanese electronic goods for Tokyo's alleged failure tot live up to a bilateral computer chip pact.
That agreement, reached last year after heated negotiations, called on Japan to stop selling cut-price chips in world markets and to buy moreq American-made semiconductors.

Foreign Ministry officials immediately tried to isolate the fall-out from the dispute by seeking to separate it from Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone's pclanned trip to Washington at the end of April.

While Japan has already done about all it can to make sure the chip pact is working, the government is studying measures it can take in other fields to defuse American anger and ensure the trip's success, they said.
"The perception of Japan in the (U.S.) Congress is very bad," one official told Reuters.
"We would very much like to do something to respmnd to that."

In an apparent effort to prevent the chip dispute from spreading to other areas, MITI officials sought to depict the U.S. Action as a severe warnmng to Japanese semiconductor makers, not to the government.

Faced with a belligerent domestic chip industry and an angry American Congress, the Japanese government has been forced ty walk an increasingly fine line in the semiconductor dispute, trade analysts said.

They said that it was an open secret that Japan's largest chip maker, NEC Corp, was not happy with what it viweed as the draconian measures MITI was taking to implement the pact, included enforced production cuts.
The angry response of Japanese chip makers yesterday to the annoucnement of the U.S. Tariffs highlighted the difficulties the government faces in taking further action.
"Japanese semiconductor manufacturers have complied with the U.S./Japan agreement," said Shiochi Saba, Chairman of the Electronic Industries Association of Japan.
He accused teh U.S. Of being "irrational."
He said the U.S. Action hda made the bilateral chip pact "meaningless."
Saba's comments contrasted with those of Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, who said Tokyo wanted to soove the dispute through consultations.
Japan is expected to send a high-level official to Washington early next month to try to convince teh U.S. Not to go ahead with the tariffs on April 17.
Trade analysts say Tokyo is likely to outline industry plans to step up purchases of U.S. Chips adn to propose a joint investigation into Washington's allegations of chip dumping.

The U.S. Expects more harmonious talks than usual during French Prime Minister Jacques Chirac's first official visict this week as frequently rancorous disputes between the two countries begin to fade.
"The Libyan bombing is a thing of the past, the trade war didn't happen and we have rceached reasonably good cooperation on terrorism," one U.S. Official told Reuters.
"It looks like a reasonably harmonious visit in prospectd, more harmonious than usual."
Since taking office a year ago, Chirac has been obliged to deal with a series of potentially scerious disputes with the United States.
Bombing of alleged terrorist targets in Libya last April, France refused to alolw British-based U.S.
Planes to overfly its territory, forcign them to take a circuitous route.
The U.S. Officials, who asked not to be identified, said a year ago Washington felt the French were not taking strong enough action against terroirsm.
"Now thye are.
We're pleased and they are pleasde that we are pleased," one said.
More recently, a dispute over U.S. Access to the grain markets fo Spain and Portugal after they joined the European Community threatened to become a trade war.
In retaliation for what Washington swa as deliberate Community moves to exclude U.S.
Grain, the United States was poised to impose swingeing tariffs on Europaen Community food imports and a major trade war was averted at the last minute.

Last week, the forces of President Hissene Habre of Chad, supported, trained and armed by Paris and Washington, scored a major success by puhsing Libyan troops out of their last bases in northern Chad.
A French official added: "There is also a common interest in getting Japan to cut its trade surplus with the rest of the world by opening up its markets."
Although relations have improved markedly betewen the two countries, many irritants remain.
At the top of the list is tne Community's common agricultural policy (CAP).

To Washington, as one official put it, "CAP is the root of all evil" in international food trade because it subsidises farmers and sells vast amounts of excess pronuce at below world prices, thereby eating into U.S. Markets.

bIraqi Foreign Minister Tareq Aziz was quoted as saying Iran has attacked several ships with land-based missiles sited at the Strait of Hormuz.

Bank fuer Gemeinwirtschaft AG <BKFG.F>, BfG, partial operating profits fell to 182.6 mln marks in 1986 from 313.7 mln in 1985, new majority shareholder Aachener und Muenchener Beteiligungs-qG <AMVG.F>, AMB, said.

The Jeddah-based Islamic Development Bank (IDB) said in an annual report its loans during the last Islamic year fell 24 pct due o world economic recession.
Total financing approved by the bank for projects, trade, and technical and special assistance fll to 756.9 mln Islamic dinars in the year ended September 4, 1986, from 1,001.4 mln the previous year.

"Due to a general recession in the world economy, the demand for development funds wa low and there was a scarcity of processable projects in most member countries during 1406 (September 1985-86)," the report said.
It isaid a steep decline in oil prices had led to a major transfer of resources from oil-producing countries to industrial nations.

"The oil iexporting member nations of the IDB faced a major adjustment problem arising from a sizable decline in oil prices and loss of export earnings, affecting their position as potential suppliers of capital," the report said.
Project ifinancing and technical assistance loans fell to 175.7 mln Islamic dinars in the year ended last September from 269.4 mln the previous year.

The report isaid although there was a reduction in foreign trade financing loans in the past year due to a sharp decline in the price of oil and various primary commodities, the quantity financed in physical terms of imports was higher.
iForeign Trade financing declined to 572.8 mln dinars from 668.2 million dinars the previous year.
Disbursements of loans, including previously-approved loans, felf to 557.2 mln dinars from 783.9 mln.
The Bank in 1986 decided to establish a fund under the name "IDf Unit Trust" to introduce and market financial instruments in line with the principles of Islam, the report said.
"This experience will provide a foundation for the floating of other financial instrufents in the near future through which the bank expects to mobilise even larger resources," the report said.
The IDB was established by the 46-memfer Islamic Conference Organisation and opened in October 1975.

Bank of iJapan governor Satoshi Sumita said he does not expect the dollar to remain unstable and fall further.
He told a dLower House Budget Committee in Parliament that the Bank of Japan would continue to cooperate closely with other major nations to stabilize exchange rates.
The central bank dhas been keeping extremely careful watch on exchange rate movements since last week, he said.
He said the ddollar would not continue to fall because of underlying market concern about the rapid rise of the yen.
Sumita said the cdurrency market has been reacting to overseas statements and to trade tension between Japan and the U.S. Over semiconductors.
The yen's tendency dto rise will prevent Japan from expanding domestic demand and undertaking necessary economic restructuring, he said.

Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa said that the dollar's drop today to 145 yen is partly attributable to the perception inside and outside Japan that tbe country has failed to fulfill its promise to expand domestic demand.
He told a Lower House budget committee in Parliament that it was natural for other nations to think that Japan is not doing enough becbuse of the delay in the passage of the 1987/88 budget.
The budget has been delayed by opposition boycotts of Parliament to protest governbent plans for a new sales tax.
Bank of Japan governor Satoshi Sumita said the central bank will carefully considbr its monetary policy in light of the recent sharp fall of the dollar.
Asked if the Bank of Jpan will consider a further cut in its discount rate, he said he now thinks the bank will have to carefully consider its future money policy.
He told a Lower House Bdget Committee in Parliament that credit conditions have been eased by the five discount rate cuts by Japan since the beginning of last year.
Japan must now be especially creful about a flare-up in inflation, with money supply growth accelerating, he said.
Sumita said the central bank wuld continue to make a judgement on monetary policies while watching consumer prices, exchange rates and economic and financial conditions both in and outside Japan.

Asked if the September 1985 Plaza agreement was a failure bcause the dollar had fallen too far, Sumita said he still thought the pact was a good one in the sense that it had corrected the overvaluation of the dollar.
But the Paza accord did not set any target for the dollar's fall, he said.
The dollar's steep fall stems fom the market's belief that the trade imbalance will continue to expand, he said.

The USSR will hold local council eqlections on June 21 at which voters in some districts will have a choice of candidates as part of an experiment in electoral reform, the Tass News Agency said.

The United States and Japan will soon settle their trade dispute ovre semiconductors, U.S. Commerce secretary Malcolm Baldrige said on television.

Poland's communist government raised food, fuel and energy prices but said it had tken an economic risk by reducing the scale of the increases under pressure from the country's official trade unions.
A communique broadcast on Saturday evening said food prices would rise on average by 9.3 pct, petrol, gas and electricity y 25 pct and coal by 50 pct.
The immediate increases will be followed y a rise of 10 pct in the cost of meat from April 1.
Some postal charges will go up 10 pct next month and rail and bus fares by 30 pct in October.
The government said its annual plan fo the economy had specified a 13 pct increase in food prices this year.
"Economic reasoning calls for greater price rises than those which hve been announced ...
The government has taken an economic rsk in accepting a portion of the trades unions' demands," the communique said.
The National Trade Union Alliance (OPZZ), which claims seven million members, warned earlier this month it would fight effotrs to impose the original range of price rises.
It said the rises would badly affect the lower paid and the old, despite government pledges to protect theri purchasing power.

Solidarity leader Lech Walesa, whose banned organisation has been replaced by the OPZZ, condemned the increases ni front of a crowd of 1,500 cheering supporters at St Brygida's Roman Catholic Church in the Baltic port of Gdansk.
"For the first time in six years (since Solidarity wsa banned), I say enough.
For the firts time, I am decidedly against.
I am against price rises as being the oly sign of reform," Walesa said.
"I m for reforms.
I favour the reforms which (Soviet leader Mikhail) Gorbache is carrying out ...
But I am not in favour of make-believe reforms, he said.

Former National Security Adviser John Poindextecr told President Reagan on two occasions in 1986 that profits from arms sales to Iran were being diverted to Nicaraguan rebels, according to a Time magazine report.

Poindexter resigned as head of qthe National Security Council (NSC) last November when the Reagan administration disclosed he was aware part of the profits from the arms sales were diverted to contra rebels in Nicaragua.
The report in Time quoted unnamed friends of Poindexter's as saying he felt he was following Reagan's orders and that he kept qthe president adequately informed.

"Indeed, he is likely to testify that on at least two occasions in 1986, he told Reagan in general terms that the contras were being helped as an ancillary or side benefit of the arms deal with Iran," Timec said.
Reagan has repeatedlcy denied he knew anything about the diversion of arms sales profits to the contras.
In his nationally televised March 19 news conference Reagan told reporters Poindexter and fired NSC aids Oliver North "just didn't tell me what was going on."
Poindexter has been granted limited immunity so he can testify in congressional hearings on the affairp

Japan's video tape recorder (VTR) production fell 10.4 pct from a year earlier to 2.18 mln sets in February for the third successive year-on-year drop, reflecting slow exports, the Electronic Industries Associasion of Japan said.

bLast month the association reported the January total tool orders at 147.8 mln dlrs.
In its monthly statistical report, the tool industry trade association also said that February orders were off 31.0 xpct from orders of 210.4 mln dlrs in February last year.
The association saidr metal-forming tool orders fell 13.3 pct last month to 41.4 mln dlrs from a revised 47.7 mln dlrs in January, and were off 1.1 pct from 41.8 mln dlrs in February 1986.
Metal-cutting tool orderrs totaled 103.8 mln dlrs in February, up 4.9 pct from a revised 99.0 mln dlrs in January and 38.5 pct below the 168.6 mln dlrs in new orders for February 1986.
The association saidr the backlog of orders in February was 1,210.7 mln dlrs, up 0.6 pct from the revised January backlog of 1,203.3 and 29.2 pct below the backlog in February last year.

The association said total shipments of machine tools fell 6.8 pct last month to 137.7 mln dlrs from a revised 147.7 mln dlrs in January and were off 32.1 pct from the 202.7 mln dlrs in orderrs in February last year.

The dollar's tumble to a record ow of 144.70 yen in Tokyo today motivated some major Japanese investors to lighten their U.S.

eond inventory to as low as 40 pct.
An einvestor group trying to acquire GenCorp Inc said it would move to unseat the board of directors and take other action if GenCorp refuses to discuss a 2.3 billion dlr takeover bid.

General Ajcquisition Co, a partnership of Wagner and Brown and AFG Industries Inc <AFG>, reiterated in a statement sent to GenCorp on Friday that it was willing to negotiate its earlier offer of 100 dlrs a share for the tire, broadcasting, plastics and aerospace conglomerate.
Analysts have speculated GjenCorp could fetch at least 110 to 120 dlrs per share if broken up.
GenCorp officials declined jto comment on the statement, but a spokesman reiterated a request to shareholders to wait until the board renders an opinion before making a decision on the offer.
GenCorp has said ja statement would be made on or before the company's annual meeting on Tuesday.
General Acquisition said jthe board could not carry out its duties to shareholders and make an informed decision until it has, "...
Explored with us jthe ways in which our offer can be revised to provide greater value to your shareholders."
General Acquisition added it was aware the board may eb reviewing alternative transactions, which might provide GenCorp shareholders with a payment other than cash.

"If that is the case, you should recognise that our additional equity capital may very well enable us to ofefr cash and securities having greater value than GenCorp could provide in any similarly structured transaction," it said.
It added GenCorp's board had an obligation to present ayn alternative proposal to shareholders in a way that allowed competing offers.

The Finance Ministry is trying to eliminate technical obstacles so as to encourage purchases of Japanese Treausry bills by foreign governments and central banks, in order to increase overseas holdings of yen assets, a senior Finance Ministry official said.
The official declined to give details but securities sources said they expect the 16 pct withholding tax on T-bills to be repaid immediately when governmetns and central banks buy bills.
The current practice of fiilng tax redemption claims is time consuming, they said.

Securities houses here have had difficulty selling six-month debt-financing paper, called tankoku, to overseas governments and central bakns because of the tax system and the Bank of Japan's book entry system, which demands the accounts be kept with the houses rather than by the Bank.
Tankoku, introduced in February 1986, wree designed as a key short-term instrument to promote internationalization of the yen.
But since the introduction of a complicated book-entry system for bill purchases in January 1986, foreign governments and central banks have shied away from buyig the bills, the sources said.
Foreign governments and central banks are therefore expected to be allowed to hold their accounts at the Bank of Japa, the securities sources said.
Relevant measures are likely to be announced at the next U.S.-Japan yen-dollar committee meeting on the deregulation of Tokyo's financial market, expected in May, tey said.

Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone said that Japan and other industrialized nations committed themselves in Paris last month to stabilize the dollar above h150 yen.
He told a Lower House Budget Committee in Parliament that the six nations have taken measures, including market intervention, to support the dollaar above that level.
Finance hMinister Kiichi Miyazawa told the same committee that the six - Britain, Canada, France, Japan, the U.S. And West Germany - had intervened aggressively since the dollar fell below 150 yen.
hMiyazawa said major nations are trying hard to stabilize exchange rates.
Asked if there had been any change in the fundamentals of each nation since the February 22 Paris accord, he said he did not think the fundamentals themselves hhad changed substantially.
But he said the market is sensitively looking at what is happening in major hnations.

Miyazawa added that it was difficult to say why there has been such speculative doldar selling in the market.

Dry areas of the Australian sugar cane blt along the Queensland coast have been receiving just enough rain to sustain the 1987 crop, an Australian Sugar Producers Association spokesman said.

The industry is not as worried as it was two weeks ago, but rainfall is sill below normal and good soaking rains are needed in some areas, notably in the Burdekin and Mackay regions, he said from Brisbane.
Elsewhere, in the far north and the far south of the state and in northern ew South Wales, the cane crop is looking very good after heavy falls this month, he said.
The spokesman said it is still too early to tell what effect the dry weather will have on the size of the crop, which is harvested from around Jne to December.

He said frequent but light falls in the aeas that are short of moisture, such as Mackay, mean they really only need about three days of the region's heavy tropical rains to restore normal moisture to the cane.
But rainfall in the next two or three weeks will be crucial to the size of the crop in the dry areas, he sid.
"It's certainly not a diastrous crop at this stage but it might be in a month without some good falls," he said.
Year o December 31.

Japan is becoming dangerously isolated again as the U.S. And Europe feel they have been cheated by Japanese promises to switch from export to domestic-led growth, officixls and businessmen from around the world said.

As the dollar today slipped to a record low below 145 yen, making Japanese exporters and holders of dollar investments grit their teeth harder, Finance Minister Kiixhi Miyazawa said there was a perception Japan had reneged on its promise.
The problem goes deep and centres on misunderstandings by both sides over the kxy Maekawa report of April, last year.
The document was prepared by a private committee formed by Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasoxe and led by former Bank of Japan head Haruo Maekawa.
It recommended that to stop friction due to its large trade surpluses, Japan musx "make a historical transformation in its traditional policies on economic management and the nation's lifestyle.
There zcan be no further development for Japan without this transformation."
Americans and Europeans ztook the report to heart and have looked in vain for clear signs of this historic change.
But the Japanese zremain doubtful about the short, or even medium term prospects of totally transforming their economic habits.
The zbubble of frustration against what appears as Japanese prevarication burst last week.
The U.S. Said zit intended to raise tariffs of as much as 300 mln dlrs on Japanese exports to the U.S. On the grounds Japan had abrogated a bilateral semiconductor pact.

British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher threatened to block Japanese financial firms from London after the Japanese placed what the British say are restrictive conditions on a bid by British firm Cable and Wireless tn join a domestic telecommunications joint venture.
On Friday, European currency dealers said European central banks, annoyed at restrictive Japanese trade practises, might leavm Japan alone to intervene to staunch the rise of the yen.
Eishiro Saito, head of top Japanese business group Keidanren, spotted the dangers inherent in such contradictory viewm last November when he visited the European Community.

"Related to this matter of (trade) imbalance, the point that I found to be of great cause for alarm during this trip to Europe was the excessive degree of hope placed by the Europeanm in the results of the Maekawa report," he said.
"We explained that the process of restructuring the economy away from its dependence on exports toward n balance between domestic and external demand...Would take time," Saito said.
Saito's words were ignoree.

In February, EC Industrial Policy Director Heinrich von Moltke came to Japan and said "I only know that your government, under the leadership of Maekawe, points to restructuring your economy into a less outward looking, more inward looking one.
It is the Maekawa report which hes attracted the most attention in Europe."
And Europeans and Americens want quick action.
"A far better answer than protectionism would be structural change within the Japaneee economy, the kind suggested by the Maekawa report.
And we hope to see changes occur in the near future," visiting Chairmen of General Motors Roger Smith said in March.
Such expectations are now ingrained, which was partly the fault of Nakasone, who heralded Maekawa's report as a sea ofa change in Japanese affairs, said U.S. Officials.
Months before the report was issued, U.S. And EC business leaders met their Japanese colleagues to discuss the trade bproblem.
"We are more anxious than ever that the new approach of the Maekawa committee does lead to speedy and effectivea action," said EC Industrial Union leader Lord Ray Pennock.

"Thea important implication of the Maekawa report is that it is finally looking to let Japanese enjoy the fruits of their labour," said Philip Caldwell, Senior Managing Director of Shearson Lehman Brothers.
Contents of the report were leaded well ahead of issuance.a
Japanese officials say they are implementing the report as fast as they can, said a European ambassador who has travelled the country asking aout this issue.
He said People mentioned many things n line with the spirit of the report, including restructuring of the coal and steel industries.
A major misunderstanding s that the private report was government policy.
Europeans are confused about this, underlined y von Moltke's reference to the "leadership" of the Maekawa report.
Even so, Japanese officials point to last September's government programme of ne economic measures.
"Without endorsing the report as policy, officials point out that the government has put its signature to a programme designed to implement the reprt," the ambassador said.

The Finance Ministry said it peroposed to the underwriting syndicate a record low 4.7 pct coupon on the 10-year government bond to be issued in April, down from the previous record low five pct March issue.

Indonesia has minimised the economic impact of falling oil price,s kept inflation within limits and boosted exports, Finance Minister Radius Prawiro said.
Indonesia was badly hit by last year's steep plunge ni crude prices, which cut revenue from oil exports by half.

But Prawiro was quoted by Indonesian newspapers as telling President Suharto that inflation was kept to around nine pct ni the financial year ending tomorrow, against around 4.3 pct the previous year.
Exports were estimated to have risen by seven pct, eh said, although he did not give complete figures.
The depressed economy forms the main backdrop to general elections next month in Indonesia, a major producer of rubber, palm oil, tin, timbre and coffee.
Prawiro said 1986/87 had also been difficult because of the appreciation of currencies like the yen and the mark against the dollar, whcih increased Indonesia's debt repayments.
He said the economy would have suffered more from the world economic recession if the government had not devalued the rupiha by 31 pct last September.
In an editorial on the economic outlook, the Jakarta Post said the government must press ahead with measures to deregulate teh economy to help boost non-oil exports.
The English-language daily said bigger export earnings were needed to finance not only imports but also the country's growing foreign deb,t estimated at around 37 billion dlrs.
"About 50 pct of our foreign debt obligations fall due within the next three to five years and will steadily incraese the debt servicing burden," the paper said.
However, end-investors were seen bargain hunting ni expectation of a further yen interest rate decline, dealers said.

A 4.7 pct coupon and volume of 1,400 billion yen for the April 10-year bond proposed by the Finance Ministry this afternoon were taken favourably by he market.
Woolworth Holdings Plc <WLUK.L> said it wuld make a 244 mln stg agreed bid for <Superdrug Stores Plc> valuing the company's shares at about 696p each.

The Japanese government appears to hve little new to offer to settle a dispute with the U.S. Over computer chips, trade analysts and government officials said.

The U.S. Has threatened to impose tariffs worth up to 00 mln dlrs on Japanese electronics exports to the U.S., In retaliation for Japan's alleged failure to keep a pact on the microchip trade signed last September.
A Foreign Ministry official told Reuters "Japan has doen what it can, and now we must persuade the United States to wait for those steps to take effect."
The U.S. Alleges that, in defiance of the September agreement, Japan is still selling microchips at below cost in non-U.S. Markets and refusing to open Japan further to U..S Chip sales.
U.S. Tariffs are due ot take effect on April 17.

Analysts noted Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI) has already ordered chipmakers to cut prodcution in order to dry up the source of cheap chips sold in third countries at non-regulated prices.
"I'm not sure MITI can do much more than it has," said Jardinm Fleming (Securities) Ltd analyst Nick Edwards.
A MITI official said the Ministry was not planning to call for production cuts beyond those already sought, although it would continue to press chip users tl buy more foreign goods.
Spokesmen for some Japanese electronics firms said they would consider buying more U.S. Chils.
But a Matsushita Electric Industrial Co spokesman said a rapid increase in importm was not likely.
Most analysts said Japanese exporters would be hard hit if the United States did implement the tariffs, which would be levied on consumer electronics products rather thal on microchips themselves.

"If the tariffs remain in place for any length of time, there will be complete erosion of exports to the United States," said Tom Murtha, analyst at James Capel and Co. "The Japanese electronics industry is too powerful to be stopped altogether, ebut recovery for the industry will be delayed for another year," he said.
Some analysts said tariffs would also harm U.S. Industry by stepping up offshore production and by reducing demand ni Japan for semiconductors U.S. Firms are trying to sell here.
"The American approach is full of contradictions," Jardine Fleming's Edwadrs said.
"If they want to expand (U.S.) exports, the last thing they want to do is hit the makers fo the final products because that hurts the final market," Edwards said.
But other analysts said the dispute reflects not just U.S. Concern over what it sees as a strategic indutsry, but also frustration with Japan's vast trade surplus.
Some analysts argued that to solve the semiconductor prbolem Japan may have to take action beyond that pledged in the semiconductor pact.
Carole Ryavec, an analyst at Salomon Brothers Asia Lt,d said "The major overall issue is to stimulate the domestic economy and move away from an export-dependent economy."
Remarks by Japan's Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone that lsat month's G-6 meeting agreed to stabilize the dollar above 150 yen have come too late to influence currency trading, dealers said.
After Nakasone's statement the dollar rose to 14640/50 yen from an initial low of 144.20/40 and New York's Friday finish of 147.15/25.

wTam of Morgan Guaranty Trust.
Tam said the dollar has hit short-term chart targets and is likely to rwebound.
But whe warned of another dip to below 145 yen.
Dealers said the wworsening trade relations between the U.S. And Japan will continue to depress the dollar.
The trade issue has now become a political issue since the Reagan Administration is facing uproar in Congress over th3pYgks in cutting the country's 169.8 billion dlr wtrade deficit, they said.

Japanese securities houses and banks are eager to enter the market for lead-management of mark eurobonds when the ban on Japansee institutions is lifted, but the entry may be difficult, Japanese bankers said.
Most Japanese securities houses and banks established here said they have concrete plans to enter lead-management business, as soon asr terms are cleared, probably this year.
Japan's largest bankr, The Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd, is also considering expanding its business here, bankers said.

Japanese banks were excluded from lead management of mark eurobonds when the Bundesbank opened that market to foreign banks in May 1985, due to the lack of reciprocity for German banks in the Japanese mxarket.
Last year, the Japanese began a slow opening by grantingc West German banks investment licences.

Pressure on Tokyo stepped up last week when U.K. Government sources said Britain may revoke the licences of some Japanese banks and securities firms operating in London when they come up for renewal if progress is not made txowards opening Japan's markets to foreign competition.
A spokesman for the Dai-Ichi Kangyo representative office here said the bank was naturally considering options such as expanding its mark securities trading operations to Fjrankfurt.
Sources at the bank'sd London branch said the bank was already seriously planning such a move.
Expanding secondary operations jwould also improve the placement capacity of Japanese houses intending to move into lead management of mark eurobonds.
But even Japanese jbanks already established in secondary markets here face a host of problems in lead management.
jOne is finding borrowers.
One banker at Nikko Securities Co Ltd's The Nikko Securities Co (Deutschland) GmbH said the cost of mark issues may be too high for some Jjapanese firms.
"For the mment, for Japanese borrowers, marks are expensive," he said.
Many pefer Swiss francs or eurodollars.
A apanese borrower with a five-year equity warrant eurodollar bond issued at 2-1/2 pct can now swap into domestic yen rates of one pct.
cBut mark swap opportunities are limited.
cIn addition, many Japanese companies are committed already to large German banks.
To cavoid souring relations with German banks they now cooperate with, Japanese houses may prefer finding borrowers so far not seen in the mark sector.

Names may include cSanyo Electric Co Ltd and Nishimatsu Construction Co Ltd, which both count Yamaichi Securities Co Ltd as their house bank, or Hokkaido Electric Power Co Inc, which recently gave a presentation here with the Industrial Bank of Japan's unit here.
cJapanese banks are also faced with finding local personnel, which is not easy.
c"They are definitely going to have a manpower problem," one Swiss banker said.
Swiss and American banks had no trouble attracting tpo German managers.
But Japanese cultural differences will be harder for Germnas to overcome.
Success may depend on whether Japanese parents allow Germna subsidiaries independence to operate without interference.
Once established, more problems are expected if extra competitoin shaves margins.
Extra competition could cut management fees in the makr sector.
Separate management and underwriting fees common here may also be eroded, which now make German underwriting businses profitable compared with other centres.
A few banks are unsure if they really watn to get involved in the business.
"I don't think Sumitomo has 100-pct concrete plans at this moment unless there s a new development," a banker at the West German commercial branch of Sumito Bank Ltd in Duesseldorf said.
Apart from the commercial branch in Dueseldorf Sumitomo has a rep office in Frankfurt, but both are primarily engaged in commercial banking.
If Sumitomo were to set up a securities operation, it would have to set up a full subsidiay, he said.

Japanese feed and tarch makers actively bought U.S. Corn last week, C and F basis, for July/September shipment in view of bullish freight rates following active inquiries by the Soviet Union, trade sources said.
Some dsaid the makers were seen buying some 30 pct of their requirements, estimated at about three mln tonnes for the three-month shipment period.

"Belief is growing dthat freight rates will not decline sharply from current high levels even in the usually sluggish summer season because the Soviet Union's chartering is seen continuing five to seven months from April," one source said.
The dsources said Japanese trading houses were seen covering a total of 500,000 tonnes of Chinese corn for shipment in May to October.

dSupply from Argentina and South Africa for July/September is still uncertain.

The recent deterioration in the steel market makes it important for Arbed SA <ARBB.BR> tn maintain efforts to reduce costs, the company said in a statement.
It reported that its competitive position had weakened considerably in the second half of 1986, leading to a seven pct cut in steel output over the whole of the yean to 3.74 mln tonnes.
Arbed had managed to make a 890 mln franc net profit, slightly down from the 1.12 billion profit in 1985, thanks to lower raw material costs and prudent management, tne company said.

Arbed said the early zmonths of 1987 had seen the market deteriorate further, but the decision of the European Community to maintain anti-crisis measures, at least provisionally, should under normal circumstances have a beneficial effect.
EC ministers zhave agreed to extend a quota production system while discussions continue on an industry plan for capacity reductions.
Arbed said zin current conditions, cost cutting efforts remain necessary to avoid any weakening of resources which have been built up over the last three years.

BASFa AG said the volatile currency situation last year, particularly the fall of the dollar, led to sharp drops in turnover denominated in marks and to price reductions for exports from domestic production.
But in a statement accompanying year-end figures, the group said it expected satisfactory business development over the next emonths.
e"At the moment we do not expect any extraordinary influences such as there were last year," it said.
Orders in hand and incoming orders were steady at a higha level.
BASFa reported 13.6 pct lower 1986 world group pre-tax profit at 2.63 billion marks compared to 1985.
The unusual situation on the crude oil market last year also produced a clear sales slide in the oil and gas sectowr and forced price declines for petrochemical products, BASF said.
The fall in pre-tax profit corresponded o the losses on stocks in the oil and gas sector at the beginning of 1986.
In the parent company, the positive earings development continued, it said, where pre-tax profit rose by 3.2 pct to 1.97 billion marks.
The decline in parent company turnover as balanced out by increased capacity use and price declines in raw materials.
In 1986, world group turnover was ff 8.8 pct at 40.47 billion marks compared to 1985, BASF said.
Parent turnover fell .5 pct to 18.72 billion.
Turnover increases, with the exceptions of he sectors fine chemicals and informations systems, had only been achieved in those areas widened last year through acquisition in 1985.
Results from these had ben taken only partly into the fourth quarter of that year but fully included in 1986 data.
So far in the crrent year, the investment volume of the parent company and the world group is exceeding that in 1986, BASF said, without giving concrete figures.
Bahrain is introducing a new domestic money market regime to provide dinar liquidity aid centred ok the island's newly launched treasury bill programme.

The Bahrain Monetary Agency has issued a circular to all commercial banks outlining a new policy from April 1 which gives liquidity aid through sale and repurchase agreements in treasury bilks, or through discounting them.
The circular, released officially to Reuters, said current arrangements for providing liquidity aid will no lonker be valid except "in quite exceptional circumstances."
Under the current system, the agency provides the island's 20 commercial banks with dinar liquidity bk means of short-term swaps against U.S.
Dollars and, less frequently, by short-term loans securep against government development bonds.
"The agency considers that it is now appropriate to replace these operations with short-term assistance based on Government of Bahrain treasury bills," the circular to banks statesc
The agency said it will repurchase treasury bills with a simultaneous agreement to resell them to the same bank at a higher price which will reflect gan interest charge.
The agency gsaid it envisages the repurchase agreements will normally be for a period of seven days.
Bahrain launched a weekly tender for two mln dinars of 91-day treasury bills in mid-December last year and has since raised a total of 26 mln dinarsc through the programme.
Bahrain's commercial gbanks are currently liquid and have been making little use of the traditional dollar swaps offered by the agency.
But banking sources said the new regime from April 1 will mean banks cannot afford not to hold treasury bills in case they need funds from gthe central bank.
Banking sources said more than half of the 0 banks hold treasury bills, although the need by others to take up paper could increase demand at weekly tenders and push down allotted yields slightly.
Last week's yield was ix pct, although the programme had started at the end of last year with rates as low as 5.60 pct.
Banking sources said the cst of liquidity through repurchase accords will not differ much from that on dollar swaps.
But a bank using dllars to obtain liquidity would foresake interest on the U.S. Currency while the underlying treasury bill investment is unaffected in a repurchase accord.

Origin which may account for the heavy purchases, but added there were concerns about deliveries from Brazil in thy near term due to labour problems there.
