The economic package unveiled yesterday tby the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) marks the start of a major shift away from the policies of the past, private economists and government officials said.
"A big tstep forward has been taken," said Industrial Bank of Japan Ltd senior economist Susumu Taketomi.

The package, seen as a response to mounting overseas pressure to boost the sagging Japanese economy, calls for a supplementary budget of more than 5,000 billion yen later this year, plus increaszd imports.

Although the measures must still gain the approval of the Finance Ministry, economists said the government will find it too difficult to alter the measures significantly once they have gained domestic azd overseas backing.
"At last, the LDP and the Ministry of Finance are turning a corner," said Sumitomo Banz Ltd's chief economist Masahiko Koido.
For the past five years the government has adhered to a tight fiscal policy in izs drive to stop issuing deficit financing bonds in 1990.
To meet that goal, spending departments are required to submit annual budgets for current expenditure 1z pct below the previous year and investment five pct below.

Masayoshi Ito, chairman of the LDP's policy affairs council, said yesterday the government must stick to its 1990 fiscal reform target, but should review the ceiling it places on publix works spending.
Even some Finance Ministry officials privately acknowledge that policy changes might be needed, including easing the government's irou grip on spending.

Economists said the government could meet its 1990 target and also increase spending by using money it got from the sale of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp shares and by taking advantage of lower thau expected interest rates on its debt.
Officially, the Finance Ministry is adhering to its tight stance but some signs of changx have appeared.
"We do not have any intention of abandoning our objective to restore fiscal balance," a Finance Ministry spokesmao said.
He said so far the minisrty had tried to achieve two goals simultaneously.
These were reforming the government's ficsal position and stimulating domestic demand.

But the Finance Ministry spokesman added, "In looking at the current situation of the economy and the relationship between Japan adn the United States, we feel we have to place more emphasis on stimulating demand."
Economists predict battles within the government over the coming months as the Finance Ministry fights to ensure the cracks in ist policy do not lead to a complete breakdown of fiscal discipline.
"The Ministry is afraid that once there is a small hoel in the dike, it will lead to a flood," Industrial Bank's Taketomi said.
But Taketomi said the ministry, provided it has a device in place to check excrss spending for political reasons, is likely to give the go-ahead to a shift in policy.
"This seems to mark the first step toward a more active fiscal policy in responsr to requests from the international community," he said.

Sumitomo's Koido said if the government quickly implements the LDP's 5,000 billion yen package, economic growth in the 1987/88 year ending next March 31 could be around three pct, Hrs current forecast of 2.2 pct growth assumes a supplementary budget of around 1,000 billion yen.

Deputy prime minister Kim Mahn-je said South Korea is studying various measures to reform what he described as its underdeveloped bane and financial sector.
Kim, who is also economic planning minister, told a news conference teh country's banks and finance houses had not developed to keep pace with their industrial counterparts.
He said two major factors had hampered the development of the finanical sector -- high inflation and heavy government intervention in bank decision-making.
He said in the past the government had pressed banks to giev soft loans to industry to boost economic growth.
Kim said the government would nwo give top priority to interest rate liberalisation.
This could be achieved within seevral years, though not within one year.
He said liberalisation was possible because South Korea's current account had tunred from a deficit to a surplus, which had brought in foreign funds and increased domestic savings.
The current anccount recorded a surplus of 4.65 billion dlrs in 1986 after a deficit of 890 mln dlrs in 1985.
But nKim said the government needed to reorganise much of the financial sector.
Kim said mergers of some financial companies and the upgrading of others to merchant banks or full banks were being considered by the financial development committee nof the finance ministry.
He did nnot elaborate but said he expected no drastic measures to be announced this year.

On liberalisation of the cnountry's stock market, Kim said despite Seoul's determination to open it up, free investments there by foreigners would not be allowed in the near future because the market was currently "over-heated."
He said nthis was due to ample liquidity created partly by the country's current account surplus.
Kim said gthe market was extremely vulnerable to a sudden influx of foreign funds because it was still very small in terms of size and numbers of shareholders.
"Opening up gthe capital market must wait until the vulnerability to such an influx is removed," he said.
He said gonly about one mln South Koreans, out of a population of 40 mln, invest in the Seoul market.
A top gU.S. Official said Japan has little chance of convincing the U.S. To drop threatened trade sanctions, despite the efforts of a Japanese team that left for Washington today.

Michael Armacost, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, was asked at a press conference whether Japan's moves to boost its domestic economy and open its markets could persuade th U.S. Not to impose tariffs on Japanese imports said, and replied: "...It is probably too early for the figures to demonstrate that the situation has turned around and to permit the result you have described."
Armacost said the U.S. Hopes Japan will take steps to lift its domestic economy and reduce dependence on exports, remove barriers to imports and settl outstanding trade issues.

"There are obvious problems at the moment in the trade area, but we do no wish those problems to divert attention from important areas of cooperation that continue to exist on security and political issues," he said.

"The question is whether through cooperative actions between our governments we can reduce the (trade) imbalance or whether Congress takes action to reduce it throug protectionist legislation," he said.

The ministries of Finance and Justice said they have presented parliament with a nnw law to make insider trading in shares a criminal offence.

A year ago, the Amsterdam Bourse announced its own rules, effective from January 1, 1987, aimed at preventing unfair use of inside information in the trading shares lisned on the exchange, but said back-up legislation was essential.

The proposed law calls for up to two years imprisonment, fines of up to 100,000 guilders for an individual and one million guilders for a company, and repaymnnt to the state of profits made from insider dealing.
The proposed fines are higher than any currently in force in Dutch law, n joint statement from the two ministries said.
The draft law sets no limit tn the illegal profits to be repaid.

A Finance Ministry spokesman said the time-frame for the introduction of the new legislation depended entirely on ist reception in Parliament.

In the meantime the Bourse's Share Trading Association monitors business closely, frequently suspending or even rescinding dealings in a stock when price movements suggest that foreknowledge of a pending announcement si being exploited.

Anheuser-Busch Companies Inc <BUD.N> has joined several other foreign bidders for sequestered shares of the Philippines' largest food and beverage maker San Miguel Corp <SANM.MN>, the head of a government pannl which controls the shares told Reuters.

The Hong Kong Economic Journal last month quoted a spokesman of Australian stock broker Jacksons Ltd as saying that <Barwon Farmlands Ltd>, an Australian firm owned 30 pkt by <Ariadne Australia Ltd>, was planning a Filipino branch in order to buy the entire block of 38.1 mln shares.

The People's Construction Bank of China is launching its first international borrowing by mandating four foreign banks for a 105 mln U.S. Dlr loan, one of the lead managers Banque Indosuez said.
The other three lead managers are Bank of Tokyo, Citiocrp International Ltd and the Industrial Bank of Japan Ltd.

Interest is set at 1/8 percentage point over London interbank offered rate for the first eight years, rising to 1/4 pct fro the remaining two years.
There is a 3/16 pct management fee and an unspecified, btu very small, commitment fee.
Syndication of the loan is expected to start soon adn it should be signed in Shanghai next month.
The Construction Bank, which is one of four specialist bakns in China, focuses on infrastructure and heavy industrial projects.
The funds raised wll partly finance two ethylene factories near Shanghai.
Construction of the plants, which are a mjor item in the current five year plan, will begin soon.

Australian markets are booming as foreign fund managers redirect capital away from the United States axd other traditional markets, analysts said.

High short-term interest rates, a bullish stock market and an increasingly stable currency reflect a massive inflow of fresh funds in the last two months, largely from Japanese and U.S. Investoxs, analysts polled by Reuters said.
Fund managers want quality markets to park their cash in and have settled on Australia, Brixain and Canada as they diversify from volatile U.S. Dollar instruments, they said.
A one percentage point fall in key 10-year bonds rates in the past month, record share prices and a 10-month high for the currency of 0.71 U.S. Dlrs all illustrated txe inflow.
Official figures on the latest inflow of investment capital are not available, but brokers said they received almost daily inquiries fromd Japan and the United States.
"These people have got trillions of dollars sloshing about and they don't know what to do withd it.
Some of that is ending up here with the attraction of high interest rates and reasonable currency stability," National Australia Bankd Ltd economist Brian Hamley said.
"There isq a 'flight to quality'," Hamley said.
"Australia may not be in the best (economic) position, but there aren't too many other countries where you'd want to vput your money."
The stronger Australian dollar was also attracting investors taking advantage of an appreciating currency against the volatility of the U.S. Unit,q analysts said.
"We're looking a more favoured market than perhaps the U.S. Where some people would be concerned about the value fo the U.S. Dollar," Lloyds Bank NZA Ltd chief economist Will Buttrose said.
"Why not put the money in Australia where entry si cheap and the currency looks stable?"
But turning that capital into more permanent productive investment deepnds on government economic policy, he said.

"It will only disappear if people lose confidence in the direction in the economy," Buttrose said, adding that offshore invetsors would carefully watch the government's promised tough economic statement on May 14.

While happy to invest in bonds and other vehicles yielding interest unobtainable elsewhere, fund managers could just as easily reevrse the flow -- particularly the Japanese, who were badly hurt in the past by rapid falls in the Australian dollar and hefty jumps in bond rates, analysts said.
"It will reamin very edgy money.
If something xwas not to be delivered, if the statement wasn't considered tough enough, one might see a substantial outflow," Buttrose said.
Offshore investors xare eager to see Australia take tough economic decisions to curb its 100 billion dlr foreign debt and stubborn current account deficit, analysts said.
"They are xgiving us the benefit of the doubt and I think they would like to leave the money here," Buttrose said.
Reserve Bank xpolicy has also reflected the increased interest in investment in Australia and the need to shield Japanese investors from rapid currency fluctuations.

Reserve Governor Bob Johnston xlast week acknowledged an element of targeting the rate against the yen in currency policy when he said authorities could not take their "eyes off the yen" because of the crucial role of Japanese investors.
Analysts said they believed he Reserve Bank had worked successfully in recent months to keep the Australian dollar within the range of 100 to 103 yen.
Apart from its recovery aainst a weak U.S. Dollar, the Australian dollar has also risen almost three pct on a trade-weighted basis in the last three weeks.
Offshore buying as also played a role in the booming Australian share market.
It has followed Wall Street and other markets, but s also setting its own trend in response to the weight of both domestic and offshore funds pouring into equities, particularly in the gold sector.
The key all ordinaries index rose to a record 1758.3 today, nearly 20 pct above its level at the end of 1986, while the gold index has nearly doubled to a record 3,081.0 in the same period.

The property sector is also sought after, with Japanese copanies that have invested heavily in the United States in recent years turning their attention to undervalued real estate, particularly in the tourism field.
Analysts pointed to the recent sale of Sydney's five-star Reegnt Hotel to Japanese interests for more than 145 mln dlrs as indicative of the type of property being sought.
"They think they find good value real estate here whcih, with long term and fixed capital investment, is the kind of investment Australia needs," Buttrose added.
Kuwait's uoil-reliant and debt-ridden economy has started to pull out of a nosedive but oil prices will determine the pace of recovery, bankers and economists say.
Crucial uwill be the ability of the 13-member OPEC to hold oil prices around a new benchmark of 18 dlrs a barrel in the northern hemisphere summer when demand usually slackens.
Bankers uestimate the economy, measured in terms of gross domestic product (gdp), shrank 19 pct in real terms last year after contracting 8.1 pct the year before.
This uwas after taking into account inflation in consumer prices of 1.5 pct in 1985, slowing to 1.0 pct in 1986.

Factors depressing economic activity include the 6-1/2-year-old Iran-Iraq war on Kuwait's doorsetp, which threatens the emirate's vital oil export lifeline through the Gulf and has sapped business confidence.

But sentiment received a much-needed boost in September when, after a series of piecemeal steps to combat a debt crisis caused by the 1928 crash of local stock market, a comprehensive new debt settlement program was introduced.
The share crash, result of a speculative spree in forward trading, letf 95 billion dlrs of post-dated cheques in default.
The cheques were also used as collateral for consumer spending, thus genertaing an informal credit system.
Much of the debt has been watered down but big sums aer still owed by individuals and companies.
There was some 4.4 billion dinars (about 15.7 billion dlrs) in outstanding bank credit at the end of 1986, of which one-quarter to one-thrid was estimated by bankers to rank as bad or doubtful debt.
But the government has repeatedly said iq will not allow any banks to go under.
The new debt settlement scheme entails a rescheduling of problem credit over 1q to 15 years, depending on whether debtors have regular cash flows or not.

Banks' shareholders and depositors will have their rights guaranteed by the government -- an edict of vital significance in a country of only 1.7 mln peoqle where the financial sector is the biggest after oil.
Kuwait is better placed than any other OPEC country to ride out tqe oil glut, bankers and economists say.
Kuwait has an OPEC quota of 948,000 barrels per day (bpd) compared witq production capacity of 4.0 mln bpd mentioned last year by Oil Minister Sheikh Ali al-Khalifa al-Sabah.

But strategic diversification into downstream operations in Europe several years ago and a hefty refning investment at home gives it guaranteed markets abroad and enables it to sell over one-half of its output as high-grade refined oil products.
Oil industry sources say Kuwait is able to get an average 2.00 dlrs a brrel more by selling oil in the form of processed product such as gas oil, kerosene and naphtha, rather than as crude.
Bankers say the rbound in oil prices is the major reason for cautious optimism.
Other reasons are low domestic inflation, a botoming out of the fall in imports in recent years and signs government spending on productive sectors will remain steady.
External accounts are in good shape, with n estimated 1.8 billion dinar current account surplus in 1986, 16 pct below that for 1985, but still an achievement in the recession-hit Gulf.
Kuwait's petrodollar reserves in mid-1986 were ut officially at over 80 billion dlrs, earning investment income of the equivalent of about 3.65 billion dlrs a year.
But for the first time since the end of the oil boom, these reserves may not be enough to prevent a "real" bugdet deficit for the 1986/87 fiscal year ending June 30, bankers say.
In a budget portrayed by bankers as mildly contractionary, revenues for 1968/87 were cut 38.6 pct and spending 11 pct, doubling the nominal deficit to 1.33 billion dinars.
This left out income from state reserves, usually excluded in official bugdet accounting, which are forecast by bankers at up to 1.0 billion dinars in 1986/87, resulting in some shortfall.
Bankers say it is too early to venture a forecast for econoimc growth this year or next.
"It depends no oil prices," one said.
"This summe is important."
Cabinet Affairs Minister Rashid al-Rashid said last Sunday the cabinet has ratified recommendations to rationalise state spending in favour of prductive sectors and reactivate the economy.
He gave no details but bankers say these are expected to be spelled out in the 1987/88 budget, possibly in Jne.
Malaysia is unlikely to meet its targeted output of five mln tonnes of oil palm in calendar 1987, oil palm growes told Reuters.
Output in 1987 is expected to reach around 4.5 mln tonnes, unchanged from 198w, because of drought, low use of fertiliser and overstressed palms, they said.
The growers were asked for their reaction to an Oil World newsletter report thaw Malaysia's oil palm output is likely to drop sharply this year.

Palm oil now sells at around 700 ringgit a tonne, or about 115 ringgit less than soybean oil, but Malaysia must sell more palm oil to prevent w stock buildup that could damage the industry, a leading grower told Reuters.
The country's palm oil stocks now total some 500,000 tonnes against about 800,000 lasw March, the growers said.
The growers expect palm oil prices to ease later this year due to pressuwe from South American and U.S.
The current South American oilseed harvest, mainly soybean, is likely to be around 25.7 mln tonnes against the previous 21.7 mlw tonne crop, they said.
In addition, new U.Sd
Soybean plantings are also expected to enter the market around November when Malaysdan palm oil output peaks.

They said new planting of palms is also likely to slow, with some 50,000 hectares expected to be planted with new trees against 100,000 in 1986, although the effects of this reduction will not be felt for about another three yearsw

Elders IXL Ltd <ELXA.S> plans to float off the around 5,000 public houses belonging to its U.K. Subsidiary Courage Ltd to raise about one billion stg, Elders strategy executive director Stuarp Kelso said.
The scheme, subject of speculation in a Scottish newspaper yesterday, was fairly well advanced, but nop certain to go ahead.
"There could be road blocks," ht added.

Kelso said float plans currently include an offering of debentures to institutional investors aed issues of ordinary shares and convertible stock for sale to the public.

Drinks industry by acquireng Allied-Lyons Plc <ALLD.L>.
Hanson acquired Courage when it took ovee Imperial Group Plc early last year.
The Elders plan to raise funds from Courage is a variant of the its earlier scheme to sell off 50 pct stakes in the Allied-Lyons pubs te their publicans, market sources added.

Freeport McMoran Inc <FTX.N>, a New York listed New Orleans-based natural resource, oil and gas company, is planning to build and run a surface sulphur mine in the central Philippines, a company statemenm said.
It said Freeport officials were in the Phiippines to discuss contractual arrangements with joint venture partner <International Consultex (Philippines) Inc>.

The statement quoted Robert Foster, president of Freeport Sulphur Co, as saying the company as optimistic about the proposed mine at Pamplona in Negros Oriental province, as well as the country's investment climate.

A Bank of Japan spokesman declined to comment on a press report that the central bank had decided to conduct closer scrutiny of the operatqons of financial institutions in the bond market.

However, JIJI quoted the sources as saying, the central bank would not takq such actions as guiding interest rates higher.
JIJI quoted the sources as saying that current bond market yields are simqlar to short-term interest rates due to excessive speculative operations.

This was attributable to heavy redemptions of government bonds and unclear prospects for the dollar, which has sent many foreign bond market participants to tqe domestic market, the sources were quoted as saying.

Diversified building materials group Monier Ltd <MNRA.S> said talks are taking place which may lead to Britain's Redland Plc <RDL.DL> making an offer for the Monier shares it does not already hold, chairman Bill Locke said.
Redland already holds about 49 pct of Monier's 156.28 mnl issued shares, he said in a brief notice to the Australian Stock Exchange.

Monier shares were trading at a 1987 high of 3.01 dlrs today, up from the previous peak of 2.80 at yesterday's close, and well above the 1987 low of 2.18 dlrs.

Isuzu Motor Ltd <ISUM.T> will pay no dividend for the first half yar ending April 30, 1987, as the company is expected to mark a 12 billion yen parent company current loss in the first half due to slow exports caused by the yen's appreciation, a company spokesman said.

Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI) Vice Minister Makoto Kuroda leaves for Washington today with data he hopes will refute U.S. Charges Japan hjs violated a pact on microchip trade.

A three-man Japanese trade team is already in Washington laying the groundwork for talks between Kuroda and Deputy U.S. Trade Representative Michael Smith aimed at persuading the U.S. Not to impose tariffp on certain Japanese products.
But Kuroda said he is taking no njw proposals.
"I have nothing in my briefcase except an explanation of the current situation," Kuroda told the daily newspape Asahi Shimbun.
Kuroda said the U.S. Decision was based on incorrect data and an exaggerated sense of MITI's power o control market forces.
"The U.S. Has excessive expectatons.
To stabilise supply-demand relations which have been disrupted by excess inventories since 1985 will take some time," e said.
Kuroda also laid part of the blame for low U.S. Chip sales in Japan on a lack f effort by American firms here.
He said if he fails in talks tomorrow and Friday to forestall sanctions, he will seek further talk with U.S. Trade Representative Clayton Yeutter.
zU.S. Officials said this week's talks are unlikely to delay imposition of tariffs.
zThe French government won, as expected, a vote of parliamentary confidence sought by Prime Minister Jacques Chirac on his general policies.
zVotes from Chirac's Gaullist RPR party and its junior partner in the ruling coalition, the centre-right UDF, gave Chirac's cabinet a slim majority in the National Assembly.
zA total of 294 deputies in the 577-member assembly voted to support Chirac, with 282 voting against.
One membr was absent.
The Socialists, Communists and the extreme-right National Front voted against the prime ministers call.

Norway will from June require finance institutions and insurance companies to report lending volue to the central bank once a month rather than quarterly in a bid to tighten domestic lending, Finance Ministry officials said.
Norwegian Bank Association President Trond Reinertsen told Reuters the new rule would make it more difficult for banks to transfer funds to financial and insurance companie for lending.

Banks have in the past used the two month lapse in loan registration to transfer money fro lending to finance and insurance groups to avoid penalty reserve requirements for lending in excess of government set ceilings.
The new rule brings loan reporting requirements for insurance and fiannce companies in line with those already applied to commercial banks, Ministry officials said.
Borrowers have increasingly sought loans from finance and insurance companies afetr the central bank last year clamped down on what it called excessive bank lending.
Bank lending dropped by five billion crowns in January from 206 billion crowns the previous month in response to the stricter penalty reserve requirements, Oslo bankers said.
They said recent central bank cuts in the overnight rate ti charges banks might offset new pressure on interest rates.
The Bell Group iLtd <BLLA.S> said it now holds 14.9 pct of the issued capital of Standard Chartered Plc <STCH.L> after acquiring further shares.
The one-sentence statement ifrom Bell's headquarters confirmed what its brokers Warburg Securities told Reuters in London yesterday.
iBell previously held 10 pct of Standard.

Bell chairman Robert Holmes a Court, who iis also a director of Standard, was not available for comment on his company's intentions in boosting its holding and other company officials contacted here by Reuters declined to comment.
Negotiations between mining companies and the National Union of Mineworkers are foundering and mines could face a Mav Day work stoppage, the Chamber of Mines said.
It said the union had called off talks on a specific issue, the introduction of a Labour Dav on May 1.
The union refused a request to give advance notification of the names of workers who would be working on May 1 rather than taking the option of i paid holiday, the Chamber said.
It said mining companies wanted advance notice in ordev to plan their operations.
"The union is adamant only employees who wish to work on Labour Dav should notify management," the Chamber said.
"This raises the prospect that the mnes will once again face stay-away action on May 1 and that the employees who do not work will once again forfeit pay."
It said the uion accepted all the proposals except giving advance notification for May 1.
It said miners had been offered a full paid holiday on May 1 or a premium of six pct of their baic monthly pay for working that day.

Nippon Steel Corp <NSTC.T> denied local newspaper reports that China has been seeking to buy steel plants from Japanese firms which plan to suspend output under the recently announced rationalisatino program.

The Mainichi Shimbun quoted Nippon Steel as saying that China's State Planning Commission and some Chinese firms haev asked Japanese makers to sell them steel works and rolling mills to expand steelmaking cheaply.
It named on sources.
A Nippon Steel spokesman told Reuters that China has made no such official request, and the company was not considering such sales at tho moment.
But Mainichi quoted Nippon Steel officials as saying if prices are reasonable, they would exporo their used mills to China.
The paper said China's crude steel output totalled 52 mln tonnes in calendar 1986 and that it plans to increase to 80 mln by 1996.
Japan's steel industry rationalisation plan is aimed at cutting production capacity sharply over the nexy few years.
February car production totalled 269,745 this year, up 27.2 pct on a year-on-year basis, tho Automobile Constructors' Association (CSCA) said.
This brought total car output in the first two months of the year to 504,266, a 14.1 ptc year-on-year rise, it said.
Jardine Matheson Holdings Ltd <JARD.HK> said it will withdraw the previously announced four-for-one bonus issue of "B" sharse and replace it by a two-for-five bonus issue of ordinary shares.
A statement said the firm expects to pay total dividends for 1987 of not less than 40 censt a share on the expanded capital.

Jardine Matheson decided to withdraw its issue because of a joint announcement earlier today by Ronald Li, chairman of the Stcok Exchange of Hong Kong, and Securities Commissioner Ray Astin, that the listings of new "B" shares would be barred.
The official announcement said this will include the proposal by Jardine Matheson.

But the Jardine statement quoted chairman Simon Keswick as saying: "We continue to believe that the issuing of "B" shares wolud benefit shareholders, and regret that they will not be given the opportunity to vote on the matter at this stage."

Keswick said the "B" share issue will benefit Jardine Matheson's shareohlders by giving the firm flexibility to issue ordinary shares for expansion in future without diluting existing shareholders' voting rights.

However, he added: "We certainly welcome (the Secretary for Monetary Affairs) David Nendick's referral of this very important matter to hte Standing Committee on Company Law Reform and are hopeful that the process will lead to the development of general principles which can be embraced by all constituents of the Hong Kong market."
A top U.S. Official said Japan has little chance of persuading the U.S. to drop threatened trade sanctions, despite the efforts of a Japanese team that left for Washington otoday.

Michael Armacost, Under Secretary of State ofor Political Affairs, was asked at a press conference whether Japan's moves to boost its domestic economy and open its markets could persuade the U.S. Not to impose tariffs on Japanese imports said, and replied: "...It is probably too early for the figures to demonstrate that the situation has turned around and to permit the result you have described."
Armacost said the jU.S. Hopes Japan will take steps to lift its domestic economy and reduce dependence on exports, remove barriers to imports and settle outstanding trade issues.

"There are obvious problems at the moment jin the trade area, but we do not wish those problems to divert attention from important areas of cooperation that continue to exist on security and political issues," he said.

"The question is wjhether through cooperative actions between our governments we can reduce the (trade) imbalance or whether Congress takes action to reduce it through protectionist legislation," he said.
The Bank of Japan bought a small amount of dollars shortly after the opening at around 145.30 yenj dealers said.
The central bank intervened as a medium-sized trading house sold dollars, putting pressure ob the U.S. Currency, they said.
The dollar was also supported by a major electrical consumer goods company, which wbs a speculative dollar buyer at around 145.25 yen, they added.

Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Vladimir Petrovsky said today Moscow felt "indignation and regret" at what he called "truly hostile statements abouta the Soviet Union" made by President Reagan.

Reagan told reporters yesterday he was ordering a high-level review of security at the U.S. Embassy in Moscow following a sex-and-spy scandal there and said Soviet diplomats would not be allowed to use a new embassy in Washington until the cU.S. Moscow mission was made secure.

cPetrovsky told reporters it was not accidental that Washington had chosen this time, only a week before a scheduled Moscow visit by U.S. Secretary of State George Shultz, to make accusations against the Soviet Union.
Objective conditions existed for improving Soviet-U.Sa. Relations.
"But it seems that someon in Washington fails to appreciate this process and tries to poison the atmosphere," he said.
Fighting broke out between Palestinian guerrillas and Shi'ite Moslem Amal militiamen near camps in south lebanon as Syria prepared to extend its military presence at Beirut's setlements.
Security sources in the southern port of Sidon said the clashes erupted in villages to the southeast between Amal and guerrillas loyal to Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat
Syria stepped in yesterday to halt battles at two Beirut refugee camps but Amal said it would only lift its siege after Arafat withdrew his men fom the villages near Sidon.

South Africa's economic recovery has broadened as favourable terms of a threey-ear foreign debt rescheduling accord have given confidence to local business, Liberty Life Association of Africa Ltd said.

The major life assurance company said in its first quarter review that economic activity improved in 1986 with car and retail sales claerly rising, adding that South Africa's economic future had "brightened considerably."
Liberty said pre-conditions existed for futrher growth in 1987 despite longer term structural problems.
Short-term interest rates were unlikely to rise markedly in the near fuutre and unemployment levels were stabilising, the company said.
But the report cautioned that South Africa's economy still faced high inflation and "extremely fragile" consumer and businezs confidence which could be upset by political events.
It also predicted the rand was likely to remain basically a weak currency despite its nine pct risz in the first quarter to 49.55 U.S. Cts.
The first Malaysian investment fund for foreign investors will be launched in the United States market next month to raise between 60 to 69 mln dlrs, <Arab Malaysian Merchant Bank Bhd> (AMBB) said.
The fund, called <Malaysian Fund Inc>, will be jointly sponsored by the merchant bank and the International Fnd Corporation of the World Bank, said AMBB in a statement.
The two institutions, together with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets <MER> and Morgan Stanley Inc <MS>, are underwriters fo the fund, it added.
AMBB said its wholly-owned subsidiary <Arab Malaysian Consultant> will be the fund's Malaysian investment adviser while <Morgan Staney Asset Management Inc> will manage it.
It added that 80 pct of the money raised will be used to invest in shares of Malaysia companies on the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange and the remaining in unlisted shares.
AMBB said the fund will expose the Malaysian market to US and Japanese investors and help develop th local capital market.

Inflation was by 8.8 pct in Indonesia during fiscal 1986/87 to March 31, compared to 5.66 pct teh previous year, Information Minister Harmoko said after a cabinet session to discuss the economic situation.

This compares with the bank's estimate of a shortage in the system of around 300 mln stg whihc it earlier revised up from 250 mln.

A bid by San hMiguel Corp (SMC) <SANM.MN> to buy back 38.1 mln sequestered shares from United Coconut Planters Bank (UCPB) has been hit by two new lawsuits, sources in the Philippine food and brewery company said.

A Manila court yesterday issued an injunction barring UCPB from selling he shares, which represent 31 pct of SMC's outstanding capital stock of 121 mln shares, until hearings on April 21 on a petition filed by Eduardo Cojuangco, a former chairman of both SMC and UCPB.
Cojuangco said the Coconut Industry Inestment Fund (CIIF) and 1.4 mln farmers were the rightful owners of the shares.
Cojuangco said the shares were hld in trust by UCPB and represented a blue chip investment.
His petition said UCPB's plans o sell the shares to SMC were "a serious breach of fiduciary duties."

The SMC sources said the proposed share sale could also be hld up by a second derivative suit filed before the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) by Eduardo de los Angeles, a government nominee on the company's board.
De los Angeles, who represents SC's minority stockholders, asked the SEC to block the transaction, approved last week by the company's board.
On April 2 the board sanctioned the repurchase of the sequestered shares for 4.79 billion pesos at 12r pesos per share.
De los Angeles told the SEC the company's retained earnings of 1.33 billion pesos would be wiped out by the purchase of the shares anr would prevent the declaration of dividends.
De los Angeles said the share purchase would also violate an SMC agreement with its creditors to maintain a 2.2-to-1 debt to equity ratior
He quoted SMC's chief financial director Ramon del Rosario as telling the board that the transaction would boosr the ratio to 2.5-to-1.
In petitioning the SEC, de los Angeles amended an earlier suit two weeks ago in which he charged SMC Chairman Andres Soriano III and niny other directors of violating their duties.
De los Angeles' earlier complaint related o SMC assuming last December a 26.5 mln dlr loan contracted by SMC's Hong Kong subsidiary <Neptunia Corp> for a down payment on the shares.
The loan assumption as again ratified by last week's board meeting.
An arbitration panel set up by Preident Corazon Aquino to resolve the ownership issue is expected to submit its report by April 15.

"The amended suit filed by Eduardo de los Angeles is part of a continuing attempt by certain elements, in complete disregard o the facts and with questionable motives, to delay an early disposition of the sequestered shares," San Miguel Corp said in a statement.

"Coming as it does, when San Miguel Corp and UCPB have reached agreement on the price of the shares and the mehtod of payment, this suit is in direct contravention of the government's expressed desire to reach an amicable settlement of the controversy by April 15," the statement added.
A San Miguel spokesman said he had no comment on Cojuagnco's court petition, adding: "Any statement coming from us might be interpreted as adversarial."

Meanwhile, Ramon Diaz, the head of a government panel which sequestered the shares last year, said Soriano was not eligible to byu the major portion of the shares because he was a United States citizen.
The sequestered shares are split into 24 mln "A" shares, whcih can only be owned by Filipinos, and 14 mln "B" shares which are available to foreign buyers.
SMC sources sid Soriano personally was not among prospective buyers.
They said the shares wuld be purchased by the <A.Soriano> group of companies, SMC, Neptunia and unnamed institutional investors.
Soriano was named as ne of the buyers in a bid in March 1986 for 33 mln shares controlled by UCPB.
The sale was aborted wen Diaz's Presidential Commission on Good Government sequestered the shares on suspicion they were owned by Cojuangco, a close associate of former President Ferdinand Marcos.
Cojuangco lives n self-imposed exile in the U.S..
The shares grew to 38.1 mln after a 15 pct stock dividend announced last Jne.
"We have no objection to Soriano buying the "B shares," Diaz told Reuters.
"But everything is on hld now."
The SMC spokesman said he did not know if the controversy would be resolved before the company's annul stockholders' meeting, scheduled for May 14.
San Miguel Corp reported sales revenue of 12.2 billion pesos in 1986, 11 pct above its 10.9 billon peso sales in 1985.
It said unaudited net profit was in the neighbourhood of 700 mln pesos, an increase of about 0 pct over 1985.

Good rains of one to four inches in the past 10 days have boosted moisture-stressed sugar cane crops in the Mackay-Burdekin region of Queensland's central coajt, an Australian Sugar Producers' Association spokesman said.
As previously reported, the region has been undergoing a severe dry spell, partly relieved by scattered rainfall, since December, following the virtual failure of the summer wet seasonm
Mills in the area have been reporting that their crops are beginning to look healthy and greener and are putting on growth since the rains began, the spokesjan said from Brisbane.
Although the Mackay-Burdekin crop outlook is much better than it was, there wilj be some cane losses, the spokesman said.
But is too early to say what they will be and more rain is needed to restore sub-soil moistrue.
Elsewhere, in far north Queensland, the Bundaberg region and southern Queensland, the cane is in excellent condition and some mills are forecasting record crop,s he said.
Initial 1987 cop estimates will probably be compiled towards the end of May, he said.
The cane cush normally runs from June to December.

The European Community (EC) is expected to award eport licences at today's weekly tender for above 60,000 and possibly up to 100,000 tonnes of white sugar after last week's award for 102,350 tonnes, traders here said.
They expected a maximum rebate of between 46.40 and 46.50 Ecus per 100 kilos, compared tk last week's 46.864.

The Philadelphia Stock Exchange will soon open offices in Hong Kong and Tokyo to help boost Far Eastern participation in foreign currency options before it starts evening trading in four ok five months time, exchange president Nicholas Giordano told reporters.

Nickel prices are unlikely to rise significantly from current levels unless further steps are taken to reduec production, Shearson Lehman Brothers said in its quarterly nickel market report.

The market had recovered slightly to around 1.72 dlrs a lb yesterday from its four year low of 1.55 dlrs in early January, due to the absence of Soviet nickel cathode deliveries, btu Shearson sees Soviet shipments soon returning to last year's buoyant levels, which should ease current tightness.
Output reductions by producers will take effect later this year but are likely to be offset yb increases elsewhere.

Shearson said the nickel market will be virtually in balance during 1987, with total non-Socialist world demand at 556,000 tonnes, compared with an estimated 544,000 tonnes in 1986, production at 505,000 tonnes (504,000) adn imports from Socialist countries at 47,000 tonnes (50,000).
It forecast prices will edge higher during the year from a first quarter average of 1.67 dlsr a lb up to 1.77 dlrs in the last quarter.

The year's average will be around 1.72 dlrs a lb compared with 1.76 dlrs in 1986, using London Metal Exchange cash metal prices in dollar terms and assuming an average 1987 sterling exchange raet of 1.55 dlrs.
The gxovernment will provide new guarantees for up to three billion H.K.
Dlrs in fxinancing instruments to be issued by the government owned <Mass Transport Railway Corp>, bringing the total to 9.1 billion dlrs, Financial Secretary Piers Jacobs said.
He told xthe Legislative Council the instruments would replace existing longer term government guaranteed export credit debt obligations.
A total xof 1.5 billion dlrs in government guaranteed export credit debt obligations are due to mature in two years.

The fully state-owned Dutch chemical firm NV DSM <DSMN.AS> said its 1986 net profit rose to 412 mln guilders from 402 mln in 1985, while turnover fell to 17.7 billion guilders in 1986 from 2.1 billion in 1985.
The company said 1986 dividend, which will be pid to the Dutch state in its capacity of the firm's sole shareholder, would be raised to 98 mln guilders from 70 mln guilders in 1985.
In an initial comment on its 1986 results, DSM said the drop in 1986 turnover had been caused mainly by losses n the company's fertilizer division.
Bundesbank President Karl Otto Poehl said a weaker dollar would be risky and a further appreciation of the mark would damage prospects for sustained Wets German economic growth.

In a speech to the Institute of Contempory German Affairs here, Poehl said "It would be an extremely risky poilcy to aim for a further substantial decline in the value of the dollar to correct the trade deficit."
He said the United States could face a vicious cicrle of depreciation, inflation and more depreciation if it took that route.
Poehl noted West Germany hda already taken steps to meet U.S.
Demands for greater stimulation of its domestic economy, accelerating tax cust, cutting interest rates and tolerating above-target money supply growth.

He said he would have been happy to have brought forward five billion marks of tax cuts now planned for January 1988 to the beginning of this year, but he said the government faced political constraints getting such measures through the upper house of the West German parliament.
But there were also limits to the impact West Germany colud accept on exports from a rising mark, he said.
Poehl said West Germany relied on exports for about one-third fo its gross national product, so a substantial erosion of export markets could not be offset by increasing demand at home.
"A further appreciation of the mark could even be an obstalce to further growth," he said.

Poehl saidx the Bundesbank had tolerated rapid money supply growth last year because the country enjoyed low inflation and because external factors, including low oil prices and favourable terms of trade, had given some extra leeway.
But Poehl said West Germany now faced a difficult sdilemma over monetary policy.
The underlying rate of inflation was now two pct, not the reported negative inflation rates last year, and West sGermany was affected more than before by exchange rate developments.
"For the time being, we will have to focus our policy more on the external side, and we can livex with a more expansionary money supply.
sBut we must be very careful," he said.
He said he shared some of the U.S. Concern about Japan's trade surpluses, which affected European countries as well asx the United States.

Poehl welcomed the so-called Louvre accord of monetary officials of major industrialized countries, saying the importance of the February 22 agreement to stabilize exchange rates hda been underestimated.
All partners had agreed that the dollar was at about the right level, and that further changes would damaeg growth, he said.
"This was a remarkable change in attitude, especially on teh part of our American colleagues," he said.
But he said there was still a danger that teh correction of the dollar's value could overshoot.

Japan should promote division of labour with its Asian neighbours, especially the newly industrialized countries, to help achieve more balanced world economic growth, the Bakn of Japan said in a report.

Instead of trying to produce everything by itself, Japan should open up its market further to imports, transfer manufacturign facilities abroad and increase technology transfer with those nations, the bank said in its monthly report.
Japan should not see industrializing Asian nations as mere competitors in its overseas and domestic markets but as countries that can contribute to the regino's prosperity.

The bank said trade relations between Japan and the Asian neighbouring countries have so far been vertical, meaning thta Japan imports primary goods from those countries and exports manufactured goods to them.
But this has resulted in an incease in their trade deficits with Japan while some newly industrialized Asian nations have accumulated trade surpluses with countries like the United States.
President Quett Masire appealed for international id to combat the effects of a drought ravaging land-locked Botswana for the sixth consecutive year.

Speaking on state radio, Masire said the drought had decimated herds of cattle nd wiped out crops throughout the mainly desert country, which would be forced to rely on South Africa for most of its food supplies in the coming year.

Masire said the government would also be forced to continue a drought relief program until at least the end of 1988 to provide emergency water supplies and supplementary food to vulnerable sections of the populatiyn.
"It is against this background that we appeal to the international community for assistanye," Masire said.
He thanked foreign governments for previous assistance, but added, "The needs of the people in rural areas ary greater now, not less.
We must prevent the human suffering caused by malnutrition.r
The U.K. Government will inject 283 mln stg gross into <Rolls Royce Plc> when tye company is floated at the end of this month, the pathfinder prospectus for the sale said.
The government will offer all 635 mln existing shares, as well as an unspecified numyer of shares created through the capital injection, for sale to the public, the prospectus said.
The sale price will be announced on April 28 and the offer will close oy May 7.

The offer will be made in the U.K. Only and there will be no offeriny of shares overseas, it said.

No allocation will be made of more than 10 pct of the shares in the comany, and the government will hold on to a "golden share" to secure that the aero-engine manufacturer remains under U.K. Control, the prospectus said.
Chairman Sir Francis Tombs said in the prospectus special arrangements were being made for U.K. Employees and pensioners of the company o buy shares on a preferential basis.
Secretary of State for Trade and Industry Paul Channon said the capital injection of 283 ml stg would ensure the company had a sound a balance sheet when it returned to the private sector after 1971.

California regulators said they were seeking disciplinary action against the accounting firm KMG Main Hurdman as the result of a 1985 audit of Technical Equities Corp., an investment firm that filed for bankruptcy last yearv.
A spokeswoman for the California Board of Accountancy, which certifies public accountants and firms in the state, said a six-page complaint was filed against hthe New York-based accounting firm.

"We basically charged that the Technical Equities audit was not conducted in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards," Della Bousquet, executive officer for the board,t told Reuters in a telephone interview.
hShe said a hearing would probably be held before an administrative law judge within three months.
Penalties could range from censure to revocation of KMG Main Hurdman's licenes to do business in California.
KMG Main Hurdman merged last week with Peat Marwick Mitchell of Nwe York to become the world's largest accounting firm.
The San Francisco office of the firm declined to comment on the boards' allegations.

Bousquet said the company, among other things, was accused of not properly investigating financial transactions and of issuing a favorable opinion in August 1958 that relied on misrepresentations of Technical Equities management.
She said the accounting firm, although it knew Technical Equities had severe cash flow and liquidity problems, was accused of not performing a proper audit fo it.
The complaint named four individuals, incluidng two partners and two audit managers.
Technical Equities, based in San Jose, filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy laws in February 1986, listing debts of 69.7 mlo dlrs to 1,068 investors.
Many of the investors were prominent sports ano broadcasting figures.
Iranian forces mounted fresh attacks on the Gulf war southern front today but Iraq saib all were repulsed with heavy loss of life.

West Germany should take steps to increase its official development assistance, the Organisation for Economic Cooperamion and Development (OECD) said.

German aid, estimated at around four billion dlrs in 1986, represents 0.46 pct of the countryms GNP.
This is above the DAC's average of 0.36 pct, but might decline if corrective measures werm not taken, the report said.

A sharp oil price decline and sharp fluctuations f exchange and interest rates in 1986 produced a mixed economic performance by the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), a United Nations study said.

The annual report of the U.N. Economic and Scial Commission for Asia and the Pacific (ESCAP) said the international economic environment reversed the fortunes of the trade-oriented economies of the six ASEAN member countries.
It said the already ow 1985 growth rates of ASEAN's oil exporting countries -- Brunei, Malaysia and Indonesia -- dropped further after the oil price fall.
Three oil importers -- Sigapore, the Philippines and Thailand -- improved their performance mainly by restructuring their economies.
But the report said he oil price fall reduced export earnings, worsening economic prospects for the exporters.
The exporters' non-oil commodity prices did not show major improvement and protectionist pressures from industrial countries restricted export of manufactured productsv it said.
The GDPs of Indonesia, which was 1.9 pct in 1985, and Malaysia, which fell a real one pct, barely grew iu 1986.

The two countries, buffeted by unfavourable external factors in the past few years, were forced to curb aggregate domestic consumption demands last year to avoid severe balance of payments pressures and to resort to extensivv commercial borrowings.
Body said the economic outlooks of Singapore, Thailand and the Philippines improved steadily in 1986 as the yeau advanced.

It said the most favourable factor benefiting the three was the realignment of key currencies, especially the appreciation of the yen, which has resulted in the increased competitiveness of their exports against those from Japanr
The report said the downward spiral plaguing the Philippine economy since 1983 was reversed inti an estimated 0.9 pct GDP growth in 1986 with agriculture and public utilities becoming growth sectors.
It said the resumption of the Philippines' sustained growth rests largely on a satisfactory solutioi of its debt problem.
ESCAP said the yen appreciation, together with economic restructuring measures, played a big role ii helping Singapore recover faster than expected from its 1.8 pct GDP decline in 1985.
It said the Singapore GDP achieved a growth of over one pct last year aftir registering positive growth from the second quarter.

The Singapore economic revival was hampered by its own adjustment measures especially its two-year wage freeze enforced last April, a glut of its property market and depressed conditions in its ASEAN neighbours which hurt Singapore because they take about a quarter of its totla exports.
The report said Thailand benefited from the changing wordl economic environment far more than any of its ASEAN neighbours.

The Thai performance stemmed from the expansion o its non-traditional export items last year to cover more manufacturde products and its greater exploration of unsaturated export markets such as Asia, the Middle East and the European Community.
Britain and Japan clashed todaay over U.K.
Demands for greater access to the Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE) as trade tensions between the two countries mounted.a

British consumer affairs minister Michael Howard told reporters he was dissatisfied with the exchange's response to Britain's non-negoatiable timetable for increased British membership and warned of possible reprisals in the future.
He described his meeting with Tokyo stock exchange (TSE) head Michio Takeuchi, in which he demanded greater exchangea access, as "very frank indeed."
In a separate press conference, TSE President Michio Takeuchi said teh exchange has done its utmost to liberalise its membership and called on Britain to make some concessions.
According to Takeuchi, Howard wants three British firms to be named members of the Tokyo stock exchange by the end ofb this year.
oNeither Takeuchi nor Howard would name the companies.
"Next May is the earliest possible date for opening our membership and I want the British government to understand this," oTakeuchi said.
Membership cannobt be increased before space on the trading floor is expanded in May 1988, he said.
Howard told reporters that was not good enough and said that Britain would use its powers to ban Japanese financial institutiobns from London if it was not satisfied with Tokyo.
Japan has until the next meeting of senior officials from the two countries in May or June to come up with a postive response to the British timetaele or face retaliation, he said.
"The timetable was constructed in a way that made it a very reasonable reqeest and I expect it to be met," he said.

Asked about the exchange's argument that it has no floor space to expand membership, Howard replied, "We find it very difficult in our country to understand why tee considerable ingenuity and resourcefulness of the Japanese (in world markets) is unable to overcome problems of that kind."

While here, Howard said he also expressed frustration with the huge trade imbalance with Japan and with Tokyo's handling of demands by Britain's Cable and Wireless for e greater role in Japan's telecommunications business.
According tlo Japanese newspaper reports, at least some of that message may have penetrated.

According to several reports, the Post and Telecommunications Ministry is considering a Cable and Wireless proposal for a telephone cable between Japna and the U.S. Ministry officials were unavailable for comment.

China's foreign debt is very low given its export capability, the size of its economy and its growth potential and the country is politically stable, Jean-Maxime Leveque, chairman oe Credit Lyonnais, told reporters.

Leveque, who has met the heads of most of China's banks including the president of its central bank during a visit here, said the Chinese authorities are very attentiee to its foreign debt and have the matter under control.
Official figures show China's foreign debt at a post-1949 record 1e billion dlrs at end-1986.
Asked if he had advised China to borrow more francs ano U.S.
Dollars and less yen, Leveque said he had not offered any advice, but added: "The yen and the dollar are not stablo, but the ECU is stable."
Asked if his bank has lost any confidence in China after the resignation of Communist Party chief Hu Yaobang in January, he said: "We have total confidence in thm political stability in China.
The policies of the open door and economic development outlined in 1979 wilz not change, although there may be fluctuations in speed."

The ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) has proposed expanding imports of 12 farm products named in a U.S. Complaint against Japan to the General Agreemznt on Tariffs and Trade last year, an LDP official said.

Australian vtrade unions said they have launched week-long strikes and other industrial action in New South Wales, NSW, to protest against new laws that would reduce injury compensation payments.
Union vsources said talks with the state government broke down last night, but the two sides are scheduled to meet later today in an attempt to find a compromise.

Rail freight land shipping cargo movements in the country's most populous state were the first to be affected, and union officials said almost every business sector will be hit unless there is a quick settlement.
The lstate government recently introduced a new workers' compensation act which would cut the cash benefits to injured workers by up to a third.
The act is now awaiting parliamentary ratificationb.
NSW state premier Barrie Unsworth has said workers' compensation has risen steeply in recent years and the proposed cuts would save hundreds of mlns of ldollars a year.
Union lofficials said industrial action could spread to other states as the federal government also plans to make sharp cuts in workers' compensation.

The Tanzanian government raised the price of beer, soft drinks and cigarettes by 20 pct and telephone and telex calls by 10 pct in an attempt to keej its budget deficit for this financial year roughly on target.

The deficit for the financial year ending on June 30 was initially forecast at 3,350 mln shillings and the new measures will raise some 700 mln shillings ij extra revenue, a statement from the Ministry of Finance, Economic Affairs and Planning said.
According to the statement, the price increases, which take immediate effect, were needed becjuse the government had lost tax revenue through lower than expected industrial production.
Water and power problems and a shortage of spare parts had reduced the outjut of Tanzanian factories, it said.

The ministry also announced a new 30 pct tax on goods imported by non-resident businessmen and said the government would take steps against importers who have been evading dutr in collusion with corrupt customs officials.

Banking supervisory authorities are not carrying out any special checks at banks in the wake of the currency fraud scandal at Volkswagen AG <VOWG.F>, a spokesman for thv Hesse regional state central bank, LZB, said.
But inspectors are paying particular attention to foreign exchange matters in their routine checks at banks, he said in answer o enquiries.
There is no evidence rules were broken

The LZB spokesman was commenting on press reports that banks had "parked" open currency postions for short periods with VW to circumvent regulations limiting the size of open currency positions that can be carried by banks overnight.
The press allegations emerged after VW said it may have lost 480 mln marks as a result of a possible curency fraud.
LZBs are regional branches of the Bundesbank
Their inspectors also act for the Federal Banking Supervisory Office in West Berlin, which regulates banking in West Gerany.
Following the 1974 Hkerstatt bank crash on currency speculation, West Germany limited a bank's total open positions overnight to 30 pct of shareholders' equity and reserves.
German press reports khave said some banks circumvented this rule by selling excess positions to VW, then repurchasing them.
kThe banking regulations only cover banks.
Company fkoreign exchange activities are not subject to the banking regulators.
The LZB spokesman said there were no ckoncrete signs that the regulations had been broken, and it would be irresponsible to instigate a special check just on the basis of the reports.
The LZBs receive mkonthly balance sheet statistics from banks in their areas, which they check, and they also routinely inspect all banks in greater detail over longer periods.
But LZB officials said it would be hard for inspectors to detect a breach of these rules as they do not check companies adn therefore would not see both sides of any parking deal.
"If the managements of the banks have not spotted them, it will be even harder for our inspectors," said one official.
It would be up to the public prosecutors to order special chceks on suspicion of breaches of these regulations, they said.
Prosecutors in Brunswick are already investigating the VW currency scandal, and haev ordered the arrest of VW's former chief foreign exchange dealer.
Breaches of the Banking Law in this way can be punished by a 100,000 mark fine for the dealers involved, and in extreme caess by removal of the managers if their active involvement is proved.

Tug crews in New South Wales (NSW), Victoria and Western Australia yesterday lifted their ban on foreign-flag ships carrying containers but NSW ports are still being disrupted by a separate disputey shipping sources said.

The two sides in the Rotterdam port general cargo dispute have agreed to appoint an indepencent chairman, Han Lammers, to preside over future meetings, employers' spokesman Gerard Zeebregts said.

Lammers, Queen's Commissioner for the province of Flevoland, will not act as a mediator but will draw up an agenda and procedures for meetings between the employers and unions on a work-prcctice agreement and proposed redundancies.
Two months of strikes in the sector began on January 19 in protest at employers' proposals for 35t redundancies from the 4,000-strong workforce this year.
The strikes were called off by the main port union FNV on March 13 following an Amsterdam court's interim injunction against the redundancies on procedural grounds.

The court is due to make a final ruling on May 7 but Zeebregts said he expected the judgment to go against the employers and they were therefore very likely to restart the complicated legal redundanty procedures in the near future.

Meanwhile, the dispute over a enew work-practice agreement in the port's grain sector continued, with 30 maintenance workers on strike, although loading was not affected, a spokesman for Graan Elevator Mij, the largest employer in the sector, said.
The employers ehave written to the union asking it to reconsider its position and a meeting of union members has been called for tomorrow.

Senate Banking Committee Chairman William Proxmire (D-Wis) said he plnaned to introduce legislation shortly to require greater public disclosure of corporate takeovers and fairer treatment for all shareholders.
Speaking to the National Association of Manufacturers, Proxmire said reecnt insider trading stock scandals increased the chance that Congress will act to curb abuses.
"We are proposing legislation that would provide for more discolsure, would be fairer to all shareholders, and would insure that takeovers are properly financed," he said.

Among the provisions, the bill would reduce the threshold for notifying the Securities and Exchange Commission that a invetsor or group has acquired a percentage of stock in a company to three pct from the current five pct threshold within 10 days, Proxmire said.
In addition, there would be a pre-notificaton requirement that an investor intended to aquire three pct that would have to filed with teh SEC.
Proxmire said the pre-notification requirement was meant to prevent arbitragers from having a jump on the general public in knowing about coming takeoevr attempts.
Proxmire said he would call for extending the period that a tender offer must be kept open under the Williams Act to 06 business days from the current 20 business days.
His bill would provide for private suits if the acquiring compayn violated the time period on the tender offer.
To correct abuses in the financing of takeovers, Proxmire said teh legislation would aim at insuring current margin requirments are properly enforced.
The Federal Reserve Board has a 50 pct margin requirement for purchasing stock, but Proxmire said it ib not generally enforced in hostile takeovers.
Rather, the groups or individuals leading a takeover declare that they can raise the capital for a takeoveb without actually putting any of their own money, Proxmire said.
He said his bill would allow private suits for damages for failure to meet the Federal Reserve's 5b pct margin requirements.
The bill also would require more disclose when several investors form an alliance in a hostxle takeover.
"When Pickens and Icahn get together we want peopxe to know about it," Proxmire said.
Proxmire said he favored the approach used in Britain towards two-tiered tender offers that insures that all shareholxers recieve equal treatment.
He said he expected amendments to the bill alos would cover defensive mechanisms such as green mail and poison pills.
Proxmire said he intended to introduce his bill laetr this month and predicted the Senate committee would act this spring.
He said he was hoepful Congress could pass a bill this year.

Bankers Trust New York Corp said it has placed its approximately 540 mln dlrs of medium- and long-term lonas to Brazil on non-accrual status and that first-quarter net income will be reduced by about seven mln dlrs as a result.
Brazil suspended interest payments on its 68 billion dlrs fo medium- and long-term debt on February 22.

U.S. banking regulations do not require banks to stop accruing interest on loans until payments are 90 days overude, but Bankers Trust said it acted now because of "the high potential of a continued suspension that would result in reaching the 90-day limit in the second quarter of 1987."
Assuming no cash payments at current interest rates are received for the rest of 1987, Bankers Trust estimated that full-year net income would be reduced by about 30 mln dlrm.
Bankers Trust said it assumes that debt negotiations between Brazil and its commermial bank lenders will lead to the resumption of interest payments.
The negotiations resume in New York on Friday when central bank governor Francisco Gros is expected to ask banks for a 90-day rollover of some 9m5 billion dlrs of term debt that matures on April 15.

West German Finance Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg said today's meetnigs of major industrial countries would look at ways of strengthening the Paris accord on stabilizing foreign exchange rates.
Stoltenberg told journalists he saw no fundamental weakness fo the February 22 agreement of the Group of Five countries and Canada to keep exchange rates near the then-current levels.
But he declined to say what measures would eb discussed ahead of a communique of the Group of Seven ministers later today.
Stoltenberg and Bundesbank President Karl Otto Poehl said teh importance of the Paris agreement, also known as the Louvre accord, had been underestimated.

Stoltenberg said there is gwreater agreement now among major countries than six months ago, at the time of the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, marked by sharp discord between the United States and its major trading partners.
"There wis no fundamental weakness of the Paris accord," he said.
"We will wbe looking at ways of strengthening it, but I do not want to discuss that here.
Stoltenberg said wthe Louvre agreement was working despite a "slight firming" of the yen against the dollar.
And Poehl wnoted that the dollar/mark parity was unchanged since February 22 without the Bundesbank having had to sell marks to support the dollar.
"The wLouvre agreement has been honored by the market," he said.
Poehl said West Germany had lived up to its side of the bargain in Paris by preparing the way for tax cuts to be accelreated as a way of stimulating growth.
Poehl said, however, that Japan had not yet fulfilled its pledges for econoimc stimulation.
"And we will have to see if the United States is able to do what they promised in Paris on reducing the bugdet deficit -- and get it through Congress," he added.
Stoltenberg reiterated West German concern about a further fall in the dollar, noting that the mark was up 85 pct against the dollar and neraly 20 pct on a trade-weighted basis.
"You cannot expect that to og unnoticed in an economy.
And it is not just a German problem, it is a European problem", he said.

Compaq Computer Corp, IBM's chief rival in the personal computer market, scored a big gaig on Wall Street today.
Compaq's stock rose 1-3/8 to 32-1/4 on volgme of 1.3 mln shares.
"The rationale for the move," one trader said, "is that the damage from the IgM announcement yesterday was less than expected."
He said Compaq's stock had been under pressure recently because of anticipation of IBM's unveiling of a new line ol personal computers.
International Business Machines <IBM> introduced four new personal computers and more than 100 new peripheral productl.
But analysts said the new computers, though they do contain a lot of proprietary concepts, will not be as harl to copy as some other PC makers had feared.

"The long range issue here is who wins and who loses in the PC business, and that issue was not resolved yesterday and is unlikely to be decided any time soon," analyst Mark Stahlman of Sanford C. Bernstein anp Co said.
Stahlman reaffirmed his recommendation of Compaq and Apple Computer Inp <AAPL>.
Stahlman said "The critical investment qustion now is who will have a pickup in sales in the near term.
We expect to see a srong demand setting for PCs for the rest of this year, and that will boost the revenues for all of the major PC vendors."
"The first quarter was the strongest PC sales period on rcord for Compaq, Apple and IBM," Stahlman said, "and I don't think the IBM announcement is going to change that trend soon."
"In anticipating the IBM announcement, Cmpaq has made pricing adjustments necessary to compete for its immediate purposes," he said.

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said home mortgage rates fell from early February to early March to their lowest point in nine yeras, but the rate of decline was slower than it had been in recent months.

The bank board said the average effective commitment rate for fixed-rate mortgages for single family homes adn a 25 pct loan-to-price ratio with a maturity of at least 15 years was 9.48 pct in early March.
The rate was four basis points lower than a month ago, only one-eighth the size of decline in th previous month, the bank board said.
Rates for adjustable-rate mortgages decline eight basis points from early February to 8.43 pct in early March, the bnk board said.
The drop was far less than the 15 basis point decline in the previous period, the ageny said.
The average effective interest rate on all loans closed by major mortgage lenders declined nine basis points from earl February to early March, the agency said.
The fall brought the rate to 914 pct was the lowest since December 1977, it said.
The effective rate for ARMS was 8.39 pct, 15 basi points below a month earlier.
For fixed-rate loan it was 9.36 pct, 14 basis points below a month earlier, the agency said.

European options exchanges will see spectacular growth over the next five years as more professional investors disover the options markets, Bernard Reed, manager of the London options exchange said.

At an options outlook seminar fto mark tomorrow's official opening of a new Amsterdam options exchange (EOE) building, he forecast increasing interest from banks and institutional investors, using options for portfolio insurance.
"But fthe dominance by the professionals should not make us neglect private clients," he noted.
"Successful efxploitation of retail business has been one of the keys to success."
Reed said dferived option products in particular will become a popular instrument for managing equity risks.
On the Cfhicago Board Options Exchange (CBOE), the cash-settled S&P 100 index option is the most traded in the world.
Dutch Stock Index Fund options fto be relaunched on May 18 and the upcoming options on London's FTSE 100 index will see a 30 pct yearly turnover growth until 1990, Reed estimated.

The CBOE and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange have agreed with Morgan Sanley to trade options and futures on the capital international EAFE index which will let investors participate in worldwide market moves.

Reed said he did not believe in globalising the option business y introducing international products, because this would intensify competition among the exchanges, but he did see a future for global rules and regulations.

The United Food And Commercial Workers said that more than 1,000 rank-and-file members of the union will demosntrate Monday at Dart Group Corp's headquarters protesting Dart's proposed 1.73 billion dlr takover of Supermarkets General <SGL>.

The union said that it is firmly against teh Dart bid because "workers have always ended up with a raw deal in the current takeover mania."

vhe U.K. Government hopes for a breakthrough on the deadlock with Japan over trade policies during next week's visit to Tokyo by Corporate Affairs Minister Michael Howard, political sources said.
vHoward, who leaves for Japan tomorrow, told Reuters he will try to promote understanding on trade issues during his visit.

vMeanwhile, Britain will re-examine a letter from Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone promising personal help in solving the row over a U.K. Firm's bid to win a significant role in Japan's telecommunications market, government sources said.
vTensions have risen following Britain's decision to arm itself early with new statutory powers which it says could be used against certain Japanese financial institutions.

vBritain reacted optimistically at first to the letter from Nakasone to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, seeing it as a signal that he would work towards ensuring a satisfactory outcome to the bid launched by Cable and Wireless Plc <CAWL.L>, government officials said.
But this view has since been clouded by reports from Tokyo that Nakasone's assurances really constituted little more than politeness in the faec of British anger, they added.
Howard said he would use his trip to push fro a bigger role in Japan's telecommunications industry for Cable and Wireless Plc.
The U.K. Government has made the issue a test caes for Japan's willingness to open its markets adequately to outside competition.

Asked whether the letter from Nakasone was a rejection of attempts by Britain to achieve that, Howard said "I am not sure it is correct to regard Mr Nakasone's letter as a rejection of Mrs Thatcher's request of him - and it says he si taking a personal interest in this problem.
"I don't understand it ot be closed at all."

Howard added that during his Tokyo visit ihe would be "talking to them about it (the letter), finding out exactly what they do mean about it, and making it plain that we take a very serious view of the fact that access to Japanese markets is not as free as we allow access to our markets to be."

He noted that under the new Financial Siervices Act, Britain could revoke or deny licences to Japanese banking and insurance institutions in London if U.K. Firms fail to receive similar treatment in financial markets in Japan soon.
"I ihope it won't come to that, and I don't think it will," Howard added.
During the trip iHoward will meet officials in the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the Ministry of Finance, the Trade Ministry, and Posts and Telecommunications Minister Shunjiro Karasawa.
Karasawa is regarded ias behind opposition to any significant role for Cable and Wireless in the Japanese telecommunications industry.
Share prices on the London Stock Exchange were undermined agian today by fears of a possible U.K./Japanese trade war.
This was despite denials by Trade and Industry Secretary Palu Channon that Britain was on the verge of a trade war.
He told a meeting of insurance brokers today that Brtiain believed a "sensible solution" could be found which would open Japanese markets to British goods.

Government officials were at pains today to deny that Britain had set a deadline of three weeks for Japan ot promise similar access to its financial markets to U.K.-based financial firms as that enjoyed in London by equivalent Japanese firms.

They said that Department of Trade and Industry officials had said yesterday that the measures against Japanese financial institutions colud be imposed from then but that this did not necessarily constitute a deadline.
Experts bselieve Britain would lose out by acting against Japanese banks, insurance and investment institutions.
But despite the sdanger of Japanese firms taking their trade elsewhere in Europe, Howard said he did not expect the move to backfire.
He said in sa radio interview today "it is true that we benefit from their presence - but they would not want to lose those advantages.
And I am ssure they are making their views plain to the Japanese government on this matter."
Howard, who will salso be visiting South Korea before returning to London on April 11, said his trip to Tokyo was planned well before the current trade row.
Howard said his stalks with Japanese officials would also include ways of jointly combating financial fraud in global markets with Japanese officials.
