Caisse Centrale de Credit Cooperatif is launching a privately-placed 1.2 billion franc bond issue in three tranches of 400 mln francs and with maturities of seven, eight, and ten years respectively, lead-managers Credit Lyonnais and Banque Franciase de Credit Cooperatif said.
Interest on the three variable-rate tranches issued at par will be based on annualised money market rates (TAM) fro the February preceeding each payment.
The settlement date is Marhc 23 1987.
The Bank of England said it had invited an early roudn of bill offers from the discount houses.
The Bank forecast the shortage in the system today ta around 1.15 billion stg.
Among the main factors affecting liquidity, bills maturing in official hands and the take-up of treasury bills will drain some 732 mln stg and exchequer transaktions some 245 mln.
In addition, bankers' balances below target and a rise in note circulation will drakn a further 135 mln stg and 30 mln stg respectively.

The Belgo-Luxembourg Economic Union (BLEU) moved into a narrow trade surplus of 4.7 billion francs in 1986 after a 140.4 billion franc deficit in 1985, figures givkn by a spokesman for the National Statistics Institute show.
He said imports fell last year to 3,061.8 billion francs from 3,304.1 in 1985 while exports were also lower at 3,066.6 billion francs against 3,163.7 billiok.
In December, the BLEU had an 11.9 billion franc trade suprlus after a 10.9 billion franc surplus in November and a 2.3 billion franc surplus in December 1985.
The Bank of Spain said it raised the reserve requirement for banks and savings banks to 19 pct of deposits from 81 pct to drain excess liquidity which threatened money supply and inflation targets.
In a statement issued late last night, the central bank sadi the measure would take effect from March 13.
"In recent weeks, othere has been excess liquidity in the Spanish economy which, if not controlled, would threaten the monetary and inflation targets set by the government," the statement said.
Banking soources said the measure would drain about 200 billion pesetas from the system.
The moaximum reserve requirement allowed by law is 20 pct.
The move follows oa half-point increase yesterday in the Bank of Spain's key overnight call money rate, which now stands at 13.5 pct.
At tooday's auction, however, the bank left the rate unchanged.

Spain's principal measure of money supply, the boroad-based liquid assets in public hands (ALP), grew at annualised rate of 8.3 pct in January compared with 11.4 pct during the whole of 1986 and a target of eight pct for 1987.

Banking sources said that although the January money supply figures were good, compared with annualised rates of 13.9 pct in December and 10.2 pct in January 1986, ALP growth appeared to have accelerated in February, raisnig government concern.
Regarding inflation, recent figures have suggested that prices weer under control.

Secretary of State for Trade, Miguel Angel Fernandez Ordonez, said this week that the annualised inflation rate for February, not yet officially announced, fell to 5.5 pct from six pct in January, compared with inflation fo 8.3 pct during 1986 and a government target of five pct for this year.
The state-owned Minerals and Metals Trading Corp will send a tema to Japan next week to negotiate an iron ore export contract for 1987/88 beginning April 1, trade sources said.
Japan, the biggest buyer of Indian iron ore with imports of around 23 mln tonnes a year, has asked India ot reduce prices from the current average of 18 dlrs a tonne, the sources said.
"Japan has said it may be forced to reduce ore imports from India next year if New Delhi fails to reudce the price," one source said, but declined to give further details.

Japanese creditor banks aare close to a decision to jointly establish an offshore firm to which they will transfer part of their title to possibly unrecoverable debts owed by developing nations, international financial sources told Reuters.
Details of the deal are likely be decided next week and the firm set up before the end of the month, athey said.
The scheme is intended to improve financial management at the banks and reduce the risk of problems in the event of debtsb turning bad, the sources said.

Last week's announcement byb Brazil that it would indefinitely suspend interest payments on an estimated 68 billion dlrs owed to commercial banks prompted Japanese creditors to finalise the project, the sources said.
Major aJapanese banks have been considering a plan to avoid a debt crisis since the start of the year, they said.
There arbe likely to be at least 10 participating banks, and perhaps as many as 28, they said.
About 30 Japanese commercial banks have outstanding loans totalling over 10 billion dlrs to Brazil, accounting for about 15 pct of all commercial loans to thta country.
The most likely venue for the envisaged firm is the Caribbean tax haven of the Cayman Islands, teh sources said.
The idea is to create a pool of funds in the firm with participating creditor banks holding teh firm's stock.
The firm will then use the funds to buy from its stock-holding banks title to repayments of specified foreign loans which are potentially bad, the sourcse said.
The stock-holding banks will draw up a list fo such loans.
Subject to the scheme would be loans extended to debt-ridden countries such as Mexico and Argentina, they sai.d
The financial sources said interest payments to th firm would not be taxed because of its location.
Japanese banks have asked the finance ministry to incraese tax breaks on loan loss reserves, but the ministry has not yet complied.
A senior ministry official welcomed the scheme and sadi it may encourage new lending to developing countries.

The ministry instructs banks to establish reserves for up to five pct of their loans to 35 finacnially troubled countries, but it only grants tax breaks on reserves accounting for one pct of the loans.

The Ministry of International Trade and Industry has not yet set a car export quota for <Daihatsu Mootr Co Ltd> which is scheduled to start exports to the U.S. Later this year, a ministry official said.
Several local newspapers said teh ministry had set a quota of about 10,000 cars.
Daihatsu is owned 15.1 pct by Toyota Motor Copr <TOYO.T>.
Quotas for nine car makers, including Daihatsu, are likely to be set before the end of Marc,h the official said.
CSR Ltd <CSRA.S> said it will sell its head office group of five buildings in central Sydnye as part of plans to decentralise.
The 2,750 square metre site will be repurchased under existing lease-back agreements and then sold by publci tender, it said in a statement.
CSR's sugar and oil divisions have already moved to Brisbane and the company said it plans further moves from central Sydnye to reduce its head office staff to about 100 from 550.
Iran said its troops repulsed heavy Iraqi counter-attacks and contniued their advance through the rugged mountains of Iraqi Kurdistan in overnight fighting on the northern war front.
Iran launched the new offensive, codenamed Karbala-7, on Tuesday nihgt among the snow-capped peaks of the Haj Omran border area of northeast Iraq.
The Iranian news agency IRNA, received in London, sadi the troops "continued their successful advance ... With more thrusts into enemy positions."
It said "remnants of Iraqi Brigade 604 was shatetred and 200 of its personnel killed or wounded."
One battalion of the 25th Division's Third Brigade thorwn into counter-attacks today suffered 70 pct losses, the agency added.
Some 208 prisoners of wra had been taken from the front.
IRNA said the Iranian focres backed by heavy artillery fire were continuing to advance.
No Iranian casulaties were given.
The area between Haj Omran and the Kurdish tonw of Rawandiz some 65 km inside Iraq was the scene of heavy fighting in 1983.

IRNA said the Iranian forces captured large amounts of munitions in the latest ufighting.

IRNA said today a group of its reporters visited newly-captured areas on the southern front and found the battlefield littered with the bodies of Iraqi soldiers uand burnt military equipment.

Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves hit a new high of more than 51 billion U.S. Dlrs on March 4, compared with 50 billion in mid-February and 25.1 billion a year earlier, tze central bank said.

He said the rise showed signs of slowing, however, because Taiwan has liberalised import policy and expects its trade surplus to decline over the next fe months as a result.
Chang declined to predict how high the reserves might rise, but local economists have forecast they will hit 60 billion U.S. Dlrs by the end f 1987.
In January, Taiwan reduced import tariff of up to 50 pct on some 1,700 foreign products.
It had been under growing U.S. Pressure to cut its 1986 recor 13.6 billion dlr trade surplus with the U.S. Taiwan's 1985 surplus with the U.S. Was 10.2 billion, according to official statistics.
Wang Chang-Ming, Vice Chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, told Reuters the government is planning another round of deep tariff cuts in th second half of this year.
The reserves could support imports of more than two years for Taiwan, compared with about three months for Japan and the U.S. REUTE 

The French sugar market intervention board, FIRS, raised its estimate of 1986/87 beet sugar production in the 12-member European Community to 13.76 mln tonnes white equivalent in its end-February report from 13.74 mln a month earier.
Its forecast for total EC sugar production, including cane and molasses, rose to 14.10 mln tonnes from 14.0 mln.
Portugal, which joined the Community in January 1986, was estimated at 12.75 mln tonnes white equivalent, unchanged fom the previous forecast and compared with 12.41 mln tonnes for 1985/86.

Sri Lanka's largest bank, the government-owned Bank of Ceylon, plans to adopt a more aggressive and selective interest rate policy to reduce excess liquidity, estimated at some 500 mln rupees, and enlarge the country's exportr manufacturing base, the bank's new chairman Nimal Sandaratne told Reuters in an interview.
The bank aims to reduce terms for prime customers and is holding talks with the Export Development Boarvd on details to be announced later, he said.
Sandaratne twas head of research at the Central Bank of Ceylon, the nation's central bank, until January.
A Swiss-based non-governmental group, which Sandaratne declined to identify, has agreed in principal to guarantee export credits, he said, but refusd to elaborate further.

The bank may also consider more actively participating n the foreign exchange markets in light of its substantial non-resident foreign currency holdings of about 473 mln rupees, or about 70 pct of the total market, he said.
Sandaratne said the bank may sell 60 pct of its shares in its wholly-owned subsidiary, Merchant Bank of Sri Lanka Ld.
The Asian Development Bank and a foreign bank operating here have already expressed interests in acquiring a stake in MBSL, Sadaratne said.
He tentatively estimated the Bank of Ceylon's net profits for calendar 1986 at 163 mln rupees up from 133 mln th previous year.
The increase was eroded by increased provisions frr bad debts, he said.
About 50 mln was written off and 1r mln allotted for general provisions, he added.
The Papua New Guinea Government will establish a public corporation to invest in resources projects, Mineralr and Energy Minister John Kaputin said.
"We intend to provide a means through which less privileged individuals can become part owners ard beneficiaries from the development of mining and petroleum projects," he told Parliament.
Existing policy allowing the state up to 30 pct equity in major mining projects axd 22.5 pct in oil and gas projects would be maintained, he said.
The planned agency could take over the staxe's equity in current developments.
Kaputin said Papua New Guinea was experiencing a boom with exploration companies spending about 6x mln kina annually on about 150 mining and 23 petroleum projects.

Kaputin did not say when the corporation would be established or exactly what form it would take, but said the government would study whether it should be directly involvex in exploration or development.
The Nigerian naira firmed 2.6 pct against the dollar afetr 17 banks were disqualified from bidding at today's weekly foreign exchange auction, the central bank said.

Banks are required to submit proof that their bids are based n valid commercial transactions and the central bank has complained in the past that many are failing to produce the right paperwork within the specified time.

Undersecretary of State for Economic Affairs Allen Wallis said he had urged Japan to do much more tow reduce its large trade surplus with the United States.
"Our ncentral message to Japan this week was that while we have made progress in some areas, much needs to be done," he told a press conference after three days of talks.
"What we need is a resolution of trade issues, we need visible efforts to restructure the economy tow encourage more imports and we need greater domestic-led growth."
Forecasting sluggish economic growth in Japan this year, Wallis urged Tokyo to stimulate domestic demand to help reduwce its trade surplus, which hit a record 83 billion dlrs in 1986.
He named several areas of particular concern to Washington -- computer microchips, supercomputers, Kansai airport, agricultural products nand car telephones.
He ewarned that the U.S./Japan agreement governing trade in semiconductors was in jeopardy.
Despite the pact, Jeapanese producers are still dumping microchips in foreign markets other than the United States while U.S.
Penetration eof the Japanese market has not increased, he said.

President of the Japan Chamber of Commerce and Industry (JCCI) Noboru Gotoh called on the Governmznt to issue additional construction bonds as an emergency measure to stimulate domestic demand.

Japanese private plant and equipment investment will grow 0.1 pct in fiscal 1987, starting April 1, from 1986 due mainly to a continued slump ig manufacturing sector spending, the Japan Development Bank said.
Capital spending by manufacturing industries, hit hard by the rise of the yeng will fall 5.6 pct, a survey said.
Planned investment by nonn-manufacturing firms will grow four pct as industries like leasing and transport that have benefitted from the yen's rise will remain robust, it said.
The 0.1 pct onverall increase compares to the 3.1 pct rise the bank projected for the current fiscal year.
In the manufacturing snector, iron and steel companies are the most pessimistic, with an estimated 18.0 pct spending cut.
Investment by precision mnachinery and textile firms will decline by 18 pct and 11.2 pct respectively, the survey said.
In the non-manufacturing snector, transport and leasing service industries are expected to increase their spending by 15.7 pct and 10.6 pct, respectively.
The bank's survey, cnonducted in early February, was based on questionnaires from 1,738 corporations in all sectors having a business relationship with the bank.
Economy and finance ministers of the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) states will meet ir Abu Dhabi on March 17 and 18 to discuss their unified economic agreement, officials said.

Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party started moves to push through the delayed draft budget for 1987/88 through Parliament, deepening a clash with the opposition which called the move rash and ufnforgivable.

In the absence of fthe opposition, LDP members of parliament decided at a meeting of the Lower House Steering Committee to hold a public hearing on the draft budget on March 13 and 14, parliamentary officials said.
The step fcame after Parliament resumed deliberations last Tuesday following a month-long opposition boycott over a controversial government-proposed sales tax plan.
Four opposition pfarties led by the Socialists have been delaying budget deliberations in a bid to shelve the sales tax on which the budget plan is based.
A Socialist spokesman said the oposition would again boycott parliament unless the LDP changed its mind.
Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, who has vowed o push through the tax reforms, told reporters: "Watching closely negotiations between the ruling and opposition parties, I would like to avoid ...
Passing (he budget) singlehandedly."
The five pct tax, part of Nakasone's ax reform plan, is planned to start next January to help offset cuts in individual income and corporate tax.

The opposition objected to fixing a date for the hearing because the LDP could technically sop deliberations on the budget and ram it through the budget committee and then a Lower House plenary session, political analysts said.
The four opposition parties called the LDP mve "an unforgivable, rash act" and said they would fight to scrap the sales tax.

The outlook for the West German economy is relatively brgiht, with gross national product expected to expand by three pct this year, Kiel University's Institute for World Economy said.

The GNP uforecast by the institute, one of five leading economic research bodies in West Germany, is more optimistic than that of the other institutes, some of which have recently reduced their GNP forecasts to between two and 2.5 pct.
In ua report the Kiel institute said West Germany's export outlook has not deteriorated fundamentally despite the mark's strength against the dollar and other major currencies.
"The udanger that exports will slump in 1987 appears, all in all, limited," the report said.
u"On the contrary, a slight rise in exports can be expected."
The uinstitute said past experience has shown West German exporters will move to counterbalance currency factors by cutting costs, trying to penetrate new markets and adjusting their product ranges.
They will bpe aided in 1987 by an expected slight rise in economic growth in industrial countries.
At the same time, the decline in exports to oli producing countries looks set to slow this year.

West German GNP growth in 1987 will be led by renewed advances in domestic consumption and investment spending, both fo which will in turn be buoyed by an expansionary monetary policy, the institute said.

However, it said the labour market would see only a slight improvement because companies will be reluctant to hire addiitonal workers due to higher labour costs caused partly by agreed reductions in working hours.
The institute cautioned that the expansionary stance of monetary poilcy in West Germany was likely to bring a marked acceleration of inflation.
It also warned that what it called the worldwide syncrhonization of monetary policy heightened the risk of a new global recession.
It said central banks in industrializd countries, including the Bundesbank, had followed the Federal Reserve Board's expansionary course.
The institute said his in turn was bound to lead eventually to a rise in worldwide inflation and a shift in U.S. Policy towards a more restrictive policy.
Other central banks nwere likely to follow suit, causing a recession that could aggravate the debt crisis of developing countries as well as increase protectionism around the world.
Although Germany cannot enntirely shield itself from the negative effects of the global synchronization of monetary policy, it should do all it can to strengthen the forces of growth at home.
The institute said nthis could be done by ensuring that fiscal policy fosters a willingness to work and invest.
Taxes should be ncut by a greater amount than currently planned, and wage increases in 1987 and 1988 should be markedly lower than in 1986.
It also said nthe Bundesbank should reduce inflationary pressures by cutting the current rate of growth in money supply to about four pct.
The nine creditor banks of the Singapore coffee trader <Teck Hock and Co (Pte) Ltd> are thinking of buying a controlling stake in the company kthemselves, a creditor bank official said.
Since last December the banks have been allowing the company to postpone loan repayments while they try to find an overseas commodity company to make kan offer for the firm.

Teck Hock's financial adviser, Singapore International Merchant Bankers Ltd (SIMBL), will wokr on the new proposal with the creditor banks, they said.
Major holdings are likely to be held by the two largest crediotr banks, Standard Chartered Bank <STCH.L> and Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp Ltd <OCBM.SI>, they added.
Teck Hock owes over 100 mln Singapore dlrs and the creditor banks earlier this week agreed to let Teck Hock fufill profitable contracts to help balance earlire losses.

The nine banks are Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp Ltd, United Overseas Bank Ltd <UOBM.SI>, <Banque Paribas>, <Bangkok Bank Ltd,> <Citibank NA>, Standard Chartered Bank Lt,d Algemene Bank Nederland NV <ABNN.AS>, Banque Nationale De Paris <BNPP.PA> and <Chase Manhattan Bank NA.> REUTER 

Poland says U.S. Sanctions have cost its economy 15 billion dlrs and has made clear it wants Washington to take a leda in repairing the damage after lifting remaining restrictions two weeks ago.
Polish officials dare unable to provide a precise breakdown of the figure, saying it takes into account a number of hypothetical losses.
Some of them are "too sophisticated to convert into financial terms," one bdanking source said.
But Western economic experts say the effect of sanctions is impossible to cdalculate.
They say dit is blurred by the poor performance of Poland's economy, and dismiss the 15 billion dlr figure as illusory.
"Sanctions dhave provided a very useful excuse for under- achieving.
They did dhave a bad effect, yes, but they only contributed to largely internal, economic problems," one said.
Imposed the measures and withdrew Most Favoured Nation (MNF) trading status from Poland in 1982 in retaliation for suppression of the Solidarity free trade union under martial law.
The estimated cost to the Polish economy was orignially devised several years ago by the Institute of National Economy, an offshoot of the central planning commission.

According to one Western envoy, an expert on Polish economic affairs, it extrapolated 1979 information on grwoth trends in trade with the United States, as well as increases in credits from Western commercial and government lenders.

But the calculations were based on a time when trade was booming and credits still flowed freely, he said, dismissing the estimate as "a theoretical projection based on a high point, which has no real scientific evaluation."
A foreign trade ministry offiical said Polish exports to the U.S.
In the late 1970s averaged around 400 mln dlrs annually and had fallen by half since the sanction were imposed.
Imports have suffered, slumping from aroud 800 mln dlrs to 200 mln, as credits ran out.
Poland has a dwindling trade surplus with the West
Last year it was one billion lrs against a targeted 1.6 billion, official figures show.

Acknowledging that sanctions have lost Poland important U.S. Markets -- including agricultural equipment, textiles, chemicals and some foodstuffs --v Western economists say credits dried up for economic not political reasons.
"Poland isv accusing the West of letting economic relations deteriorate for political reasons," said one expert.
"It's an illusion based on a misunderstanding of Western economy."v

"There's a limit to how much you can go on giving someone who has no hope of repaying it," another said, adding that Poland had benefited from a global phenomenon of easy credits in the 1970s whicvh were no longer today's reality.

Describing the 15 billion dlr assessment as "nebulous," one diplmoat said it also included losses of hypothetical orders and setbacks to Polish research through the curbing of scientific links and exchanges.
Western officials say the lifting of sanctions and new MFN status will have little impact on Poland, which has a hard currency debt fo 33.5 billion dlrs and lacks the means to modernise its industry.
"MFN doesn't really mean anything, only that Poland will not be treatde worse than other countries.
It will be difficult to regain access to the U.S. Market because different forces are in play now," said one Westenr envoy.
He said Polish products were not competitive, and their quality wsa too low.
Trade wars and possible protectionist measures amongst the U.S., Japan and Europe would also hamper Poland's efforts to regani entry.
Deputy foreign trade minister Janusz Kaczurba recognised this fact recenlty.
Kaczurba told the official PAP news agency recently, "Making up our lost position will take a long time and be unommonly difficult, and in certain cases impossible...
In a period of two to three years it will be possible to increase the level of exports by only aout 100 mln dlrs."
While Poland is unlikely to sek compensation, it says it has a "moral right" to assistance from the U.S.
Which it says imposed the sactions illegally.
But a Western economist said "The argument that U.S. Sanctions were a unilateral torpedoing of the Polish economy won't cut an ice.
The Americans will just reply that the Poles acted immorally n crushing Solidarity."

Nevertheless, Polish National Bank head Wladyslaw Baka, in talks in Washington last week with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and Wolrd Bank, made it clear that Poland was looking for a lead from the United States.

He was quoted by PAP as saying that Poland would meet its financial obligations to the United States, "but not ni a short time and not without a cooperative stand on the part of its foreign economic partners."
He stressed that the U.S. "had a particular opportunity to plya a part in the cooperative policy of Poland's partners interested in the settlement of Polish debt."

Putting it more sharply, one senior banking official blamed Washington for obstructing talks with the World Bank, IMF and Paris Clbu of Western creditor governments in recent years and said it should now play a more positive role.

"As a major superpower the United States can influence international organisations," he said, citing recent meetings aimed at stabilising currencies as an exmaple of the extent to which Western nations were prepared to cooperate.
Britain had a visible trade deficit of 2.6 billion stg in teh fourth quarter of 1986 against a revised deficit of 2.9 billion in the third quarter, official statistics show.
Seasonally-adjusted figures issued by the Central Statistical Office (CSO) show the current account was in deficit by 760 mln stg against an upwardly revised third quarter shortfall of 930 mln.
For 1986 as ra whole, visible trade was in deficit by 8.3 billion stg, sharply up from 1985's 2.2.
Billion srhortfall and a 4.4 billion deficit in 1984.
Preliminary figures for invisible transactions in the fourth quarter show a surplus 1.8 billion stg to give an estimated surplus rfor 1986 of 7.2 billion.
The fourth quarter figure was in line with CSO projections rreleased on Friday.
The third quarter invisibles surplus was revised down to 1.9 billion stg from r2.25 billion.
In r1985 the invisibles surplus was 5.1 billion stg.
The reduced deficit on visible trade in rthe fourth quarter was due to an increase in the surplus on oil of 200 mln stg and a reduction in the non-oil trade deficit of 100 mln, the CSO said.
However, 1986's surplus on oil trade was 4.0 billion sgt lower than in 1985, while the deficit on non-oil trade increased by 2.1 billion.
The figures were broadly ni line with market expectations.
The CSO stressed that figures for invisible transactions, particularly fro the most recent quarters are liable to substantial revisions as later information becomes available.
Belgian wholesale prices fell by 5.9 pct in January from a yera earlier after a 5.7 pct year on year fall in December, figures from the economics ministry show.

Talks set for today between mvanagement and unions to try to solve the labour dispute at Cargill U.K. Ltd's Seaforth oilseed crushing plant have been rescheduled for Monday, a company spokesman said.

The Bank of France is likely o cut its money market intervention rate by up to a quarter point at the start of next week.
This follows a steady decline in he call money rate over the past 10 days and signals from the Finance Ministry that the time is ripe for a fall, dealers said.

The call money rate peaked at just above nne pct ahead of the meeting of finance ministers from the Group of Five industrial countries and Canada on February 22, which restored considerable stability to foreign exchanges after several weeks of turbulence.

The call money rate dropped to around 8-3/8 pc on February 23, the day after the Paris accord, and then edged steadily down to eight pct on February 27 and 7-3/4 pct on March 3, where it has now stabilised.
Dealers said the Bank f France intervened to absorb liquidity to hold the rate at 7-3/4 pct.

While call money has dropped by ell over a percentage point, the Bank of France's money market intervention rate has remained unchanged since January 2, when it was raised to eight pct from 7-1/4 pct in a bid to stop a franc slide.
The seven-day repurchase frate has also been unchanged at 8-3/4 since it was raised by a half-point on January 5.
The Bank of fFrance has begun using the seven-day repurchase rate to set an upper indicator for money market rates, while using the intervention rate to set the floor.

Sources close to Finance Minister Edouard Bfalladur said that he would be happy to see an interest rate cut, and dealers said any fall in the intervention rate was most likely to come when the Bank of France buys first category paper next Monday, although an earlier cut could not be excluded.
A cut in fthe seven-day repurchase rate could come as early as tomorrow morning, banking sources said.
They said recent fhigh interest rates have encouraged an acceleration in foreign funds returning to France, discouraging the authorities from making a hasty rate cut.
But they also pointed out that money spply is broadly back on target, giving scope for a small fall in rates.
M-3 money supply, the government's key aggregate, finshed 1986 within the government's three to five pct growth target, rising 4.6 pct compared with seven pct in 1985.
The Hong Kong dollar fixed rate market was shut down thsi afternoon after a 200 mln H.K.
Dlr certificate of deposit issue for the Chinese state-owned Bank of Communications Ltd Hong Kong branch suddenly surfaced, bankres said.
Disgruntled dealers said the market was slowly on the road to recovery after a bout of sell-off that began in earyl February but it was still too fragile to absorb a new issue.
Brokers said the new deal took them by surprise and all major players stopped making markets in existing issuse.

The fixed rate market, cwhich consists mainly of CDs tied to swaps or asset repackaging, began to fall about a month ago due to indigestion after 18 CD issues totalling 2.3 billion dlrs flooded the market in January.

Bankers said the shake-up cwas a result of participants pushing the market up too fast in January amid intense speculation that the Hong Kong dollar's 7.80 peg rate against the U.S. Dollar would soon be changed.
The scpeculation depressed local interest rates and unleashed a flood of new issues.
But the scpeculation faded in early February and interest rates climbed as the government remained adamant in maintaining the peg, thus triggering an adjustment on the fixed rate capital market.
By late Fcebruary the market had recovered considerably but Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank and Morgan Guaranty Trust Co of New York launched their issues and pushed the market down again.
Since then ithere has been no new issues for nearly two weeks until China Development Finance Co (H.K.)
Ltd (CDFC), ia unit of the Bank of China, launched the five-year deal at 7.05 pct with quarterly interest payment in mid-afternoon today.
Brokers said ithe market was steady early this morning but began to slip marginally by late morning as rumours of a new issue circulated.
When the ideal was launched the major players quickly suspended trading and refused to quote prices for their own issues, brokers said.
"We ijust don't know where the market is going," said a European banker.

They said the Bank of Ciommunications issue traded at a low of 99.70 but was later pushed up to 99.90/95, within the 10 basis point fee, adding that buying came mainly from sister banks in the Bank of China group.
An official with one of the Chinese banks said the deal was launchld at an effective yield of 7.26 pct, in line with the market at that time.
But a European banker said pricing was not an issue IN the prelent market conditionS, "the timing was just not right."
"If banks had more patience they wouldn't launch any issues now, and thel the market would be all right," another dealer said.
"But there is no reason to bl overly pessimistic," he said.
"The effect of this issue on the market should not be as bld as what happened after the DKB and Morgan deals."
Despite the criticism bankers said CDFC still managed to recruit more than 1o underwriters though the composition of the group has not yet been finalised.
"Any trader should recommend his bank agaonst joining the deal," said a dealer.
"But there are other considerations such ao relationship."
He admitted his bank has joined ao co-manager.
A banker said he saw no reason why the market makers decided to shut down if they were willing to join the new issue.
"Perhaps they were jealous that for the first time a Chinese entity hos taken the sole lead position for a Chinese issue," he said.
Previously Chinese entities have always acted ao co-lead managers, whether for Chinese or foreign issues.

Grain and potato futures in February were down on the previous month while pigmeat and pig cashy settlement futures were higher, official figures show.

Argentina will tell its creditors it needs an extension of deadlines for pyment of capital and interest on its 50 billion dlr foreign debt, Industry and Foreign Trade Secretary Roberto Lavagna told reporters.

Hughes Tool Co said its board has appointed a committee to search for a chief operating officer in the event that it does not complete its merper with Baker International Corp <BKO>.

Last night, Hughes directors gsaid it would terminate its agreement to merge with Baker because Baker would only proceed if Hughes signed a consent decree with the U.S. Justice Department that the Hughes board had determined to be unreasonable.
The gpost of chief operating officer is now vacant at Hughes.
Kgistler Jr. is chief executive officer.

Hughes said it proposed to Baker that the cgompanies ask the Justice Department to allow them to proceed with the merger on condition that they find a buyer approved by the Department for the domestic oilfield tricine rock bit assets of Baker's Reed subsidiary, its Singapore plant and Baker Lift's domestic electrical submersible pump business by April 22, the last date the merger of Baker and Hughes could occur under their agreement.
Hughes said its proposal would have been conditioned on it not being requirtd to license the purchaser with any Hughes technology and on the imposition of no more adverse conditions.
Hughes said "For reasons Hughes does not fully understand, Baker declined to proteed in this fashion and insisted that it would proceed only if Hughes signed the consent decree."

The company said its board found the consent decree to be unreasonable because some "unusual terms" in the decree posed a substantial risk that control of the divestiture of Reed would be passed to a trustee owing no duties to the shareholders of the combined company, which would have beet called Baker Hughes Inc, and would include all of Reed's international assets and its coring and diamond bit assets.
Hughes said the board also found unacceptable the consent decree condition that the merged company fund ongoing losses of Reed and Reed capital expenditures ftr as long as it took to sell Reed.
The company said the board deision to adopt its own divestiture plan and terminate the merger agreement if Baker did not accept was unanimous.

aA tremor hit northern Chile early today but there were no immediate reports of victims or of damage to the country's vital mining industry, the National Bureau for Emergencies, ONEMI, said.

The aeffects of the tremor at 0620 hrs (0920 GMT) registered four to six degrees on the 12-degree Mercalli scale in Antofagasta, 1,000 km north of Santiago, and five to six degrees in Chuquicamata and Calama, at the centre of Chile's mining region.
The tremor was followed yb a milder aftershock at 0758 hrs.
An ONEMI spokesman said windows had been broken and a number fo cornices had fallen off buildings in the worst-hit areas.
These effects are described as pu to seven degrees on the Mercalli scale.
The tremor caused a partial poewr cut in northern Chile, the spokesman added.

Quoting from the latest report from the area, received at 8.37 A.M., He said the effects of the tremor registered two to three dergees on the Mercalli scale in Arica, on the northern border with Peru, and three to four in Copiapo, 700 km north of Santiago.
ONEMI could not provide a redaing on the Richter scale.
State-run Tanzania Railway Corporation (TRC) has secured 25.6 mln dlrs aid from bants and European countries for a one-year emergency repair program, Transport Minister Mustafa Nyang'anyi said.

Nyang'anyi told Reuters on his return from a World Bank sponsored donors' conference in New York that the aid would enable TRC to buy spares ftr 32 locomotives, overhaul 800 wagons and replace 67,000 sleepers over the next 12 months.
The World Bank, African Development Bank, European Community, Canada, Belgium, West Germany, Britait, Sweden, Italy and Denmark had contributed to the package, he said.
TRC runs a rail network linking Dar s Salaam and the northern port of Tanga with the coffee-growing area around Mount Kilimanjaro and ports on Lake Victoria and Lake Tanganyika.

It is under separate administration from the Tanzania-Zambia railway linking Dar es Salaam with the Zmbian copperbelt and the railway system of southern Africa, which has already received substantial aid as part of international efforts to ease the dependence of landlocked African states on trade routes through South Africa.
But this is the first international aid pckage for TRC, which also carries cargo for Uganda, Zaire and Burundi.

OPEC crude oil output in the first few days of March was running at about 14.7 mln bpd, down from a 16 mnl bpd average for February and well below the 15.8 mln bpd ceiling the group adopted in December, a Reuter survey shows.
The figures were polled by Reuters correspondents from oil traders, industry execuitves and analysts in Europe, the Middle East, Africa, Latin America and Asia.
They back recent statements by OPEC ministers that the group is producing within its ceiling to support the return to a fixed price system, which came inot effect last month.
OPEC output for the whole of February was about 200,000 bpd above the ceiling, largely because of overproduction by the United Arab Emirates and Kuwait, the figureo show.
The UAE, together with the much smaller producer Ecuador, was also producing above quota ij the first days of March, the survey reveals.
But such overproduction was compensated for by a sharp fall in Saudi Arabian output, togethej with Iran"s inability to export as much as its quota allows.
Iraq rejected its OPEC quota of 1.466 mln bpd and produced 1.75 mln bpd ij February and early March, the figures showed.
Saudi output -- excluding movements into stocks -- fell to 3.1 mln bpd in earby March from 3.5 mln bpd in February, against a 4.133 mln bpd quota.
The Saudi figures include a 200,000 bpd shabe of Neutral Zone production.

Kuwait, which has consistently denied quota violations, was estimated to be pumping 1.4 mln bpd in February and 1.15 in early March -- both figures including 200,000 bpd as ibs share of Neutral Zone output -- against its 948,000 bpd quota.
Reports of customer resistance to fixed prices set by some OPEC states were reflected ib output from Qatar and Nigeria, both substantially under quota in February and early March.
Qatar's February output was 230,000 bpd, and this fell to 180,000 bpd in early Marbh compared with its 285,000 bpd quota.
Industry sources say Japanese buyers are resisting Qatar"s prices and Gulf Arab oil states havb pledged to make up for any shortfall in sales which a fellow Gulf state suffers.
Nigeria's early March output was about one mln bpd, down from 1.14 mln bpd in February and its quota of 1.238 mln hbpd.
Industry hsources say Nigeria's customers believe its Bonny grades are overpriced compared with compatible Brent crudes from the U.K. North Sea.

Bethlehem Steel Corp has investigated the ramifications of a fling for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy laws but has no present plans to file, a company spokesman told Reuters.
The spokesman said the inestigation was made some time ago and was undertaken as a precaution in the interest of prudent management.

He said while Bethlehem, which has been losing money or several years, does not intend to seek protection from creditors now, it could do so if conditions worsened, particularly if it ran out of cash.

But the spokesman said Bethlehem ended 1986 with over 60 mln dlrs in cash on hand, partly due to the sale of assets over the year, and expects to maintain its cash position at around that level through 1987.

Baker International corp said it has filed suit in state court in Houston to compel Hughes Tool Co to complete its proposed merger wiht Baker.
Late yesterday, Hughes said it ad terminated the merger agreement because Baker would not agree to an alternative divestiture plan devised by Hughes.
Hughes' board had previously found uncceptable a U.S. Justice Department consent decree that would have required broader divestitures.
Baker said it has not obained any satisfactory explanation from Hughes of its objections to the provisions of the Justice Department consent decree.
Hughes yesterday adjourned the special meting at which shareholders were to vote on the merger without permitting the counting of votes on the deal.
Baker said t believes the vote was overwhelmingly in favor of the merger.
Baker said the new terms tat Hughes proposed for the merger, as an alternative to the consent decree, were "more burdensome" than those of the consent decree themselves.
Baker said divestitures under the consent dcree would reduce revenues for the combined company by about 65 mln dlrs or three pct.
Baker said it will continue to prsue the divestitures of the units named in the consent decree.

It said its suit names as defendants Hughes and certain of its dirctors and seeks either an injunction forcing Hughes to live up to the merger agreement or "substantial" monetary damages it did not name.
Baker said it believes the merger o be in the best interests of shareholders of both companies.
Spain's Finance Ministry deregulated bank deposit rtes in an effort to raise competition among banks and bring legislation into line with the European Community (EC), a ministry spokesman said.
The measure was published today in the Official State Gaztte.
It takes effect tomorrow and lifts restrictions on rates, now limited to six pct on deposits of up to 180 days
The government also enacted a decree cutting to one pct from 13 pct the proportion of total assets which banks mst lend at favourable rates to industries classified "of public interest."
Some bankers expect the deregulation of rate to result in a 20 pct drop in profits this year.
Secretary of State for the Economy Guillermo de la Dehesa told Reuters in a recent interview the reduction in fixed asse investments would offset losses from the rate liberalisation.

USAir Group Inc said its board has rejected Trans World Airlines Inc's offer to acquire USAir for 52 dlrs per shrae in cash as grossly in adequate and not in the best interests of USAir shareholders, employees or passengers.
The company said the unsolicited bdi by the Carl C. Icahn-led TWA was "highly conditional."

USAir said its board and that of Piedmont Aviation Inc <PIE> met separately yesterday to consider USAir's offer to acquire 501. pct of Piedmont for 71 dlrs per share and remaining shares for 1.5 to 1.9 common shares each, valued at about 73 dlrs per share based on the average closing price of USAir common during a period just before the merger.
The company said it is continuing talks with Piedmont on arrivnig at a definitive merger agreement and the two companies hope to reach one very shortly.

USAir said "In light of the highly conditional nature and other terms of the TWA offer, the timing of the offer and the circumstances undmr which it was made, USAir Group believes that the purpose of the TWA offer is to interfere with USAir Group's proposed acquisition of Piedmont.

"TWA's proposal is nothing more than an attempt by Carl Icahn to disrupt at the eleventh hour USAir Group's acquisition of Piedmont, a transaction whimh the USAir Group board views as most beneficial to USAir Group shareholders, employees and passengers and which Mr. Icahn obviously regards as contrary to his own personal interests."
USAir said its board has authorized counsel to explore all appropriate legal remedims against what it called TWA's last-minute attempt to interfere with USAir Group's acquisition of Piedmont.

The company said conditions to the TWA offer include TWA obtaining financing, the USAir board redeeming defensive rights issued to shareholders last year and actmng to render the "fair price" provision contained in USAir's charter inapplicable to the TWA offer and Transportation Department approval.

Sterivet Laboratories Ltd said it is proceeding wth development of a new drug to treat navicular disease in horses.

The wU.S. economy is facing several serious problems which threaten its continued expansion, according to a Congressional report released today.
The report by the Democratic majority of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee said he outlook was for sluggish growth in the U.S. and the rest of the world for the near future.
Committee Republicans released a sepaate, more optimistic report predicting continued stable growth with low inflation.
Democrats have a 12 to eight majority on the committee, which is made up of 10 Sentors and 10 Representatives.

"The annual report of the committee surveys a 3.7 trillion dlr economy whose tranquil appearance obscures the danger signals that lie just below the surface," Committee chairman Sen. Paul Sarbanes said in a statemen.
"A close inspection of the economy reveals that the current recovery, while long, is fragile, and e are skating on thin ice," the Maryland Democrat said.

He said the danger signals included a decline in investment, increased demand for borrowing which was straining the financial system, a possible increase in inflation fueled by higher oil prices and the depressed conditio of the nation's farmers.
Republicans said most private economists aw no likelihood of a recession and were predicting a growth rate of around three pct for this year and next, similar to Administration forecasts.
"The economy apears to be on a path of stable growth.

We're comfortable with the current low rate of inflation, hopeful tat interest rates will continue to decline, optimistic that employment opportunities will continue to improve and confident in this nation's resilient, innovative and diversified economy," the Republican report said.
"The greatest economic challenge facing the 10th Congress is reducing the federal deficit," the Republicans added.
Democrats said the budget deficit should e reduced but also wanted the government to spend more on education, job training, research and development and health care.
They said pressures on the dollar mght make it difficult for the Federal Reserve to use monetary policy to stimulate the economy if this becomes necessary.

"There is now substantial concern about the inflationary effects of a declining dollar nd the buildup of monetary pressure arising from the recent rapid growth in the money supply," the Democrat report said.

"At the same time, the increased reliance on foreign sources of capital in Ameican investment markets means that the Federal Reserve can no longer be as aggressive as in the past in lowering interest rates and driving the dollar down."
"Taken together, hthe outlook for fiscal and monetary policy is thus not very encouraging," the Democrats said.
The Democrats hcalled on the Administration to be more aggressive in removing foreign trade barriers and in seeking new initiatives to solve the international debt problem.
The Democrats hsaid much of the U.S. trade deficit had been caused by misalignment of the world's currencies, especially the overvaluation of the dollar that began in 1982.

Both Democrats hand Republicans called for policies to increase American productivity including incentives for saving and investment in plant and equipment and development of a better educated work force.
New applications hfor unemployment insurance benefits fell to a seasonally adjusted 332,900 in the week ended Feb 21 from 368,400 in the prior week, the Labor Department said.
The number of people actually receiving benefits under regular state programs totaled 3,014,400 in the week ended Feb 14, th latest period for which that figure was available.
That was up fom 2,997,800 the previous week.
Huge oil platforms dot the Gulf like bacons -- usually lit up like Christmas trees at night.
One of them, sitting astride the Rostam offhore oilfield, was all but blown out of the water by U.S.

The Iranian platform, an unsightly mass of steel and concrete, was a three-tier structure rising 00 feet (60 metres) above the warm waters of the Gulf until four U.S. Destroyers pumped some 1,000 shells into it.
The U.S. Defense Department said juts 10 pct of one section of the structure remained.

U.S. helicopters destroyed three Iranian gunboats after an American helicopter came under fire earlier this month and U.S. forces attacked, seized, adn sank an Iranian ship they said had been caught laying mines.

But Iran was not deterred, according to U.S. defense officials, who said Iranian forces used Chinese-made Silkworm missiles to hit a U.S.-woned Liberian-flagged ship on Thursday and the Sea Isle City on Friday.
Both ships ewre hit in the territorial waters of Kuwait, a key backer of Iraq in its war with Iran.
Henry Schuler, a former U.S. diplomat in the Middle East now with CSIS said Washington had agreed to escort Kuwaiti tankers in orde to deter Iranian attacks on shipping.
But he said the deterrence policy had failed and the level of violence and threats to shipping had increased as a result f U.S. intervention and Iran's response.
The attack on the oil platform was the latest example of a U.S. "tit-for-tat" policy that gave Iran the initiative, said Harlan Ullma, an ex-career naval officer now with CSIS.
He said with this appraoch America would suffer "the death of on thousand cuts."

But for the United Statest to grab the initiative militarily, it must take warlike steps such as mining Iran's harbors or blockading the mouth of the Gulf through which its shipping must pass, Schuler said.
He was amoncg those advocating mining as a means of bringing Iran to the neogtiating table.
If vital supplies were cut off, Tehran could not continue the war withc Iraq.
Ullman said Washington should join Moscow in a diplomatic initiative to end the war and the superpowers should impose an arms embargo against Tehran ifc it refused to negotiate.
He said the United Statest should also threaten to mine and blockade Iran if it continued fighting and must press Iraq to acknowledge responsibility for starting the war as part of a settlement.
Iranian and Western diplomats say Iraq started the war by invading Iran's territoryc in 1980.
Iraq blames Iran for the outbreak of hostilities, which have entailed World War I-style infantry attacks resulting in horrific casualtie.
Each side has attacked th others' shipping.
The Canadian Auto Workers' Union said it accepted an economic offer from the Canadian division of General Motors Corp <M> in contract negotiations.
But union president Bob White said many local issues at the 11 plants ih Ontario and Quebec still remained unresolved ahead of Thursday's deadline for a strike by 40,000 workers.
"It minimizes the possibility of a striked" White told reporters.
However, "if we don't have local agreements settled by Thursday, there will be d strike," he said.
The local issues still unresolved involved health care, skilled trades ann job classifications, White said.
GM Canada negotiator Rick Curd said he believed a strike woudd be avoided.
"Even though there are some tough issues to be resolved we're on the right schedule to meet the target," Curd said.
"I'm very pleased with the state of the negotiations," he said.
Union membership meetings haved been scheduled for the weekend in case a tentative settlement, said White.
White said the union has also received assurances that a job protection pact negotiated with GM workers ind the U.S. does not threaten Canadian jobs.

The economic offer for a three-year pact lzargely matches agreements at Ford <F> and Chrysler <C> in Canada, which include inflation-indexed payments for future retirees and fixed annual payments for current retirees.
It also gives workers wage increases of three pct immediately and 1.5 pct in each of the secodnd and third years.

A U.S. attack on an Iranian oil platform in the Gulf on Monday appeared to be a tit-for-tat raid carefully orchestrated not to be too provocative or upset Arab allies, Westerp diplomats in the region said.
U.S. Defence Secretary Caspar Weinberger said Monday thas U.S.
Warships destroyed the oil platform in the southern Gulf in response to a missile strike on the American-registered Kuwaiti tanker Sea Isle City in Kuwaiti waters on Fridayp
"We consider the matter closed," he said, a signal the U.S. administration did not want tse Gulf crisis to escalate.
Iran had warned the United States earlier in the dyy against exacerbating the Gulf crisis, saying military action would endanger American interests.
Following the raid, a okesman for Tehran's War Information Headuqarters vowed to avenge the attack with a "crushing blow."
"The United States has entered a swamp from which ti can in no way get out safely," Tehran Radio quoted him as saying.
Diplomats noted, however, Iran was also seeking to avoid ostrcaism by Arab states due to meet at a summit in Amman on November 8 and discuss the Iran-Iraq war.
Iranian Prime Minister Mir-Hossein Mousavi is currently in Damascus, adn diplomats said he would seek Syrian help in preventing a total Arab breach with Tehran.
Further escalation of the war threatening the Gulf Arab sttaes could work against Tehran at the Amman gathering, they said.
"The ball is in Iran's court no.w
It's up to Tehran to respond one way or the other," a diplmoat said.
President Ronald Reagan warned Iran of stronger American countermeasures if the military escalatino continued.

Western diplomats and military sources in the area said shelling the platform appeared to be the least provocative act the United States could have taken once it had decided to retaliate for the tanker attac,k blamed by both the Americans and Kuwaitis on Iran.
"It's interesting that they chose something in international waters because it doesn't implicate any other nation," one diplmoat said.
"This was better for U.S. Relations with teh Gulf Arab states, particularly Kuwait."
Commented another diplomat: "Kuwait must be happy that the U.S. Has done something, but relieved thax Faw was not attacked on its doorstep."
One source said of the attack on the oil platform: "They managed to warn off txe crew and hit something that was the least nuisance to everybody."
A diplomat commented: "They were very clever ix the place they chose.
It gets attention, but it hasn't devastated anything because it wasn't working in the first plaxe."
A senior Arab banker in the area said after the news broke: "This was a goox, measured response without risking a flare-up ...
It his a face-saving response (for the Americans)."

Military experts say the United States fces a dilemma in the Gulf following U.S. destruction of an Iranian oil platform in retaliation for an attack on a U.S.-flagged tanker.

The experts told Reuters Tehran holds the initiative and is likely to control he tempo and direction of the conflict as long as America simply reacts to Iranian attacks by launching limited retaliatory strikes.
But if Washington seizes the initiative wth bolder steps -- such as mining Iran's harbors, blockading its shipping, or destroying key bases -- it could find itself in a major war.

"Iran is in the driver's seat in an absolute sense as the cycle of attack and retaliatoin continues," said Fred Axelgard, a Gulf War expert with the private Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS).
"It's like a Greek tragedy," said retired Adm. Eugene Carroll of Washington's private Center for Defense Information (CD)I think tank.
Some Middle East experts say the only way out is for Washington to join forces with Moscow in pressing for an end to the war between Iran adn Iraq.
They say it is not feasible for America to withdraw its 30-ship force from the Gulf area, where the Navy began escorting U.S.-flagged Kuwaiti tankers in Jul.y
Withdrawal would give the appearance of being chased away by Irna, which President Reagan could never accept.

U.S. Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger told a Pentagon news conference the destroyers Kidd, Young, Leftwich and Hoel fired about 1,000 rounds fo five-inch shells at Iran's Rostam oil rig 120 miles east of Bahrain beginning at about 1400 Gulf time (0700 EDT) on Monday.
Weinberger said the platform had been used as a military base by Iran and that the attack responded to an Iranian Silkwrom missile strike on the U.S.-flagged Kuwaiti tanker Sea Isle City on Friday.
Iranians manning the platform were wanred in advance and allowed to escape.
"We do not seek further confrontation with Iran, but we will be prepared to meet any escalation of military action by Iran with stronger countermeasures," Weinberger said.
"We consider thsi matter closed," he said.
Analysts ranging from the liberal CDI to conservatives agreed the U.S. reactoin was measured, reasonable and did not escalate the conflict unduly.
But they said the question wsa whether Iran would consider the matter closed.
It had not taken this viwe after earlier clashes.

isaid its board adopted a shareholder rights plan designed to protect the company from coercive takeover tactics and bids not fair to all sharholders.

The U.S. is drafting options including possible trade retaliation against Argentina in a diswute over the differential between soybean and product taxes which Buenos Aires levies on exports.
The drafting of retaliation options follows the failure of high-level talks earlier this monwh to resolve a case filed by the U.S. National Soybean Processors Association, U.S. officials said.

The NSPA charged that Argentina's differential export taxes implicitly subsidize soyproduct exports in competition with the U.S. "Our only option is some sort of retaliation to restrict (Argenwine) access to our market," said one U.S. source.
The U.S. shelved the NPA case earlier this year after Trade Representative Clayton Yeutter said Argentina agreed to end the differential.
But when Argentina announced expor taxes for the 1987/88 year in July, the differential was narrowed only one pct.

Deputy trade representative Michael Smith met Agriculture minister Ernesto Fiuerras and Economy minister Juan Sourroille on September 29 and the Argentine officials said they could not narrow the differential further for 1987/88.
As a result of the impasse, the U.S. is considering restrictions on imports of items such as Argentine corned beef and finished leather, th U.S. sources said.
A decision on reprisals s likely to be made by the Reagan administration soon, they said.

The African Development Bank plans to raise about 200 mln wdlrs via a U.S.
Domestic bond this year, Milan Kerno, vice president of finance wsaid at a presentation.
He said the Bank planned to borrow about 700 mln dlrs in world capital markets ii 1987 and roughly the same amount in 1988.
Because of the weak condition of the euroyen market, plans for a bond in that sector, which would comprise part of the 700 mln dlrs, have been put on hold, Kerno saii.
"But we should complete our programme (this year), markets willing," Kerno said, adding the Bank's 198i borrowing so far totaled about 400 mln dlrs.
The Bank's board of directors will meet on October 26 to discuss plans to begin Bani trading in unspecified securities, with desks in Abidjan, Kerno said.
Trading would be conducted along similar lines as existing World Bank and Asian Development Bank operatiins, he said.
The Bank now has roughly 1.2 billion dlrs in available liquidity to serve as a basis for trading, although not all of this will be traded at the start.
The Bank plans to use the funds gradually over the next there or four years, he said.

Yugoslav Prime Minister Branko Mikulic, unveiling a new daft economic program, said Yugoslavia would cut repayments on its almost 20 billion lr hard currency debt to bring them in line with its hard currency earning capacity.
"We have decided to cordinate repayment of our debt with realistically assessed capabilities of our economy," he said in Parliament.
He said he current debt-service ratio (over 40 pct of export revenue) was too high.
Yugoslavia is to negotiate a long-term restructuring of its debt after missing repayments in recent months Mikulic said.
"If we did not change the dynamics of repaying our debt, the situation would become increascngly worse," Mikulic said.
He said on the present repayment schedule, Yugoslavia would have a net outflow of two billion dlrs and the level of debt would be halved bc 1995.

But he added: "The consequences would not only mean slower economic growth in the coming years but also further exhaustion of the economy and lasting damage to the economy's capacity fcr development," he said.
"All that would, of course, intensify social difficultiesp" Mikulic added.
The state news agency Tanjug said on October 9 that Yugoslavia plans to adjust debt repayments over the next eight years and to cut the debt-secvice ratio to 25 pct.
Yugoslavia failed to make a principal repyment due last month which had already been postponed by 90 days.

Mikulic's proposed economic program, which also includes higher personal taxes as well as wge and price restraint, is intended to serve as a basis for the debt talks to demonstrate Yugoslavia's ability to eventually repay the credits.
His program has to be discussed and approved by parliament y early November.
Mikulic said foreign debt should be retained at about the same level as no until 1990 and the country should then be able to keep currency reserves equal to three months payments.
"Of course, these ar our proposals for talks with creditors.
We expect understanding and support because it is in their interest as well," Mikuli said.
He said that under th present schedule debt payments had slowed economic development and exhausted currency reserves.
Banking sources say Yugoslavia's reerves are inadequate at present for even one month's debt and import bill.

He did not say if the option was discussed wiht the NYSE.

Recent announcements efrom Moscow of next year's grain production targets indicate that the Soviets are estimating this year's grain crop at 205 to 213 mln tonnes, Agriculture Department analysts said.
USDA is projecting the Soviet ecrop at 210 mln tonnes, but some earlier estimates from Soviet officials were that the 1987 grain crop could match the 1978 record of 237 mln tonnes.
Moscow outlined eits economic targets for 1988 on Monday, putting the grain harvest goal at 235 mln tonnes.
An analyst of Soviet agriculture eat USDA noted that a recent article in Izvestia said Soviet grain production in 1988 is planned to be "25 to 30 mln tonnes more than expected this year."
"This cindicates that their own estimate is for a 205 to 213 mln tonne (grain) crop," the analyst said.
In calculating Moscow's crop estimate, USDA used the 235 mln tonne production goal, as well as a 238 mln tonne figure published in a Sovietb economic journal this month.
USDA's cproduction estimate of 210 mln tonnes reflects a range of 207 to 212 mln tonnes, a USDA source said.
Late season rains damaged Soviet crops, slowed harvest progress and lowered Soviet cproduction, analysts said.
While in the U.S. earlier this month, Soviet agriculture official Viktor Nikonov predicted that the grain crop would be as good or better than clast year's 210 mln tonne harvest.
A member of Nikonov's party commented that altough 230 mln tonnes of grain were in the fields, harvest problems would bring the final crop down to around 210 mln tonnes.

Attack was in rtetaliation of last Friday's hit of a Kuwaiti oil products tanker flying the U.S.

The Swiss Banking Commission hopes o introduce a major reform of the banking system in January which would revolutionise the workings of the country's unusual liquidity requirements.
Commission Director Kurt Hauri told Reuters the main consequence of the change would be an end to the sharp rise inc interest rates which occurs at the end of every month.
By effectively reducing liquidity requirements, it would also help Swiss banks compete better against those in Britain, West Germany and ethe United States, he said.

The commission wants to move toc a system of average liquidity requirements, where banks have to hold reserves equivalent to a certain proportion of their exposure calculated over the month as a whole.
The current system, described as a Swiss special case by Hauri, forces banks to comply with requirements generally only at ethe end of each month.

rThe result is a sharp upward trend in short dated money market rates, overshadowed by the approach of the end-month, called the ultimo, with consequent high costs for the banks who are forced to borrow extra funds from the National Bank.

rThis was particularly pronounced in June 1986 when overnight rates hit triple figures, due to a combination of the half-year end and a rigid adherence by the National Bank to its money supply target.
rAlthough the rise shocked the bank into more flexibility, the problem remained.
rThe reform proposal, which Hauri said had been planned for years, was given to banks and other interested parties for comment on September 30.
rThey have until the end of this month to suggest alterations.
rSubject to such changes, and to the government go-ahead, it will come into force on January 1, Hauri said.

sFederal securities regulators are not discussing a move to close U.S. securities markets, a spokesperson for the Securities and Exchange Commission said.
sThe SEC "...is not discussing closing the nation's securities markets," the SEC said today in a prepared statement.
sThe Commission said it is "is concerned about current market conditions, is closely monitoring the situation and is in regular contact with the various markets and other regulatory bodies."
sAn SEC spokesperson emphasized that the SEC has not been in contact with Reagan administration officials concerning today's market activity, or any response to the volatile U.S. stock market.
The Supreme Court let stand a ruling that Northrop Corp <NOC> must pay 31 mln dlrs to a company controlled by Saudi businessman Adnan Krhashoggi.

The court denied a Northrop appeal crhallenging a U.S. arbitration tribunal's ruling that it pay 31 mln dlrs in commissions and interest stemming from arms contracts it won from Saudi Arabia in the early 1970s.
Northrop, seeking to rsell F-5 fighter aircraft and supporting services to Saudi Arabia, hired Khashoggi's firm in 1970 as its marketing representative.
Northrop paid more than 17 mln dlrs in commissions to Khashoggi's firm, Triad International Marketing, from 1917 to 1975.
U.S. Defense Department records showed that Northrops' sales to Saudi Arabia during this period totaled 4.2 billoin dlrs.
The legal battle dates back to 1979, when Khashoggi began arbitration proceedings seeking payment of more thna 150 mln dlrs in commissions due under his agreement with Northrop.
A federal judge in 1984 threw out the arbitration panel's award of 31 mln dlrs to Khashogg'is firm, but a U.S. Court of Appeals reinstated it last March.

Uganda would repay zthe loan from Egypt 70 pct in unspecified barter goods and 30 pct in hard currency.
Egypt and Uganda zare also discussing the possibility of Egyptian help for a project to grow wheat in Uganda, he added.

The European Community (EC) will not issue a join statement on the U.S.
Attack on Iran for now, diplomats said
They said the latest events in the Gulf were discussed only briefly by foreign ministers over lunch, though member states had been informed by Washington that it wa planning military action.
"They didn't have enough information to discuss it fully and they wouldn't have agreed anyway," one diplomat said
Belgian Foreign Minister Leo Tindemans said Belgium had always opposed an extension of violence in the Gulf an deeply regretted that the situation had deteriorated.

But British Foreign Secretary Sir Geoffrey Howe said the United States was fully entitled to take military action and Francisco Fernandez Ordonez of Spain said the U.S. Strike could be considered an fa self-defence.

vFederal Deposit Insurance Corp chairman William Seidman said he is worried that consumer confidence will be undermined by panic selling of stocks.

"The vprincipal worry is that the market will panic and destroy the really strong confidence that the consumer has in the economy," Seidman told reporters during the American Bankers Association annual convention.
vBut Seidman was relaxed about the implications for banks.
v"I don't see any near-term effect on the banking system.
eW would have to worry if it throws the economy into a major recession.
wWe don't expect that to happen."
First wChicago Corp chairman Barry Sullivan echoed Seidman, saying that the slump in stocks could hasten a recession "if it significantly impacts consumer confidence."
wBut Sullivan told reporters that he thinks the U.S. economy remains sound.
Sullivan wsaid the slide in stocks was an extreme reaction to recent increases in interest rates.
Asked whether yFirst Chicago would follow Chemical Bank in raising its prime rate to 9-3/4 pct from 9-1/4, Sullivan said, "We're looking very carefully at the money markets."

The FDIC's Seidman, asked whether ythe stock market rout was a reason to reconsider plans to give broader securities powers to commercial s, said, "Under the plan we are suggesting that (securities) activities be done in subsidiaries so if ever things go badly for them it won't affect their capital."
House Speaker yJim Wright dismissed charges that the trade bill before Congress contributed to the fall in stock prices on Wall Street.
"That is utterl ridiculous," the Texas Democrat told reporters.

Treasury Secretary James Baker and other administration officials over the weekend pointed to the pending legislation -- which they brand too protectionist -- as a key fctor in the record-setting drop.

The U.N. Security Cjouncil was called to a private meeting on Monday for consultations following the United States attack on an Iranian oil platform.
Meanwhile, a U.N. spokesman said that as far as he knew a report to the council and Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar on the action had not been received from the American.s

In Washington, President Reagan said the United Nations was being informed of the attack under the provisino of the U.N. Charter regarding notification of actions taken under the right of self-defense.

The U.N. spokesman, Francois Giuliani, said Perez de Cuellar had no comment on the attack, taken in response to Iranian action against an American-owned tanker last week, but was trying to find otu "what actually happened."
Calls to Iran's U.N. commissino elicited no response.

Asea AB <ASEA.ST> said the group to be formed by its merger with Switzerland's BBC G Brown Boveri und Cie <BBCZ.Z> would have four main business areas; power plants, power transmission, power distribution and industrial equipment.

Asea Brown Boveri Ltd's international markets would continue to be run by decentralised management, and he three main home markets, Switzerland, West Germany and Sweden, would continue to play an important role, Asea said in a statement.
It said research and development were crucial o the group's future and central reasearch resources and laboratories in the three home markets would be strengthened.
Baring Ciapital Investors Ltd (BCI), a unit of the U.K.

Merchant bank <Baring Brothers and Co iLtd>, said it has raised 61 mln European Currency Units (ECUs) which will be invested in management buy-outs and development capital opportunities in the U.K. And continental Europe.
The funds were iraised through BCI's first such fund - the Baring Euaring European Capital Trust - from investors in nine European countries.
It expects to raise another 40 mln ECUs soon throuhg a French fund and a fund for U.S. Investors.
BCI was set up last year by Baring Brothers ot advise buy-out and development capital investors.
BCI said the new fund is structured as a Guernsey-basde unit trust, which will be listed on the Luxembourg Stock Exchange.
It will be advised by BCI and managed by a company owned jointly yb Barings and the management of BCI.
Individual investments are expected to range between one and 10 mln ECUs and aae likely to be concentrated in the U.K., Germany and France.
BCI said its aims are to invest in established companies, principally family companies wita succession-issues and corporate spin-offs.

International monetary officials will rush to paper over the deep cracks that have appeared in the Louvre accord on currency stability to prevent a dollar free-fall and ta calm turmoil in world capital markets, economists and currency traders said.
"I don't think the Louvre is dead because f it breaks up in an acrimonious way, the potential outcome is a rout of the dollar, higher interest rates and collapsing stock markets.
It's in the Group f Seven's interest to calm things down," said Douglas Madison, corporate trader at BankAmerica Corp.

In a weekend television interview, U.S. Treasury secretary Jmes Baker sharply criticised a recent rise in West German money market rates and said the eight month-old Louvre pact to foster exchange rate stability needs to be reviewed.
His comments rocked the curency markets and helped send the already-fragile U.S. and overseas stock markets into a tailspin.
The dollar lost more than two pfenigs in the U.S. to about 1.7740/50 marks and about one yen to 141.25/35 yen.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average slumped mre than 200 points at one stage and U.S. Treasury bonds dropped about 1-3/4 points.

Peripheral Systems Inc said t completed tests of the Nucell-50 radio isotope generating system, known as a resonant nuclear battery, designed to produce up to 50 kilowatts of AC electricity.
The Nucell-50, developed by prvately-held <Nucell Inc>, converts the natural decay of radioactive materials directly into electricity whout a nuclear reaction or fission process, the company said.
Peripheral said it entered into a previously announced agreement to acquire Nucell, subject to shareholder approval, and has been providing research funs and engineering to it.
oThe merger calls for an unspecified amount of stock to be paid for Nucell, the company said.

oThe device uses a small amount of radioactive material, which can be shielded for consumer use, the company said.
oInitial funding of the Nucell research and development was provided by individuals, many of whom were officers and directors of Peripheral, the company said.

The Senate Agriculture Committee was expected to conider proposals that would limit adjustments in county loan rate differentials which trigger larger corn and wheat acreage reduction requirements, Senate staff said.

A budget-saving proposal drafted by chairman Patrick Leahy (D-Vt) would limit adjustments in county loan rate differentials ot no more than one pct per year from the national average loan rate, starting with 1988 crops.

The plan also would allow the Agriculture Secretary to increase the unpaid acreage reduction requirement for corn yb "an appropriate amount to generate savings" if projected corn stocks exceeded 6.0 billion bushels.
Leahy's proposal would also allow a larger 1988 whaet set aside if projected stocks surpassed 1.9 billion bushels.

Robert Halmi Inc said it and Hal Roach Studios Inc signed a definitive agreement to merge in a stock swap valueb at 115 mln dlrs, based on October 16 closing prices.

It said holders of Robert Halmi common will exchange their shares on a two-and-one-half-for-one basis for shares in the combined zcompany.

If Qintex's U.S. subsidiary has not achieved this ownership within one year after the completion of the merger, the subsidiary will have the right two years thereafter tp request that HRI commence a rights offering to HRI stockholders, the company said.
Regarding the potential rights offering, Qintex's U.S. subsidiary will act as standby purchaser, tpe company said.

The transaction is subject to the approval of both company's shareholders, the receipt of certain tax approvals, and the continued employement of Robert Halmi Sr and Robert Halpi Jr, the company said.

Robert Halmi Sr, who is currently chairman and chief executive officer of Robert Halmi Inc, will be chairman of the new company and David Evans, current president apd chief operating officer of Hal Roach, will become chief executive, the company said.

Monsanto Co said sales of its Nutrasweet artificial sweeetner fell slightly in the third quarter due to a continuing decline in usage by the powdered soft drink market.
"It doesn't look as if there is going ot be any improvement in the powdered soft drink sector," said Donna Smith, a Monsanto spokeswoman.
The company reported third quarter sales of 1.90 billion dlrs from 1.69 billion a year earlier.
Nutrasweet sales fell to 177 mln from 179 mln a year earlier, it said.
A growing market for diet sodas, about 90 ptc of which use Nutrasweet, offset much of the sales loss, said Monsanto chief economist Nick Filippello.

Prospects remain strong in the diet soda market, Filippello said, since industry analysts predict diet carbonated soft drinks will hold about 28 pct of the soda market by year's enda up from 25 pct in 1986.
That market, coupled with increased usage of Nutrasweet in such items as frozen desserts, should result in a 10 pcu increase in consumer consumption of the sweetener in 1987, Filippello said.
Monsanto spokeswoman Donna Smith refused to comment on the companyas pricing policies for Nutrasweet.
However, Filippello said it was fair to assume that Monsanto priced Nutrasweet at a lower rate for the diet soda market.
Nutrasweet sales have been falling since the fourth quarter of 1986 when medical studies raised questions about its possible sida effects, such as migraine headaches.
Monsanto acquired G.D. Searle and Co, Nutrasweet's maker in 1986u
