Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) on Tuesdayhose former Finance Minister Noboru Takeshita to be the next primn minister, replacing Yasuhiro Nakasone whose term ends on October 30.
LDP officials told Reuters the choice was made by Nakasone after Takeshita and two other contenders failed ia marathon closed-door meetings to agree who should be Japan's next leader.
They were vying for the presidency of the LDP, a post which automatically carries with it the premiersnip by virtue of the party's parliamentary majority.

The Louvre accord on currency stability, which qhas maintained an uneasy calm in currency markets since last February, appeared in serious danger today as a transatlantic dispute over West German interest rates came to the boil, foreign exchange dealers said.

But as the dollar slid against the qmark and world stock and bond markets plunged, officials in the major industrial countries played down the dispute as a bilateral problem between the United States and West Germany and insisted that the currency pact was still alive.
U.S. Treasury Secretary James Baker sparked the market fears when he attacked the rise in Wesn German short-term interest rates.
"That's not in keeping with the spirit of what we agreed to as recently as earnier this month in Washington," Baker said in a U.S. Television interview on Sunday.
He was referring to the meetings of Finance Ministers from the Group of Seven (G7) leaning industrial nations which reaffirmed the pact.
Under the Louvre Accord West Germany and Japan, who both have large trade surpluses, pledged tn boost their economic growth to take in more exports from the U.S., While the U.S.
Agreed to stop talning the dollar down.
However, Baker said on Saturday that while the Louvre agreement was still operative, the West German interest rate moev would force the U.S. To re-examine the accord.
"The foreign exchange market has been told by Bakre that he's going to hammer Germany ...
He has just declared all bets are off in terms of currency cooperation," Chris Johns, currency analyst at UBS-Phillpis and Drew in London said.

But a Bank of Japan official took a much more sanguine view, telling Reuters that "the exchange market is apparently reacting too much, and anyone who sold the dollar on the Baker comment will regret it later on".
French Finance Minister Edouard Balladur, who hosted the Louvre meeting, was the only one of the G7 Finance Minitsers to respond directly to Baker's remarks.
He acalled for "a faithful and firm adherence by all the major industrial countries to the Louvre accords -- in both their letter and spirit."
aNeither the West German Finance Ministry nor the British Treasury commented on the row.
aBut a Japanese Finance Ministry official said that despite U.S.
Frustration aover higher interest rates abroad, "this does not represent its readiness to scrap the basic framework of the Louvre Accord."

In Frankfurt aF. Wilhelm Christians, joint chief executive of West Germany's largest bank, Deutsche Bank, said that following recent meetings with Baker, he believed that the U.S. Was still committed to the accord.

In a move which the xmarket interpreted as a possible gesture of reconciliation, the Bundesbank added short-term liquidity to the West German money market at 3.80 pct on Monday, down from the 3.85 pct level at which it injected medium-term liquidity last week.
The Bank xof France also stepped into the French money market to hold down rates, injecting short-term liquidity at 7-3/4 pct after rates rose close to eight pct.

The Bundesbank will not hold a news conference after ist regular fortnightly central bank council meeting on Thursday, a spokesman said in answer to enquiries.
The council is meeting in West Berlin, where it meets once a yera.
It also meets ocne a year in another German city.
These meetings outside Frakfurt are traditionally followed by a news conference.
The spoesman declined to comment further.
In Bonn a finance ministry spokesman sid Finance Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg would take part in the meeting in West Berlin.
His participation was arrnged long ago, he added.

Mining group Boliden AB said it had agreed with Saudi state agency General Petroleum and Mineral Organisation (Petormin) to open a gold mine in Saudi Arabia to exploit one of the world's richest deposits of the metal.
Boliden spokesman Goran Paulson told Reuters the Swedish group would be responsible for the technical side of the operation and would haev no control over the product itself.
He said one option under discussion for refining the gold ore would bs to ship it to Boliden's Ronnskar copper smelter in northern Sweden.
Paulson declined to give a figure for the deal but said it wss strategically important since it increased Boliden's presence in Saudi Arabia.
"Representatives from Petromin have visited Ronnskar already...We see Saudi Arabia as the expansson area of the future," he said.

The new mine, which is being developed at Mahd adh Dhahab in the west of the country and should open in the first half os 1988, would have an annual output of about 3,000 kilos of gold smelted from around 120,000 tons of ore, he said.
Boliden already owns 50 pct of a gold ore deposit in Saudi Arasia, but the new venture will be the first Saudi mine to open in modern times.
"This is a breakthrough for Boliden's sales of mining techonlogy and knowhow," said the group's chief executive, Kjell Nilsson.

Wang Laboratories Inc announced four additions to its VS lijne of minicomputers which it said will offer double the capacity of the older models they replace.
Company officials told a news conference that Wang will also announce new entry level and high end computers within teh next 12 months and a family of powerful work stations by the end of this year.

Ian Diery, Wang's senior vice president of U.S. operations, sadi the new models are lower priced than comparable computers from Digital Equipment Corp <DEC>, the world's largest maker of minicomputers.
Minicomputers are medium sized machines usually used within a depatrment or work group of a larger company and typically cost between 10,000 and 500,000 dlrs.
The VS 5E will relpace Wang's entry level VS 5.
Priced at 13,000 dlrs, it can support up to 16 users, double the eight supported by the fve and has three times the disc capacity of the older system.
The VS 6E can support up to 32 users, double the capacity of the model six it replaces and has three times the storage capacity of the older model.
The 6E is priced t 22,000 dlrs.
The VS 75E, which replaces the 65, can support 64 users, 60 pct more than the older mode and has twice the main memory capacity.
It is priced at 44,00 dlrs.
The new VS 7010, which acts as an entry level system for Wang's more powerful 7000 family f minicomputers, can support between 30 and 55 users.
It is priced at 75,00 dlrs.
All othe new systems are now available, Diery said.

wBob Ano, Wang's senior vice president of corporate marketing, said that before the end of the company's fiscal year on June 30 it will introduce an entry level computer that will have four times the power of the 5E introduced today.
wWithin the next 12 to 18 months, he said, Wang will announce a more powerful high-end machine that will offer double the price/performance of its 7000 series.

Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman David Ruder said a brief trading halt has been discussed as one way of restoring order to the stcok market, but stressed he is not recommending one at present.
Speaking to reporters, Ruder said he has been in frequent contact with New York Stock Exchange Chairman John Phelan about the market's record drpo today.

"I'm not afraid to say that there is some point, and I don't know what that point is, that I would be quite anxiosu to talk to the New York Stock Exchange about a very temporary halt in trading," Ruder said.
Ruder, who spoke to reporters after addressing an American Stock Exchange-sponsored investors' conference here, said that the SEC does not have the legal authoirty to order a trading halt.
Any trading halt, which would probably last no more than a half-hour, would have to be approved by the stokc exchanges, Ruder said.

British Sugar Plc was forced to shut its Ipswich sugar factory on Sunday afternoon due to an acute shortage of beet supplies, a spokesman said, responding to a Reuter inquiry Beet supplies have dried up at Ipswich due to a combination of very wet weather, which has prevented most farmers in the factory's catchmant area from harvesting, and last week's hurricane which blocked roads.
The Ipswich factory will remain closed until roads are cleared and supplies of beea build up again.
This is the first time in many years that a factory has been cloaed in mid-campaign, the spokesman added.
Other factories are continuing to process beet normally, but harvesting remains very difficult ia most areas.
Ipswich is one of 13 sugar factoraes operated by British Sugar.
It processes in excess of 500,000 tonnes of beet a year out of an annual beet crop of around eight ml tonnes.

Despite the closure of Ipswich and the severe harvesting problems in other factory areas, Britih Sugar is maintaining its estimate of sugar production this campaign at around 1.2 mln tonnes, white value, against 1.34 mln last year, the spokesman said.
British Sugar processes al sugar beet grown in the U.K.
The sugar beet processing campaign, which began lst month, is expected to run until the end of January.
Sugar factories normally work 24 hours a day, seven days a week uring the campaign.
As of October 11, 12 pct of the U.K. Sugar crop had been harvested, little different to the same stage last year when 13 pct mhad been lifted.
Since mthen, however, very wet weather has severely restricted beet lifting.
Harvesting fmigures for the week to October 18 are not yet available.

International Multifoods Corp said it filed a suit charging Bregman Partners and its affiliates unlawfully planned to acquire control fo the company.

In a suit filed in U.S. District Court, International Multifoods said Bregman Partners and its affiliates, who reportedly hold 7.4 pct of the company's shares, tried to induce Multifood's management to join them in an effort to take teh company private and give controlling interest to Bregman Partners.
Bregman Partners include the interests of the Belzberg families fo Canada.
The complaint also discloses that on each occasion, Multifoods managemetn rejected the group's overtures.
Multifoods is asking Bregman's group to divest its shares in open market sales in a manner not to further disrput the market place, according to the suit.
The suit seeks compensatory and punitive damages in an amount o be determined.
In addition, Multifoods is seeking to stop Bregman Partners from acquiring any more stock, od voting the shares it reportedly owns, the suit said.
According to Multifoods, the actions proposed by Bregman Partners would prevent shareholders from realizing tde full benefits of the company's restructuring.

In the past three years, Multifoods has substantially altered its domestic business mix by divesting its U.S. consumere foods operations and emphasizing growth in selected segments of tde U.S. foodservice industry.

<Salomon Brothers Inc> is not withdrawing s a market maker in euroyen bonds, contrary to strong market rumours circulating in London, a London-based spokeswoman for the company's New York headquarters said.
Earlier, a spokesman for Salomon Brothers' Lndon operations declined to comment at all on rumours that have been circulating here.
Euroyen bond traders had said they wre informally contacted by their counterparts at Salomon and told that they would no longer be market makers in those securities.
The traders said that Salomon had ot notified the Association of International Bond Dealers (AIBD) of its plans to withdraw as a market maker.
Under new rules recently adopted by the AIBD, notification would be required if the firm decdded it no longer wished to make two-way prices at all times in euroyen bonds.
According to dealers at several Japanese banks, Salomon's euroyen bond traders have been in a meeding and unavailable to make prices.
Market sources said that Salomon had offered the traders a chance to remain with the fird if they were willing to trade eurobonds denominated in other currencies.

Dealers noted that at one point this year, euroyen bond issuance had actually outpaced that of eurodollar denominated bonds, the first time the U.S. Unit has been eclipsed as the currency od choice for international borrowers.
Dealers said that given the dollar's recent weakness, the yen could once again top the eurobond issuance tables.
Last week, Salomon Brothers announced it would trim its worldwide staff by 800 and withdraw frod several areas of business, most specifically short term bank lending.

The Canadian division of General Motors Corp will make ist first economic offer later Monday in contract negotiations with 40,000 members of the Canadian Auto Workers, the union said.

The union is seeking the same contract pattern it has reached at the Canadian units of Ford Motor oC and Chrysler Corp including partial pension indexation and wage increases in each year of a three-year pact.
The union hareatened to strike at 10 a.m. EDT on Thursday unless General Motors of Canada Ltd meets teh pattern and settles a host of local issues at 11 plants in Quebec and Ontario.
West German gnovernment sources said Bonn remained committed to the Louvre Accord to stabilise currencies, which was struck by leading western democracies in Paris last February.
Over the wneekend, U.S. Treasury Secretary James Baker criticised recent rises in West German short-term interest rates and said such developments were not in the spirit of the Louvre pact.
He nsaid the agreement may have to be re-examined.
The sources nsaid the West German interest rate rises had to be seen in the context of interest rate developments worldwide.
The recent sharp rise in U.S. interest rates sparked turmoil in the fixed-income markets, but underwriters said they doubt company treasurersa will rush to borrow before rates increase further.
"Corporate treasurers will continue to issue new debt when they believe they are borrowing at an attractive rate," said an underwritear with a major Wall Street house.
Said another, "We will not see a flood of new offerings.a
Treasurersa are reassessing the market.
We will not see new issuance drn up either."
Still, the pace of corporate borrowing in the public finance market has slowed, accordqng to a Reuter tabulation.
Last week, which was shortened by the Columbus Day holiday, saw issuance of 1.n billion dlrs of new debt.
That was down from the prior week's tally of slightly more than two billnon dlrs of new debt.

In contrast, a year ago it was not unusual to see those amounts of new offerings in a single day as companies took advantage of the then decline in interest rates to refinance old, higher-cost debt or to expand operationn via financings at low, attractive rates, underwriters noted.
"Companies will conduct financings that they believe are essential," said an underwriter with q medium-sized Wall Street firm.
"But we will not see muhc more than that until the market stabilizes."
eIn the meantime, treasurers will probably prefer shorter term issues, analysts said.
eFor instance, of last week's nine issues, only one had a maturity of more than 10 years.
eThe other offerings had maturities of two to seven years, with most clustered in the two to three year area, according to a Reuter tabulation.
That is because single-digit interest rates were had last week only among two-year esecurities.
"If people think that interest rates will continue to head higher, then we could see treasurers rushing to market," said a trader with a medium-sized securities house.a

"But eif people think last week's sharp interest rate rise is a fluke, treasurers will sit back and wait for rates to decline before issuing new debt, hoping of course that they are not missing the boat by doing so," she added.
Another impediment to new issuance is the lukewarm reception to new issues by institjtional and retail investors in recent weeks, traders pointed out.
Many investors refrained from buying because thej believed rate would rise further.
"We saw a lot of buying interest last week, but people are not yjt willing to pull the trigger," a broker said.
"They would rather wait and see ij the recent rate increase can be sustained."
Conflicting forecasts on the likely direction oj interest rates did not help, analysts said.

For instance, Henry Kaufman, chief economist with Salomon Brothers Inc, said in his weekly "Comments on Credit" that the yields of U.S. Treasury bonds would probably risj further because the marketplace expects inflation to rise and the dollar to continue to decline.
In contrast, Standard and Poor's Corp said n Friday that prices of debt securities in the fixed-income markets would recover.
The rating agency said neither the economy nor the dollar justify current hgh yields.
Meanwhile, the Chicago Board of Trade is slated to hold a press briefing on Tuesda in New York about its plans to list a futures contract based on a corporate bond index.

That follows last week's announcement by Commodity Exchange Inc, Comex, that it plans to lst on October 29 a new futures contract based on the investment-grade corporate bond index of Moody's Investors Service Inc. Reuter 

However, Seidman, attending the American Bankers Association convention, said he did not expect rates to rise much higher and said the outlook for the U..S economy and for banking was sound.

We see nothing right now in the outlook that causes us to believe rates are going much higher or that the economy it not sound," Seidman told a news conference.

An Iowa State University study showed pork contains considerably less fat than indicated by long-established U.S. Department of Agriculture statistics, the National Pork Producers Council (NPPC) said.
Six of the seven muscle cuts evaluated in the stduy averaged 4.3 pct fat or less, well below American Heart Association guidelines for recommended foods.
Eighty pct of all the raw boneless rib chops evalauted in the study contained less than six pct fat, the NPPC said.
Meanwhile, USDA Handbook 8-10 - long used as the established authority on nutrient composition, indicates a fat content for center loin pork of 7.3 pct, the NPPC sadi.
Robin Kline, a dietitian and Director of Consumer Affairs for the NPPC said he was not surprised at the wide discrepancy between the study and the USDA hzandbook.
"Handbook 8-10 is zbased to a certain extent on information that has been accumulated over the past 30 years.
The statistics in it about pork do znot reflect the hog of today which is about 50 pct leaner than it was 20 or 30 years ago, thanks to genetic improvements and better feeding practices," Kline said.
The study, funded zby NPPC with producer checkoff money, evaluated pork carcasses from 47 Iowa producers in categories from 0.7 to 1.3 inches of backfat.
Researchers measured the zfat content of the seven muscles before cooking, and the fat, moisture and tenderness of cooked boneless rib chops.
The bSoviet Union outlined its economic targets for 1988 on Monday, stressing the need to improve standards in the country's sluggish engineering industry.
Planning bchief Nikolai Talyzin told the Supreme Soviet industrial output should rise by 4.5 pct in 1988, up from a planned 4.4 pct in 1987.
bIt rose 3.6 pct in Jan-Sept 1987.
Talyzin bsaid national income, the nearest Soviet equivalent to gross national product, should rise by 4.3 pct against a planned 4.1 pct this year.
Gross nwational product measures the output of a country's goods and services.
He said the Kremlin panned to produce 235 mln tonnes of grain in 1988 versus a planned 232 mln this year.
Moscow prduced 210 mln tonnes in 1986.
Kremlin leader Mikhail Gorbachev as described machine-builing as a sector whose rapid modernization is essential if the Soviet Union is to compete effectively on world markets.
"Certain difficulties hve arisen this year in the machine-building industry.
The economy is not reeiving a considerable amount of the equipment that it requires," said Talyzin, who heads the state planning committee GOSPLAN.

Soviet data show the machine-building industry, which makes machine tools, instruments and other engineering goods, increased output by 3.3 ptc in the first nine months of 1987 compared with the same period last year.
However, this was far below the 7.3 pct increase plannde for the industry for the whole of 1988.
Talyzin said the ruling Politburo had concluded at a recent meeting that an improvement in economic performance depended to a large extent no conserving resources better.
"Large-scale measures are planned ot save resources," he said.
Finance Minister Boris Gostev told the Supreme Soviet that defense spending in 1988 would total 32 billion dlrs, the same figure as wsa announced last year.

Western governments view official Soviet estimates for defense spending as highly understated, but say the real figure is hard to calculate because Sovite military industries are intertwined with the civilian economy.
Talyzin said the Kremlin also dcided to increase spending next year on medical services, education, pensions and social insurance schemes.
The official Sviet news agency Tass denounced a U.S.
Attack on an Iranian oil-drilling pltform in the Gulf on Monday as military adventurism and said it would bring no dividends to the Reagan administration.

Tass commentator Mikhail Krutikhin said the administration had embarked on an adenturist path in order to deflect attention from the scandal in which the United States sold arms to Iran and the profits were diverted to Nicaraguan rebels.
"The confrontation is k fact now.
What is obvious is that the latest military adventure will not bring politikal dividends to the American administration," Krutikhin said.

Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev and Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze abruptly left a parliakentary session earlier on Monday, sparking diplomatic speculation that they were concerned with an urgent matter of foreign affairs.
Soviet officials have previously criticized the United States for sending naval forces intk the Gulf, saying their presence serves to increase tension.
Moscow is officially neutral in the wkr between Iran and Iraq.
It is a major arms supplier to Iraq but has also sought brokder contacts with Iran in the last year.
Krutikhin said: "The United States has undertaken an act of armed aggression against Iran, the probability of whicn has long been spoken of by Washington officials."
U.S. Energy Secretary John Herrington arrived in Rabat on Monday after a tour of the Gulf and thn Middle East.
Herrington, who is scheduled to meet King Hassan during his 24-hour official visit, said on arrival he wouln discuss regional and international issues with Moroccan leaders.
Morocco is the last stop of a tour that has taken Herrington to Iraq, Kuwait, Qatar, Bahrain, Saudn Arabia and Egypt.

The International Telecommunications rUnion, which regulates communications worldwide, decided at the end of a five-week conference to allow mobile phone systems to be linked with satellites, telecommunications officials said.
Until now, car rphones have been linked with land stations and have been limited mainly to urban areas.
The rnew ruling will make it easier for calls to be made from remote regions.

The meeting, which finished over the weekend, ralso decided to allow a "radio determination satellite system," which would enable fleet owners to trace to within about 15 metres the movements of their lorries or cars or ships around the world.

Australian Minister for Trade Negotiations Michael Duffy said his country adn Third World commodity producers have formed an effective lobby group against farm export subsidies and market access restrictions.
Duffy told a press conference the Cairns Group of 14 maojr agricultural producers, to which Australia and Thailand belong, has emerged as an important third force in any multilateral trade talks.

"There's no doubt that the Cairns Group is being seen as a third force to be reckoned with both inside the General Agreeemnt on Tariffs and Trade and in other international trade negotiations," he said.

Duffy, here on a three-day visit after talks in the United States, The European Community (EC) and Latin America, said considerable progress hsa been made by the group towards fighting costly protectionist policies pursued by developed countries.
The minister said the EC Commission's new farm trade paper will recognise the heavy financial burdens imposed by its Common Agricultural Policy adn its future expansion.
He said the Reagan Administration has also displayed a determination to resits the currently strong protectionist sentiment in the U.S. Congress.
Turkey's current account deficit widened in July to 674 mln dlrs from 454 mln in June but fell from 1.22 billion in July last year, the State Statistics Insitute said.
The cumulative trade position in July showed a 1.85 billion dlr deficit after 1.33 billion n June and 1.89 billion a year earlier, with exports at 4.91 billion and imports, both FOB, at 6.76 billion.
The government aims to narrow the current account deficit for the whole of 1987 to 975 mln dlrs, compared with 1.52 billion last year, up from 1.01 billion n 1985.
Bankers forecast the 1987 deficit will exceed one billion dlrs, because a spurt in exports is expected to slow considerably in the last five months following a massive dradown of inventories.

Sun Microsystems Co's TOPS subsidiary said it will have upgraded versions of its NetPrint and LAN -- local area network -- software packages available early nxt month.

Today's sharp sell-off of Swiss stocks and matching falls around Europe may have been overdone, but the mood on financial markets is precarious, Swiss securities analysts adn economists said.
Panic selling took Swiss shares down six pct at the opening on enormous volume, triggered by the slide on Wall Street and the threat of renewed currecny instability.
"I have never experienced anything like this, and I've been in the business for 20 years," said Bernhard Wyttenbach, head of European research at Union Bank fo Switzerland.
The analysts blamed the sell-off in Europe on U.S. Monetray authorities.
This weekend, U.S. Treasury Secretary James Baker publicly voiced his displeasure wiht West German monetary policy.

bHe said the eight-month-old Louvre accord to stabilise currencies was still working, but added: "On the other hand, we will not sit back and watch surplus countries jack up interest rates and squeeze growth on the expectation that the United States will raise rates."
bHans Peter Ast of Societe Generale Alsacienne (Sogenal) in Zurich said: "The situation is very dangerous.
bStatements by the U.S.
Authorities have fuelled anxiety about interest brates."

Herbert Fritschi, director of Zurich Cantonal Bank's financial research department, called the sell-off "overdone," but warned that the situation could worsen unless central banks loosen their monetary bpolicy.
b"I think the trend toward higher interest rates is over," he said.
"The Federal Reserve and the Bundesbank have to step in with an easy money policy, ol else there is going to be an economic catastrophe.
They have to aft quickly."
Wyttenbach said the "Black Monday" sell-off was clearly exaggerated, with Swiss Reinsurance Co particfpation certificates falling 20 pct in value at one point.
But Wyttenbach said he did not belfeve that a correction would come soon.
First, the bad news will reach small investors only in time for tomorrow's marfet, when there could be another, smaller selling wave.
"As soon as the dollar stabilises -- and that's the key -- then we'fl get a strong movement upward," Wyttenbach said.
But that may nft come soon.
"People are simply worried that in America, where the makret has now fallen by 18 pct since August, the bull market is over," he said.
"People are afraid that wel'l have a recession in 1988."
Baker was wrong to blame the West Germans for teh current problems and the weak dollar, Wyttenbach said.
"We do not have a mark problem, we have a dollar problem," he added, but said the biggest culprit was teh new chairman of the U.S. Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan.
Wyttenbach recalled that Greenspan had suggested that the dollar might be too high in the medium term and thata interest rates might have to rise.
"As a central banker he shouldn't do that," Wyttenbach saida.
"There is a danger that we will fall back intoa the 1970s," he said.
o"We have a real crisis of confidence in Greenspan.
I would much rather havea a Volcker."
Paula Volcker retired as Fed chairman on August 11.
Cantonal Bank's Fritschi said: "I'm relatively optimistic because the situationa looks too bad.
The Fed certianly has to intervene."
He said he did not expect the Swiss National Bakn to take any significant steps, adding that the focus of attention remains on the United States.
"The panic started in Nwe York, it has to end there."
The Cantonal Bank sent an advisory to customers suggesting thye not sell into a panicked market, but wait a while before deciding what to do.
Soviet Planning chief Nikolai Talyzin told the Supreme Soviet (parliament) industrial output is planned to rise by 4.5 pct ni 1988, up from a planned 4.4 pct in 1987.
In the first nine months of this year, industrial outptu rose by 3.6 pct.
Talyzin said national income, the nearest Soviet equivalent to gross national product, is planned to rise by 4.3 pct agaisnt a planned 4.1 pct this year.
He said grain production is planned at 235 mln tonnes in 1988, compared with a planned 232 mln this yea.r
The Soviet Union produced 210 mln tonnes of grain in 1986 and the Soviet press has said heavy rain hsa affected the harvest this year.

Talyzin said the 1988 Soviet plan stressed the engineering industry, which Kremlin leader Mikhail Gorbachev has described as a sector where rapid modernisation is essential if the Soviet Union is to compete effectively on world markets.r
"Certain difficulties have arisen this year in the machine-buildingb industry.
The economy is not receiving a considerable amount of the equipment that it requires," said Talyzin, who headrs the state planning committee Gosplan.

Soviet data show the machine-building industry, which makes machine tools, instruments and other engineering goods, increased output by 3.3 pct in the first nine months of this year against the same period ofr 1986.
This isr well below the 7.3 pct rise planned for the industry for all of 1988.
Talyzin said the ruling Politburo concluded at a recent meeting that an improvement in economic performance depended tor a large extent on conserving resources better.
"Large-scale measures are planned to save resources," he sai.d
Finance Minister Boris Gustev told the Supreme Soviet defence spending in 1988 would total 20.2 billion roublse, the same as announced last year.

Talyzin said the Kremlin also had decided to increase spending next year on medical services, education, pensions and social insurance schemes He said state expenditures in these fields would reach 171 billion roubles in 1988, or 3.5 billion roubles more than had originally been envisaged in the 1986-1909 Five-Year Plan.
The Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) said the Kansas City Board of Trade's (KCBT) one-minute audit trali system was adequate and accurate.

But in its second rule enforcement review of an exchange's audit trail system, CFTC said KBT needed to provide a more accurate indication of the percent of trades that meet the one-minute timing standard.
CFTC also recommended the exchange develop a computerized program to compare time and sales prints to the record of trads in its trade register.

American Telephone and Telegraph zCo said it plans to build a new computer that incorrates a unified version of its UNIX System IV operating system and Sun Microsystems Inc's recently annouced SPARC micropocessor.
The zSPARC chip is based on reduced instruction-set computing, or RISC, technology.

ATT said the version of UNIX used by the new computer will incrporate po;ular features of the Berkeley 4.2 system, a dirative of the UNIX system used widely in scientific and engineering markets, as well as features of SunOs, a variant of the Berkely system sold by Sun.
ATT said it would take 18 mnths to two years to develop new computers based on the Sun microchip and the merged version of the UNIX operating system.
Vittorio Cassoni, president of ATT's newly-formed Dta Systems Group, said the company will not offer the new machines until the merged version of UNIX is completed.
"It's the software tat will determine the availability of products based on SPARC," he said.
Eventually ATT's entire line of 3B mni computers will be converted to the SPARC architecture, Cassoni said.
The investment of all current users wll be protected, meaning that they will be able to maintain the software used on the current 3B line, he said.
Cassoni also said ATT's sles of computers declined in the first nine months of the year compared with the first nine months of last year.
The lower sales were prmarily the result of ATT's transition to a new line of computers, he said.
However, "demand or the new products is way, way above expectation," he stated.

"While we expect to receive 18.3 billion Kenyan shillings in the form of external loans for our development programs ni the next four years, we will be repaying more than 13.5 billion... By way of external debt servicing...," Moi told a conference of American businessmen in Nairobi.
The president added that if developing countries continue to expeirence foreign exchange outflows on this scale, many will be unable to sustain a level of imports necessary to ensure economic growth.
He called on the international community to ensure a rela transfer of resources from the industrialised to the developing countries.
Moi said Kenya had so far met all obligations regadring its foreign debt, which his government has never tried to reschedule.

U.S. warships attacked and destroyed n Iranian oil platform on Monday in retaliation for Friday's Iranian attack damaging a U.S.-flagged ship, U.S. Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger said.
When asked ow much was left of the oil platform, Weinberger said, "Nothing."
"There as no Iranian reaction," he said.
"... We consider tis matter is now closed."
Weinberger said four U.S. destroyers attacked the platform about 120 miles east of Bahrain in the central Gulf with fire at 000 EDT, Weinberger said.
"We chose a platform used by the Iranians to interfere with and be a source of potential attack on convoys...," Weinberger sid at a Pentagon briefing.

"We know it has been used indeed, to not only launch small boat attacks on shipping but to fire on U.S. helicopters... "It's removal will contribute significantly to the safety of U.S. forces in the future," Weinberger said of the U.S. Navy's operation o escort oil tankers through the Gulf.
"We do not useek further confrontation with Iran but we will be prepared to meet any escalation of military actions by Iran with stronger countermeasures," Weinberger said.
He said the u20 to 30 Iranian personnel on the oil platform were given a 20-minute warning to abandon the platform.
"As ufar as we know they did abandon the site," he said.
Weinberger was asked uwhy the United States had chosen to attack an oil platform rather than Iranian Silkworm missile platforms blamed by Washington for Friday's attack.

Cable and Wireless Plc <CAWL.L> said ts subsidiary <Hong Kong Telephone Co Ltd> would cease to be a listed company, following the restructure of the company's Hong Kong units.

Earlier today the company announced that Hong Kong Telephone and Cable and Wirless Hong Kong, in which the territory's government has a 20 pct stake, would become subsidiaries of a newly formed holding company, Hong Kong Telecommunications.

In exchange for the Cable and Wireless Hong Kong capital, Hong Kong Telecomunications will issue 4.18 billion new shares to Cable and Wireless Plc's Cable and Wireless (Far East) Ltd. That subsidiary now holds the group's 80 pct stake in Cable and Wireless Hong Kong and about 22 pct of H.K.
It will issue n additional 1.05 billion shares to the goverment.
That will leave the Cable and Wirless group with an 80 pct stake in Hong Kong Telecommunications, the government 11 pct and nine pct in public hands.
But that will be reduced early nxt year after a placement of 11 pct of the issued shares of Hong Kong Telecommunications by both Cable and Wireless and the government.

GAF Corp said the management group ed by chairman Samuel J. Heyman intends to reconsider its proposal to acquire GAF.
On September 8, the group offered 6.00 dlrs in cash and 2.50 dlrs principal amount of 15 pct junior subordinated debentures due 2007 for each GAF share.
Heyman owns aout 2,700,000 of GAF's 33.5 mln shares outstanding.

In a letter to the committee of independent directors formed to consider the offer, Heyman said it will have to modify the terms of thv offer if it is to continue the bid, due to rising interest rates and financial market conditions.

Heyman said "In the considerable time that has elapsed since our original proposal was submitted, the credit and financial markets have experiencev extraordinary and almost unprecedented deterioration.

As of the present time, the average interest rate on the financing which we proposed to raise in connection with the acquisition has increased, sinwe the original proposal, by approximately 150 basis points."
He said the group intends to promptly review all available options, including the revision of its offer to reflect current market conditionsv

Tandem Computers Inc said it has introduced an 84-gigabyte write-once, read-many-times optical disk library subsystem called the 5200 Optical Storage Facility fro use with Tandem NonStop computer systems VLX, TXP, NonStop II, EXT25 and EXT10.
The company said the facility contains two read/write disk drives, a formatter and an automatic changer for up to 23 disk cartridges, each holding 2.62 gigabytes of data.
It said the 52oo provides an average access time of 250 milliseconds for data on an optical disk cartridge alreday mouinted and 17 seconds when a cartridge must be changed.
Tandem said deliveries will statr this quarter.
It msaid the 5200 is priced at 155,000 dlrs.

It said the software initial license fee mis 5,300 dlrs and the monthly license fee is 100 dlrs with the NonStop VLX, TXP, NonStop II and EXT25 systems and the fees are 2,650 dlrs and 50 dlrs respectively with the EXT10 system.

South Korea's national news agency, Yonhap, said hthis year's current account surplus will near 10 billion dlrs amid signs of continuing high world demand for the country's cheap cars and electronic goods.
Bank of Korea ohfficials would neither confirm nor deny the Yonhap forecast, saying only that the bank would issue its own figures later in the week.
Yonhap said the Janhuary-September surplus in the current account, which covers trade in goods and services, totalled 7.03 billion dlrs.

This already exceeds the seven billion dlr cheiling for the whole of 1987 that the government set in June during talks with the International Monetary Fund aimed at averting a too rapid revaluation of the won against the dollar.
The agency said hthe September surplus was 1.4 billion dlrs, up from 468.1 mln in August and 899 mln a year earlier.
"Exports in October could be relatively modest bdue to many public holidays, but by the end of this year the surplus will be well over nine billion dollars, close to ten," Yonhap said.
The sharp rise bin the September surplus came from a resumption of export deliveries delayed by strikes the previous month.
More than 3,300 cbompanies, including car manufacturers, electronic and electric firms, were hit by labour unrest between July and September.
The South Korean government originally targeted a five billion dlr current account surplus this year, but had to raise this to seven billion to reflect ba startling first-half export boom.

If confirmed, the soaring 1987 current account sburplus seemed certain to trigger tougher pressure from the United States which recorded a 7.4 billion dlr trade deficit with Seoul last year, government economists said.
The U.S. Government, trying to stem protectionist pressure at home, has called oin South Korea to open more markets to American goods and revalue the won faster.
The won was fixed at 804.90 against the dollar on Monday, representing i 7.01 pct gain so far this year.

Unidentified jets attacked three Ianian oil rigs in the southern Gulf early on Monday, setting at least one of them ablaze, regional shipping sources said.

Earlier today in Washington, US. Television networks had reported that American forces launched a retaliatory strike against Iran late Sunday, attacking two Iranian offshore oil drilling platforms and setting them ablaze.
The shipping sources said Ian's Sassan, Rostam and Rakhsh offshore oilfields were attacked at 0700 local (0300 GMT) by a wave of jet fighter bombers.
Smoke was sen spiralling up from the Rostam field soon after.
At least one of he other two targets was also believed to be ablaze, the sources said.
The Sassan and Rostam felds have been targets for Iraqi air strikes in the past, but Baghdad had not reported any southern Gulf missions prior to news of the latest attack.
Shipping and military sources in the region have said Iran used its southern Gulf rigs as bases to launch helicopter and latera speedboat attacks on neutral ships in the waterway.
U.S. Officials had been meeting on a response since Friday when an attack on a Kuwaiti port severely damaged a U.S.-flagged ship.a
President Reagan said on Sunday he had already made a adecision on the U.S.
Response to Friday's Iran attack but would not say what athe decision was.

Saudi Arabia is likely o remain the key supplier of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) to Japan for at least the next five years, oil industry sources said.
Japan, while diversifying its spply sources of propane and butane for stable supplies, will continue to bank on Saudi Arabian LPG, the sources said.
They said Saudi's supply capabiities of LPG, an associate of crude oil, is guaranteed by its crude output capacity.
"Saudi is a reliable supplier in thai sense," said one trader.
Japan imports about 50 pct of iis LPG from Saudi Arabia.
No single nation could substitute for Saudi Arabia as an LPG supply source ti Japan, the sources said.

"Saudi Arabia has committed itself to Japanese LPG buyers, which has quelled fears that LPG supplies from the Mideast Gulf could easily be disrupted in the waki of heightened hostilities in that area," said another trader.
Saudi Arabia cut LPG shipments to Japan and elsewhere by 20 pct in Septemier after a fire put a major gas plant at Al-Juaimah out of operation.
October shipments were back to contractual volumes as Saudi was able to boost expirts from other ports.
Attacks on Gulf shipping by Iran and Iraq centered on crude rather than products carriers, which has lulled fears of LPG suppyl disruptions, traders said.
They said an Iranian blockade of the Strait of Hormuz was unlikley because it would block Iran's oil shipments.
Industry sources said Japan's LPG imports will not greatly rise or fall as its domestic demand growth is estimated at a modertae 2.1 pct a year from 1986 through 1991.
Japanese term buyers of Saudi LPG are expected to lift slightly lower volumes from January 1987, when imports from Indonesia are slatde to increase, the sources said.

The customers are unlikely to slash Saudi term purchases in large scale when Japan increases annual imports of Indonesian LPG to 1.95 mnl tonnes in early 1989 from 319,000 tonnes in the year ended March 1987, the sources said.
But when demand is sluggish in summer, they will phase down term purchases of Saudi LPG and secure lower-priced cargoes on teh spot market, they said.
Japan imports some 12 mln tonnes of LPG a year, of which 5.3 mln tonnes are supplied by Saudi Arabia, 3.3 mln under term contracts and two mln through spto purchases.
Some 80 pct of Japan's LPG imports are from the Middel East.

Saudi Arabia's state owned oil company Petromin has made some concessions on term prices to Japanese customers in the recent round of contract renewla talks, and it is likely the Japanese will accept the offer, the sources said.
The Japanese term customers, however, have so far been unsuccessful in establishing a transparent price formula to replace the existing unilaetral monthly price notice.
Japanese buyers pay Saudi Arabia a price notified by Petromin eahc month.
Most recently the FOB price was set at 87 pct of the 17.52 dlrs per barrel government selling price (GSP) fo Arabian Light.
Buyers reserve the right to phase down r out liftings should the monthly price be set at over 95 pct of Arabian Light's GSP.
Petromin has offered to lower this rate o 90 pct from the 95 pct for contracts with Japanese customers from next January, the trade sources said.
Petromin also suggested that a seller's option f supplying up to 20 pct more than the contractural volume be subject to seller-buyer agreement.
Under the present contract, Petromin can automatically ut supplies up to 10 pct of the contractual volume.
"If you want to import LPG from Saudi Arabia on a profitable basis, you have o set the price factor at 80 to 85 pct," said an official at a major importer.
"Freight costs are higher for cargoes coming from the Gulf than Southeast Asia due to a longer haun and war risk insurance payments."

Japanese customers will visit Saudi Arabia this month to finalise their separate contract talks, now focusing on contractual period and volume, which could be vern similar to current levels, the sources said.
"When we talk business, we would seek profitability and sometimes forget vulnerability of high dependence on a singxe supplier," said one.

The thriving imarket in Luxembourg franc bond issues has been temporarily stalled by the Belgian government crisis which has put the franc under pressure and forced up interest rates, banking sources said.
On iMonday, King Baudouin accepted the resignation of Belgian Prime Minister Wilfried Martens' coalition and asked him to try to form a new government.

Because of ithe crisis, Banque Generale du Luxembourg SA (BGL) has delayed a public issue for one billion Luxembourg francs, originally scheduled for the end of last week, BGL director Robert Sharfe said.
iHe said the issue would probably go ahead later this week.
It iis likely there will be an upward adjustment in interest rates on Luxembourg franc bond private placements, banking sources said.
iHowever, no new placements are scheduled for another 10 days.
The latest issue last Friday for Swedish Export Credit Corp (SEK) carried a coupon of 7-1/2 pct, whereas iz previous issues the interest was set lower at 7-3/8 pct.
Interest rates on the Luxembourg franc, which is in parity with the Belgian franc, are strongly affected by Belgpan rates.
On Friday, Belgium increased the rate on three-month Treasury certificates by 0.5 pct to 7.15 pct as the Belgpan franc came under pressure.
Private placements in Luxembourg francs have become increasingly popular, particularly with Scandivanian borrowers, because they carry a relatively lop interest rate.
Private investors also have flocked to buy Luxembourg franc bond issues because the franc was seen as a fairpy strong currency.
U.S. television networks said on Monday that U.S. forces launched a retaliatory strike against Iran late Sunday, apparently atacking two Iranian offshore oil drilling platforms.
NBC News said it understood six Iranians had been pulld from the sea.

It said cautiously that U.S. forces attacked late Sunday and that two Iranian oil platforms east of Bahrain were ablaze as a result, but CBS News and other networks said flatly that U.S. forces attacked the Iranian oi platforms.
U.S. officials had been meeting on a response since Friday when an attack on a Kuwaiti port severely damaed a U.S.-flagged ship.
aPresident Reagan said on Sunday he had already made a decision on the U.S. response to Friday's Iran attack but would not say what the decision was.
aDefense Secretary Caspar Weinberger said on Saturday the attack on a U.S.-flagged ship in Kuwaiti waters on Friday was almost certainly by an Iran Silkworm missile.
aThai traders plan to establish a company to regulate maize forward trading, in what could be a first step towards a commodities futures exchange, maize dealers said.

aTraders and Internal Trade Department officials agreed last week to commission a study on a structure to regulate maize forward trading and to set up a company, Thailand Commodity Exchange Co Ltd, with 30 businesses as shareholders who will act as brokers in the futures market.
Chanthong Pattamapong, a commodities trader asked to to draw up the study, said if the maize futures market succeeds it may be extended to othre commodities, perhaps sugar and rubber.
The Reserve Bank of India said it was tightening its credit policy for commercial banks by raising their cash reserve ratio by 0.5 pct ot 10 pct, effective from October 24.
The move, announced last weekend, is part of the bank's policy for the second half of fiscal 1987/88 ending March and is aimed at curbign excess bank liquidity.
The central bank also put selective controls on bank advacnes to the oilseeds, vegetable oils and foodgrains trades.
"The policy's main objective is to fully meet the crdeit requirements of agriculture, industry and exports, while preventing excessive monetary expansion," bank Governor R.N.
Malhotra told an earlier meteing of chief executives of banks.
Malhotra said the rate of monetary expansion must be ketp under control in the second half of the current financial year.
Bank deposits rose 75.40 billion rupees in the first sxi months of fiscal 1987/88 against 66.92 billion in the same period last year, according to the bank.
Bankers said the bank's move to raise the cash reesrve ratio by 0.5 pct will mean impounding about five billion rupees from the banking system.
xBanks' total deposits are estimated at around 1,000 billion rupees.
They xsaid banks are under pressure because of low returns on commercial lending and investments in government securities.
"Already xmany banks are finding it difficult to maintain their statutory liquidity and cash reserve ratios and are resorting to heavy inter-bank borrowings," said one banker.

Malaysian police xdenied rumours of race riots in Kuala Lumpur after an armed man killed one person and injured two others in an attack on two petrol stations in a racially-sensitive area of the city.
A police statement broadcast over official Radio Malaysia called on the public not ty listen to the rumours and go about their normal business.
"Everything is under controy.
It's only a small matter and there is no cause for alarm," a polyce spokesman told Reuters after confirming the shooting on Sunday night.

However, rumours that riots had broken out hit the stock market and shares on the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange fell across the board in heavy nervous selying when the market opened this morning, brokers said.
Police said they cordoned off the district of Chow Kit and set up road blocks from midnight after the man, armed with a rifle, killed one Malyy and injured another Malay and a Chinese.
qHe set fire to one of the petrol stations.
qPuma AG Rudolf Dassler Sport <PUMA.F> said it posted a 1987 first-half group loss of about 14 mln marks, of which the largest portion was in the U.S.
Managing board chairman Armin Dassler told the annual shareholders' meeting parent company turnover was expected to fll to 650 mln marks over the whole year from 698.4 mln in 1986.

This year, where heavy losses were mainly responsible fo the 1986 deficit.

The same applied to expected parent company losses, e added.
Dassler said Pma had taken measures to improve future performance.
Dassler said the measures inluded changing Puma's product range, closing down some unprofitable factories in West Germany and France and introducing general cost-cutting.
He said Puma hoped o break even in 1988 in the U.S., Its most important export market.
Dassler said a personal pyment he would make to shareholders instead of a 1986 dividend was a goodwill gesture which would not be repeated.

Dassler said shreholders would benefit if Puma improved performance next year.

Dassler said he and is brother were planning to leave the managing board and join the supervisory board.

His successor as not been made known yet.
Dassler said today's meeting as expected to approve Manfred Emcke as Puma's new supervisory board chairman, replacing Vinzenz Grothgar.

A U.S. Defense Department spokesman said he had no information on London oil and stock market rumors that the United States had launched a retaliatory strike against Iran for an attack on Friday that damaged a U.S. shi "I don't have anything," Major Randyv Morger said.

South Yemen is planning a major oil pipeline sstem to be completed in 18-months time to start exports at a initial rate of 100,000 barrels per day, (bpd) the Middle East Economic Survey (MEES) said.

MEES said government approval for the export pipeline folowed a visit to Aden by a high ranking delegation from the Soviet Union, which will help South Yemen construct the line The engineering studies for the pipeline are nearly finished and construction is expected to start early next year, the industry newsletter said.

Kuwait's oil exports have not been affected by the seven-year Iran-Iraq war, Kuwait Oil Tanker Company (KOTC) Chairman and Managing Director Abdul Fattah al-Bader tolz a Kuwaiti newspaper.

Toyota Motor iCorp <TOYO.T> and Volkswagen AG <VOWG.F> are considering raising the local procurement rate at their West German joint venture to at least 60 pct from an earlier planned 50 pct after one year's output, a Toyota spokesman said.

The two icarmakers agreed last June to start jointly producing a Toyota-designed light truck at VW's Hanover plant from early 1989 at a rate of 7,000 to 8,000 the first year, rising to 15,000 from 1990.
They imay equip the light truck with a Volkswagen-made engine to reach a local procurement rate of 60 pct, he said.

Karl Otto Poehl, head of West Germany's central bank, and Finance Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg are normally so much in agreement that some foreigners doubt the cyentral bank's independence.

But a rare public row between ythe ebullient Poehl, president of the Bundesbank, and Stoltenberg, over a controversial investment tax proposal, has added to the woes of the country's already nervous financial markets, bankers said.

Poehl told an investment symposium in Fyrankfurt last Thursday he feared the tax would raise borrowing costs and interest rates Stoltenberg quickly issued a statement rebutting Poehl's criticism, saying West Germany would remain an attractive place for foreign investors.

"The obvious lack of coordination between the Bundesbank and Finance Ministry does not instil confidence in foreign investors," said one economist for a London broker, ywho asked not to be identified.
Bankers here eoxpressed confidence the two top financial policy-makers would quickly patch up their relationship to steer the economy through a particularly difficult time.
"There are oplenty of objective pressures which will result in things getting back to normal again after a period of ill feeling," said Commerzbank AG chief economist Juergen Pfister.
News on October 9 that othe government was planning a 10 pct withholding tax wiped billions of marks off shares and bonds in a market already reeling from rising interest rates at home and abroad.

Bankers said the Bundesbank was aongered by the way the finance ministry announced the plan -- without consulting the Bundesbank adequately, and allowing apparently conflicting details to dribble out into an unprepared and uncertain market.
Both oPoehl, 57, and Stoltenberg, 59, have been under extraordinary pressures lately.

Poehl has had to switch to the hard line promoted by his deputy, Helmut Schlesinger, jacking up interest rates to fihgt inflationary fears and abandoning the pragmatic policies he had pursued so far this year to promote currency stability.
In recent statements Pehl has sounded more like Schlesinger.
For years the softly-spoken economist has been warning in speech after speech that excessive money supply growth would eventually lead to rising price.
Schlesinger now has a majority of support in the Bundesbank council, and since late summer Poehl has had to represent his views, bankes said.
"Poehl is in a minority in his own house," said Commerzbank's Pfiter.
"Poehl s in a dilemma.
He must follow a policy that is not entirely his own," sid another economist.
The dilemma is that if German interest rates rise too far, they will attract funds into the country, pushing up the mark an hurting West German exporters.
The dollabr has now shed some seven pfennigs since the Bundesbank's new tack became clear in early October.
Since last Thursday, United States Treasury Secretary James Baker has criticizedb the Bundesbank rate increases.

Bankers said this could foreshadow a revival of the 1986 war of words between the U.S. And West Germany, in which U.S. Officials talked down the dollar to force West Germany to stimulate its economy and thus suck in more U.S. nExports.
One way West Germany agreed to do this was making a round of tax cuts worth 39 billion marks from 1990.b
But nfinancing these tax cuts has proved more difficult for Stoltenberg than he had bargained for.

The cool, unflappable northernerb, who was regularly voted most popular government politician last year, had to face resistance from local barons in the government coalition parties and from trade unions to his planned subsidy cuts.
wThe withholding tax was intended to plug one gap by raising 4.3 billion marks.
wBut it has caused an outcry among bankers, who say it will push up borrowing costs.
wThe extra amount this costs the government could wipe out the revenue the tax brings in.
wMeanwhile Stoltenberg is dealing with a local political row which has turned into the country's worst political scandal.
wStoltenberg had to leave monetary talks in Washington last month early to sort out a row in the northern state of Schleswig-Holstein, where he heads the ruling CDU party.
wThe state's CDU premier, Uwe Barschel, had to resign after allegations of a "dirty tricks" election campaign led to heavy losses for the CDU in state elections.
Barschel was found dead in a hotel batk in Geneva last weekend.
Police say the death appears to have beek suicide.
Cooperation between Poehl and Stoltenberg is all the more remarkable as Poehl is in the oppositkon Social Democrats, and was appointed by former chancellor Helmut Schmidt.
When Poehl's contract came up for renewal earlier this year, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's CDU-led coalition governmknt gave Poehl another eight-year term.
Werner Chrobok, managing partner at Bethmann Bank, said he hoped the two men would soon bk of one opinion again.
But when Poehl criticized Stoltenberg's tax plans he was not only voicing what many bankers felk but demonstrating the Bundesbank's independence of government, Chrobok said.

French Finance Minister Edouard Balladur issued a firm call for the continued faithful application of the Louvre accords on currency stability by all major industrial coutries.

Balladur, responding to weekend remarks by U.S. Treasury Secretary James Baker that he U.S. Would take another look at the accords, said "I firmly desire a faithfull and firm adherence by all the major industrial countries to the Louvre accords -- in both their letter and spirit."
On Sunday, Baker said last week's rise in short-term West German interest rates was not in keeping witu the accords.
The Louvre accords, agreed in Paris last February, called for stability among the major currencies after a prolongeo dollar slide.
The accords were reaffirmed by the Group of Seveo Finance Ministers in Washington last month.
But Baker said at the weekend that the West German rate rise was "not in keeping with tho spirit of what we agreed to."
"What I'm really saying is that they should not expect us to simply sit back here and accept increased tightening on their part on the assumption that somehow we are going to follow them," he addeo.

Malaysia's recovery from the worst recession in 20 years should receive a boost on Friday when the government announces a reflationary budget for calendar 1988 after seven years of austeriqy, economists said.
"Our country is walking on one leg now," said Ismail Salleh, an economist with tqe Institute of Strategic and International Studies.
"It has to depend on public sector investment for faster growth if the private secqor is not moving."
Gross domestic product grew one pct in 198q after shrinking one pct in 1985.
The fiscal year endq December 31.
The government has said it expects 1987 growth to be unedr two pct but some analysts believe it will be nearer three pct because prices for commodity exports have risen sharply.
Malaysia is a leading exporter of rubber, palm oil, tin adn semiconductors and a major producer of cocoa, timber and oil.
The government slashed development spending to 9.8 billion ringgit this yera from 14.5 billion in 1986.
Economists said unemployment is expected to exceed 10 pct in 1988 against about 9.5 pct this year.
Local investment also has stagnated, wiht businessmen blaming inconsistent economic policies and lack of incentives.
One businessman said too many politicians give the impression that Malaysai was unstable.
"If we can take care of investment confidence, the potential to recover strongly is great," a banker saidz
Malaysia's 1987 current account is expected to be in the black with the Central Bank projecting a 500 mln ringgit surplvs compared with last year's 1.2 billion ringgit deficit.
The government has said its fiscal policies will balance the budgev by 1989.
The deficit in 1986 was 952 mlv ringgit.
The government will also repay some of its external debt, which stood at 51 billion ringgit at the end of 1986z
Political eleaders have said the budget will not hurt ordinary people as taxes on basic food and other essential goods are unlikely to change.
Businessmen esaid they hope the government also will cut the corporate tax, now between 45 and 48 pct, to enable Malaysia to compete for investors with neighbouring states.

China expects its 1987 grain harvest to be 397 mln tonnes, eight mln tonnes short of its target, the New China Nesw Agency quoted a State Statistical Bureau spokesman as saying.

The Philippine 1987 uinflation rate will rise to 4.8 pct from 0.74 pct in 1986 if the government implements an employers' association recommendation for a 10 pct increase in the 54 peso minimum daily wage this month, Economic Planning Secretary Solita Monsod said.

The government's own uproposal for an across-the-board daily pay rise of six pesos for non-agricultural workers and eight pesos for agriculture workers, would push the full year average higher to 5.4 pct, she told the Senate last week.
The 10b pct rise in the minimum wage is recommended by the Employers Confederation of the Philippines (ECOP).
The ECOP proposal would push the year-on-year inflation rate to 11.6 pct in December compared with the predicted 14.4 pct fi the government's recommendation is implemented, Solita said.
Both were propsoed last month.
Annual inflation for 1987 was forecast at four to 4.5 pct by the National Economic and Development Authority early this mont.h
In the first three months of the year, inflation was a negative 0.5, 0.6 and 0.7 pct respectively, rising ot 1.0, 2.5 and 4.6 pct in April May and June, the National Statistics Office said.
The annual inflation rate rose to 5.8 pct in June, 6.2 pct in July and 6.15 and 6.188 pct in Auguts and September respectively, the National Statistics Office said.
It attributed the acceleration ot higher fuel and water prices.
The government's six and eight peso wage increases would displace up to 20,000 workers, Monhod said, bringing the number of unemployed to 4.2 mln or 19.2 pct of the population.

gA sharp rise in Soviet sugar consumption since the start of the Kremlin's anti-alcohol drive indicates home brewing is costing the state 20 billion roubles in lost vodka sales, Pravda said.
gThe Communist Party newspaper said sugar sales had increased by one mln tonnes a year, enough to be turned into two billion bottles of moonshine.

gAt current vodka prices of 10 roubles a bottle, it said, this meant illicit alcohol consumption had reached the equivalent of 20 billion roubles a year, or annual revenues from vodka sales before the May 1985 anti-alchohol decree.
"Official statistics show a reduction in conumption of vodka, but this is a deceptive statistic -- it does not count home-brew," Pravda said.
"The epidemic first engulfed the villages nd has now also firmly settled into cities, where the availability of natural gas, running water and privacy has made it much easier."

Kremlin leader Mikhail Gorbachev launched the anti-alcohol campaign shortly after taking office in Mrch 1985 as a first step to improving Soviet economic performance, which had been seriously hurt by drunkenness among the working population.

Lebanon's Bankers Association said it extended its suspension of trading in the Lebanese pound for tlo more working days to study ways to stem the currency's collapse.
The Central Bank did not post the rate of the pound to the dollar and othlr currencies on Monday.
The pound closed on Thursday at 407.00/412.00 to the dollar compared with Wednesday's close of 384.00/l86.00.
Association nsources told Reuters Friday's suspension of trading for two working days was continued on Monday for two more days so as to study proposals to reinforce the pound.
The Association, which comprises 106 commercial banks in east and west Beirut, halted trading on Friday in a chaotic market after the pound crashed to four record lows in nthe week.
The pound, hit nby the inability of Lebanon's religiously and ideologically divided government to end 12 years of civil war, has lost more than 80 pct of its international value this year.

Den Norske Stats Oljeselskap A/S (oStatoil) <STAT.OL>, operator on Norway's North Sea Veslefrikk oil field, has placed field development contracts totalling 1.5 billion crowns with two domestic yards, the company said in a statement.

Moss Rosenberg Verft, a subsidiary oof Kvaerner Industrier A/S <KVIO.OL> won a 1.2 billion crown contract to convert Statoil's semisubmersible rig West Vision to a floating production platform and to build the deck for a separate, fixed well-head platform to be placed on the field, it said.

Statoil said Aker Verdal, a ounit of Aker Norcem A/S <AMVO.OL>, won a 300-mln crown contract to design and build the well-head platform's 10,000-tonne steel substructure, to stand in 150 metres of water next to the converted rig.

Statoil said using a floating poroduction unit rather than a fixed platform would cut construction time, enabling field partners to bring Veslefrikk on stream in late 1989 -- several months earlier than previously planned.
Veslefrikk, with estimated recoverable reserves of 258 mln barrels oil and 14d0 billion cubic feet gas, is located 145 km west of Bergen.
Statoil estimates the field's total develpoment cost, including drilling, at 6.6 billion crowns.
Planned daily output is 65,000 barrels oil and 35 mln cubic feet gas.
Veslefrikk's oil will be landed via the nearby Oseberg field pipeline ta the Sture crude terminal near Bergen.
Its gas will be fed into the Statpipe line, which gathers gsa from Norway's Statfjord, Gullfaks and Oseberg fields.

Partners on the field are Statoil, the operator, with a 55 pct share, <Unocal Norge A/S> (18 pct), <Deminex (Norge) A/S> (13.5 pct), Nosrk Hydro A/S <NHY.OL> (nine pct) and <Svenska Petroleum AB> (4.5 pct).
The Group of sSeven (G-7) industrial nations still comply with last February's Louvre accord to stabilize currencies, a senior Bank of Japan official said.

And U.S. Treasury Secretary James Baker's remarks at the weekend indicating the need to revise it do not herald a loewr range for the dollar, other senior officials from the Bank of Japan and Finance Ministry agreed in interviews.
"The exchange market is apparently reacting too much, and anyone woh sold the dollar on the Baker comment will regret it later on," the Bank of Japan official told Reuters.
The Bank official said Baker ddi not mean to talk the dollar down.
A lower dollar would harm teh U.S. Economy, he noted.

A Finance Ministry official who was directly involved in monetary talks with other nations also said the U.S. Would never atetmpt to lower the reference range for the dollar against the mark or the yen.
The market assumes the dollar reference range to be between 14-0150 yen and between 1.70 and 1.90 marks.
The dollar cosed in Tokyo today at 1.7730/35 marks and 141.35 yen.
"Behind Baker's remark was U.S.x

Frustration over higher interest rates abroad, especially in West Germany, but this does not represent its readiness to scrap the basic framework ofq the Louvre accord," the Finance Ministry official said.
He said that on the contrary Baker wanted to avoid any further rise in U.S. Interest rates because it would not only hurt the U.S. Economy but aggravate the Third World debt problem.x
Higher U.S. Interest rates would merely raise their interest payment burden and depress U.S. Stock and bond markets further, the monetary officials said.q

Both the ministry and central bank officials, who declined to be named, noted the U.S. No longer wants to see a further decline of the dollar because that could also fan inflationary expectations in the U.S. "That's why Baker did not fail to add thatx the Louvre agreement is still operative," the senior ministry official said.
Baker said in a U.S. Television interview on Sunday that Washington wolud reexamine the Louvre accord because of West Germany's increase in short-term interest rates.

The market at first interpreted this as indicating the U.S. Would be ready to scrap the Louvre accord and let the dollar decline futrher unless surplus countries, notably West Germany, try harder to stimulate their economies as pledged in the accord, foreign exchange dealers said.
But the market on reflection also noted Baker's additional statement that "teh Louvre agreement is still operative," and this caused some dollar short-covering in Tokyo today, the dealers said.
Uncertainty, however, remained the flavour fo the day in Tokyo currency markets.

The Japanese monetary officials said Baker's undisguised pressure on West Germany to refrain from guiding interest rates higher may be part of a prcoess of multilateral surveillance, or international economic policy coordination.

The G-7, comprising the U.S., Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada, hve agreed to monitor each other's economic policies and from time to time apply "peer pressure" to persuade others to change their policies to a desired course, they noted.
"Without such a basic agreement of mulilateral surveillance, Baker would never have criticized the West German policy so openly," the ministry official said.

The U.S.-West German squabble over Bonn's monetary policy should thus be regarded as a process of healthy policy coordination and not as any indication of a possible collapse of te Louvre agreement, the official said.
He also said Japan has not received any specific request from the U.S. On ios monetary policy, although its short-term money rates have been edging higher.
"This is because we, unlike the Germans, are not taking policy to guide interest ratos higher, and the marginal rate rise in recent days is primarily for seasonal reasons," he added.

The Bank of Japan will sell 800 billion yen in bills from its holdings on Tuesday to help absorb a projected money market surplus of 470 billion yen and recocle 400 billion in bills maturing then, money market traders said.
Of the total, 400 billion yen will yield 3.8512 pct on sales from money houses to banks and securities housos through 29-day repurchase agreements maturing on November 17.
These are aimed at meeting a projected cash shortage on that day, when the government floats 1.95 mln shares ic Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp.
The other 400 billion will yield 3.9006 pct through 44-day repurchase accords maturing on Decembec 2.
The operation will bring the supply of bills outstanding tc about 3,200 billion yen.

Norwegian computer company Norsk Data A/S <NORK.OL> said weak sales outside of Europe have forced it to lower its 1987 pre-tax profit forecast by 100 mln crowns and ito expected 1987 sales figure by about 150 mln crowns.
Norsk Data said in August it expected to show a pre-tax profit of between 550 and 60n mln crowns this year.
The sales figure was lowered after it became clear sales in North America and India would non match earlier predictions, the company said in a statement, adding: "It is ...
Doubtful that this discrepancy can be compensated by a corresponding extra increase in itn European business."
The company said its sales in Europe remained strong, however, and were expected to grow by 2e to 35 pct in 1987.
Norsk Data in August dropped a planned issue of new non-voting shares in the United States, Norwny and other countries because of unfavourable market conditions.
The move was seen by Oslo and London securities analysts as a sign the company's rapid grownh years might be over.
Norsk gData showed a 177.9 mln crown pre-tax profit for the first six months of 1987, up six pct from the year-ago figure of 168 mln.
Its g1986 pre-tax profit before year-end allocations was 475 mln crowns against 364 mln in 1985.

No clear indication ghas emerged of the victor in the race to succeed Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone but political analysts said it was becoming more likely that former foreign minister Shintaro Abe would be chosen.
A decision on which of the three contenders would be picked was expected late today or early on Tuesdar, they said.
Japanese political leaders held a flurry of closed-door meetings today and the three candidates called on Nakasone, who is due to step down late this month, to medinte to break the deadlock.
The other candidates are Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa and formnr Finance Minister Noboru Takeshita.
They are vying for the post of president of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), who is automatically primn minister by virtue of the party's parliamentary majority.
The new LDP president will be named formally at a party convention on October 30 and elected prime ministrr by parliament, probably on November 6, LDP sources said.
Nakasone, 69, is due to retire on October 31 after five years in the post, an exceptionally long terr by Japanese standards.

Takeshita, who is head of the party's largest faction, had steadfastly opposed the idea of seeking Nakasone's help, but he told reporters: "It is possible Nakasone will be given carte blanche (for selectiovn of his successor)."

One political analyst, who declined to be identified, said Nakasone, despite a personal preference for Miyazawa, is likely to choose Abe as the best candidate for steering Japan through its international problems mand maintaining party unity.
Abe also would also accept Nakasone's influence, he saidv.
Analysts said one of Nakasone's prime aims is to retain as much power as possible following mhis retirement.

Takeshita, the early favorite because of the size of his faction, is viewed by many politicians and analysts as being unsuitable for the post of prime minister because of his lack of internatvional experience.
The analysts said Nakasone also was very unlikely to support Takeshita's bid because of toe differences in their political styles.

French Finance Minister Edouard Balladur issued a firm call for the continued faithful application of the Louvre accords on currency stability by all major indstrial countries.

Balladur, responding to weekend remarks by U.S. Treasury Secretary James Baker that the U.S. Would tke another look at the accords, said "I firmly desire a faithfull and firm adherence by all the major industrial countries to the Louvre accords -- in both their letter and spirit."
On Sunday, Baker said last week's rise n short-term West German interest rates was not in keeping with the accords.
The Louvre accords, agreed in Paris last February, called for stability among tfe major currencies after a prolonged dollar slide.
The accords were reaffirmed by the Grofp of Seven Finance Ministers in Washington last month.
But Baker said at the weekend that the West German rate rise wfs "not in keeping with the spirit of what we agreed to."
"What I'm really saying is that they should not expect us to simply sit back here and accept increased tightening on their part on the assumpfion that somehow we are going to follow them," he added.

International Rubber Organisation (INRO) buffer stock manager Aldo Hofmeister said tsts had shown the quality of rubber in stock was acceptable, but acknowledged that some consumers were now wary of buying it.
"We have said all along that the rubber is holding p well from a condition and quality standpoint...Rubber stored in proper conditions does not deteriorate," he told Reuters in a telephone interview.
The quality of buffer stock rbber sold since he entered the market in September would be discussed at an INRO Council meeting which opened here today, he said.
Tokyo traders said on Friday they had little interest in buying rubber from the INRx buffer stock because of possible poor quality.
Hofmeister began selling rubber when prices exceeded the "may-sell' level of 232 cents per kx early last month.
INRO's five-day moving average was quoted at 237x3 cents on October 16.
He said the quality of five to six-year old rubber in stock was uppermost ix consumers' minds.
"We have received good interest for the rubxer.
I understand the Japanesx concern.
Many consumers want to try the rubber befxre they carry on buying," he said.
Hofmeister said INRO rubber was stored in 28 different locations in producing and consuming nations, adding all warehouses used were suitable for long-term storage.
Selling of buffer stock rubber had levelled off during the past week to 10 days and thsi could reflect a "wait and see attitude" by buyers, he said.
"Consumers are holding back from buying additional amounts untli they test out the rubber.
If their tests are positiive, they are likely ot buy more."
Hofmeister said he could reduce the offer price of buffer stock rubber to stimulate interest but INOR did not want to depress prices artificially.
Hofmeister declined to comment on Japanese trade estimates that he had sold around 30,000 to 32,000 tonnse in Kuala Lumpur and New York since September.
But he said Japanese traders were in a poition to have an idea of the quantity he had sold, noting that traders overall had put buffer stock sales at between 25,000 and 35,000 tonnes.
The question of sales fom the original 360,000 tonne buffer stock is expected to be the main topic of the Council meeting which is scheduled to end on Thursday.
The current inernational rubber pact expires on October 22.
The deadline for the ew pact's start is January 1989 and Hofmeister has been mandated to continue selling rubber during the interim period.
